reviewText:
Starpoint Gemini 2 is a great space rpg.

usually a statement like that needs clarification, so here we go.

this game is basically if you took the most complicated parts out of games like x, opened up the game world like evochron mercenary and throw in a control system not unlike eve online. what im getting at is that its not as complicated to play as the aforementioned games but leaves the best parts of each and marries them into a system thats fresh and familiar.

one of the things that irritated me about the x series and evochron for that matter is that missions had to be acquired at a station. my question has always been, why? no long range communications in either universe? in SPG2 that is a thing of the past, when you enter an area, you will be notified when missions are available and you can accept missions directly from the starmap

which brings me to the next point. the starmap is one contigious area, like in evochron, there are no load screeens and while the actual area is smaller than evochron, its a lot more detailed visually. so yes its probably not 100% true to life because there are very few areas that just look like a black void in space, but the visuals are well done and give you more to look at than just black with white dots everywhere.

controls are reminicent of eve online though i havent played it in years, it reminds me of that. not necessarily a terrible thing, but if you are looking to find yourself in the cockpit of the ship, these ships dont feature cockpits. if anything even the smallest class available would have a bridge. so in comparison to the ships in X or EM, youre piloting a capital ship right off the bat. in fact to give some comparison, the M5 through M3 classes of ships in X are basically bought as commodities to place in the hangar of carriers. you wont be flying anything that small and if you were, youd have reason to be very very afraid. it would seem that the gemini system doesnt build much of anything in small scale :)

As of this writing there are a few technical issues that arent game breaking but considering the devlopment team is very active and even communicates with the players regularly i feel that this game will evolve into something even better. if you like rpgs and space games, this will be right up your alley. LGM has done a great job keeping the game fun and challenging without making it a nightmare to learn how to play.

reviewText:
I love space sims. I don't even know how much time I sank into freelancer or the x3 games. Yet this one I am dropping after a bit more than 10 hours of playing.
Let's start with what I like about this game: The graphics are good, the different ships with their various layouts are cool, you can customize your ship through enhancements and hiring officers, the energy transfer management (engine, weapons, shields) is interesting, and on the surface the game feels like it is trying to marry the best parts of freelancer with those from the x series (which means many things immediately make sense if you have played those games before).

However. Somehow the game feels like a chore; something I am willing myself to play in the hope that if I continue a bit further it will finally become exciting and turn into the great game it has the potential to be.
The story is inherently boring. Fly from A to B, listen to some terrible voice-overs, destroy a target (ambushes being optional), get an (uninteresting and unusable) item and no real information other than fly to XYZ to get more info". But you need to grind a few side missions first to level up enough for that. Rinse and repeat. I have lost all interest in the main story and there is just nothing that compels me to continue playing it.
The other sidequests and missions are okay

reviewText:
Starpoint Gemini 2 recently left Early Access, and it is now one of the few games of that honour to actually turn out well. If I was to compare it to anything, I'd say it's like Freelancer or an offline EVE, though not quite as complex as the latter. Complete sandbox freedom. Go wherever you want and be whatever you want, whether that be a trader, pirate, mercenary, miner, fighter, explorer etc.

Though it is a space sim, it also plays a lot like an open world RPG. You pick from three different classes - COMMANDER: has a focus on buffing friendly units, GUNNER: all about maximising firepower and ENGINEER:  boosting your own power systems and hacking/debuffing the enemy - and go around doing freelance missions, mining, fighting or exploring, and it all gives you XP (and sometimes money) to level up your character. Levelling gives you the ability to spend points on improving your class skills, which can be used in battle, and attaining perks, which provide buffs to a number of things like increasing troop strength for boarding ships or improving trade prices.

Besides the sandbox 'Freeroam' mode where you are able to freely explore, there is also a recently added Campaign mode. This provides you with story missions, but you lose the ability to pick your class, character portrait or choose from one of the three starter ships (it forces you into a Taurus ship, arguably the best of the three anyway). The story isn't great, and it's a little buggy, but you can still freely explore and do whatever you want while doing it. The story missions are not particularly interesting (go from point A to B, kill target, deliver package, meet NPC etc), but they give you something else to do. If you're feeling aimless and not sure what to do next, the campaign missions can be a good way to provide yourself with a sort of goal or objective. Each mission will advance in level and difficulty, and you will often find yourself needing to gain XP and a more powerful ship in order to advance. I found that It added to the feeling of progression, albeit in a not very interesting way. It's completely optional, but I personally had no interest in it.

There are nearly a hundred ships to acquire by either buying them or grappling and boarding an enemy ship, killing the crew and towing it back to a nearby station to either sell ( for a very high price ;] ) or place in your garage for use, and they are all customisable. You can equip them with a variety of different weapons like railguns, plasma cannons, beam weapons and heavy weapons. You can enhance your systems by purchasing upgrades for things like your propulsion engines or shield generators. You can even give them a new paint job and add decals, though the colours don't stand out too well and the decals are just a short list of basic emblems. You do have the ability to add your own custom ones, but I didn't mess around with that feature. They're nice cosmetic touches, but nothing to rave about. The boarding is also fully automated and you don't actually get to see anything happening. It's nothing more than watching troop numbers rise and fall and choosing whether or not to send reinforcements. Quite unexciting to say the least, but stealing ships this way will be your main source of income, and managing to capture an expensive ship still gave me a lovely feeling of satisfaction despite the lack of a more involved system.

Your ship is freely controlled, you can fly it yourself wherever you wish with the WASD keys and your mouse. You also must manage your power output. Do you divert all power to engines to give yourself a speed boost, to shields to make them hold out longer, to weapons so they fire for longer or do you try to balance between them all? It's very situational and you will find yourself having to tweak it back and forth very often when travelling and in combat. It's a system I quite enjoy as it keeps you occupied and helps with keeping the combat and travel feeling busy.

Speaking of combat, it's very fun, though not too complex. You can aim and fire your weapons yourself or have it done for you with autofire (though it can be inaccurate at times) and positioning is key. You and your enemy have four directional shields, one for each side, and each decreases under fire accordingly, meaning you should focus fire on one side if you wish to do optimal damage. If any of you have played Star Trek Online, the shielding is pretty similar to what that game has. You also have a choice of four skills, which differ depending on your choice of class. Each provides some sort of combat buff and can be levelled to add more effects. On top of that, there are then a multitude of items you can purchase and use whenever you wish, such as temporary speed boosters, repair drones or T-Drives (these allow you to instantaneously jump great distances) and a variety of other things. If used right, they can really save you when in a tight spot.

One issue with the combat however, is balance. I often found myself easily destroying ships marked as 'impossible' targets to beat due to having bought a reasonably expensive weapon or by managing to acquire a powerful ship. This can really mess with the early game and make it far too easy. It does begin to even out the further you level due to enemy scaling, but as long as you continue upgrading, it never gets difficult enough. This is tricky to do however and really only becomes a problem once you're comfortable and good at the game, which takes time.

Overall, and despite some flaws, I believe this to be a good game with a lot of love and care put into it by the devs. It is just oozing with content and interesting, well polished mechanics. If the developer's words are anything to go by, a huge list of future content is still planned for Starpoint Gemini 2 and all of it will, supposedly, be completely free of charge. Hopefully a game to keep your eye on.

I highly recommend this to anyone who is a fan of space sims, sandbox titles and even people who are awaiting Elite: Dangerous or Star Citizen. It's not overly complex and it does lean a little more on the arcadey side of things, but despite that, it's still a deep enough experience to sink some enjoyable hours into.

Score: 7/10

reviewText: Starpoint Gemini feels like a PC game I played when I was younger. It's relatively rough around the edges and there is nothing groundbreaking about the graphics--but it represents a kind of space exploration game in a very cohesive package. The soundtrack is filled with ambient electronica and is a real highlight for me; scanning pulsars and exploring unknown reaches of space feels extremely gratifying and peaceful at the same time.\n\nThe game itself lets you explore space however you choose: you can become a merchant flying cargo through sectors, a bounty hunter going after pirates, an explorer of the universe and scanning anomalies and space oddities etc, etc. It's a game with great potential that doesn't hold you hand from start to finish. If you have any interest in Sci-fi/space exploration games (Freelancer/Star Trek: Bridge Commander/Eve Online) this game does a great job filling that role.

reviewText:
I would not recommend this game to anyone but the most hardcore fans of the genre, and that provided the price comes down.

While I do acknowledge some might enjoy the tedium and vaccum, neither I, nor any of my friends did. Core mechanics are grind, fetch&kill 'quests' and exploration. You also pick up things and sell them off at the nearest friendly station, or buy things at one point and sell them to a trader across the map for profit. The game world is huge and fun to explore at first, but given the lack of variety (it is space, after all) it will get boring afer a while. Combat is nothing like a proper space sim - you either get projectile weapons and miss, or directed energy (beam) weapons and hit 100% of the time via automatic turrets. These make the whole combat thing ridiculous - all the fun is outsourced to your onboard computer. The game seems to be balanced with this in mind - you can either turn on the auto tracking and let the computer do the fighting or die.

Fun parts:

-exploration. the playing environment is huge! Volumetric shadows, nebulas, asteroid and debris fields and planets are stunning. It does get old after a while given the game's shortcomings
-visuals as per above. Nothing you haven't seen in X3 already though
-ship designs & variety

The not-so-fun parts:

-tedious, fetch&kill tasks that pass for quests here; gets old in about 10 minutes
-the game is vacuous. think mmo without quests or other players.
-as of now the game is bugged and some options are greyed out. No, despite what the industry standard for indie games seems to have become lately, it is not okay to release an unfinished game with greyed out options and scenarios that 'will be added later on'. That's what early access is for!
-repetitive, unaccomplished space combat
-the 'RPG' portion of the game comes down to several global stat boosts and 4 active skills, which I've not seen to have any serious impact on the game

reviewText:
A worthy addition to your steam space strategy titles. It starts off a little grindy but once you get over the initial credit problems the fun really begins. Over 70 ships to buy and fly from gunships all the way up to carriers and dreadnoughts. You can trade and fight across a large area with many many different factions.

Customize your ship how you like with different officers, weapons and equipment and choose from a large amount of skills and perks to further compliment your ship.

There are two modes to play, campaign for a single player story and sandbox. The effort has obviously been put into the sandbox over the campaign.

One really annoying problem and probably the only major one for me is the abyssmal camera control. Something that should be bread and butter for a game of this type. you have to use something called turret mode to get anywhere near the type of camera your used to in just about every other game of this type. Unfortunately even turret mode is a floodlight type chase cam.

Despite the camera problem I heartily recommend this game for anyone who is missing a fix of space goodness.

Here is a taste of cruiser gameplay:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=52P0HA4Z2RM&list=UUStoZzu9ABIECmDstifxIgA&index=3

Here is a taste of Dreadnought gameplay:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wOlJ0gwYzAo&list=UUStoZzu9ABIECmDstifxIgA&channel=letsplaykherny

and lastly some Carrier footage:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xVVd0RNp1-U

reviewText:
As far as sequels go, this one didn't dissapoint. Awesome graphics, awesome sound, tons of ships, stations, new and smarter enemies, aspect of pirating, trading, hiring mercenaries... Highly recommended space sim with excellent graphics and beautiful music soundtrack. It's released after a year in Early Access, but I enjoyed the EA so much, I met beautiful people that are like my family now and now we all greeted full release as if we were getting a child. And putting this gem into Early Access was really a smart move and I'm sure devs would agree with me.

Community is so dedicated to this game that words cannot describe it. Parallel with the game, modders are really busy and are releaseing new mods and updates as we speak. Star Trek mod for all you Trekkies out there is a nice addition.

So the conclusion is - If you like space simulators with nice RPG elements, this one is epic win.

Buy it! Download it! Start it! Assume command!

Full disclosure: When I wrote this review back in 2013 and when I updated it after the release, I was not part of LGM team. After I joined the team I forgot about this review and got an advice (below in comments) to tell you all that I'm part of the dev team now to avoid any misunderstandings. So if you think I should remove the whole review of the game, please state in the comments below and I will remove it. But as for review, it's based on my experiences as a player so it has nothing to do with my status now. Anyway, I think you should know. :)

reviewText:
With only 3 hours play this is only first thoughts.

A worthy title. If you have played any of the X series of games this is it's younger and not so complicated brother. In some ways it is more like Freelancer but either way it has nods to all these games whilst keeping it light on the learning curve.

You can jump right in and start blasting asteroids for early bucks and the early missions (freeplay) are doable with the starting ship.

I have several mods that give me Star Trek ships and a Star Wars universe to roam in which are both from the Steam Workshop.

In short (in earlry play) this is an instantly playable space trading/shooter that looks and feels great but don't expect the depth that the X series has (which for some people will be perfect ;) )

7/10 Go give an asteroid a new bumhole.

reviewText:
Starpoint Gemini 2 is a complete turn-around from the quality of the first game. It's prettier, it's satisfyingly complex and most of all, it's a lot of fun. It's blend of RPG elements, freeroaming gameplay and atmosphere is great, and pretty well refined. While the voice acting isn't anything to write home about, the simple joy of adjusting the loadout for your ships, hiring officers, mercs and troopers, and leveling up can be downright intoxicating.

A couple small issues nag at me, however. At the time of this review, the ability to adjust shadow quality or post-processing in the video options menu is still locked. There are some balancing issues that make themselves painfully apparent within the first hour or so of gameplay, namely the rate at which you accrue money. Tackling big number bounties might seem like a great idea, but they're prohibitively difficult (as of level 7, all the available bounties were way way out of my level range) and grinding freelance missions can sometimes feel monotonous. Additionally, the lack of communications chatter between ships can make space feel somewhat sterile. When rescuing a ship from pirates, it would be great to hear a panicked captain's voice pleading for assistance, or thanking me for the help. These are minor gripes about what amounts to an overall great experience.

Granted, I haven't played through a ton of the story campaign content, and my time with the game might be small compared to others, but having seen such a triumphant turn-around from the first entry, I felt compelled to gush a little bit, and congratulate the developers. Well done, guys!

I tend to not be one to jump on the early access titles very often, but it was honestly really cool watching the development of this game, seeing community input being utilized, and watching something grow from nothing. I can say truthfully that I don't regret purchasing this game during early access in the least.

4 out of 5 stars.

reviewText:
It took nearly 20 hours to finally come to a conclusion on this game.

Despite all efforts made to make the combat complex - energy management, 4 different active abilities (with a kinda silly feeling levelups with them),  and up to 4 consumable items (of a selection of around a dozen) useful for combat - it just isn't all that fun. I believe the biggest culprit is turrets. While it is possible to partially blindside a less maneuverable ship than yours in 1v1, ultimately maneuvering and dodging in combat is best done by spinning around in circles. When you're spinning around in circles, you can't effectively target and attack targets manually, and so you rely on fire-at-will auto targetting to do that job for you. This is boring.

The economy is workable, but not that interesting - different stations have a set low-mid-high value for all of the commodities. Buy and sell appropriately.

The storyline is workable. The Gemini universe is interesting, and is worth reading about if you're into that sort of thing. The storyline does an almost adequate job of immersing you in that universe. The voice acting/writing is awwwwwwful.

The good: All around, this is a workable game that will scratch your spacefaring itch, though will likely not leave you satisfied. The graphics are beautiful, each region of space is very well stylized in the coloring, asteroids, and various anomalies. Plenty of the starbases and ships have pretty unique detailed models. Music and sound are good, although the short soundtrack for the music is a mild disappointment there.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I had this game gifted to me by a friend(Thank you, Thune!), and it's easily one of the best space games I've played in awhile.  If you enjoyed the freedom that the X series gave you, but absolutely hated the UI(or lack there-of), this is a game to rectify that.

Flying your ship is quite easy and fun, combat is rather fluid and in-line with the class of ship you're currently flying.  Combat is definitely part of the game, but certainly not the only aspect.  You can shoot asteroids for resources, scan anomalies, salvage wrecked vessels(of your own making via combat, or derelicts you find), send troops onto enemy ships in attempts to capture and then tow them to a station(strip them of fittings, sell them, or keep them for yourself), there's also trading between stations and planets.

Everything you do awards some experience points(running missions, scanning anomalies, killing things, etc), which is then used to upgrade your character's abilities(weapon skills for railguns, lasers, plasma and heavy weapons; want your railgun shots to have a chance to fire twice with one volley?  A chance to penetrate shields and hit hull?  Longer bursts for your lasers?  Put points into the appropriate skills.)

The devs are very active on the forums and always listen to the community, even adding community ideas into the game regularly.  They also really want the modding community to have as much control as possible to expand the game; as evidenced by the Steamworkshop support.

I expect great things to be afoot for this game in the future, and even in early access it's fun to tinker around and see what you can get into.  The engine is solid and the dev team is very much hard at work, the community following the game is strong.

I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys open-world space games with no loading screens.

You will likely notice it straight away when you start the campaign.  The voice acting is certainly better than that in the original, however it is still poor. reviewText:
Short Version: If you like space tactical combat, exploration, a bit of trading and if you're not just looking for another stupid space dogfighting simulator, this might just be the game for you.
At a decent price and with DLC at a very low price, this game is totally worth a shot.
It's not without it's flaws though.
The devs, apparently, take player input seriously and are constantly looking for ways to further improve the game, which is rare nowadays.


The long version:

The Good:

- You actually feel like you're in command of your ship. You're flying tripulated ships with several guns and missiles to fire on your enemies and sometimes even fighters and bombers to assist you! This is not another stupid dogfighting style camera view". It's more tactical and I love the devs for making that choice.
- Combat is very interesting and you can decide how you want your engine/shields/weapons focus in the middle of the fight.
- Graphics are very good and the design is "colorful".
- You actually feel like you're evolving as you advance in the game and have access to new ships. There are many options to suit your playstyle.
- You can fly Capital ships (dreadnoughts and carriers) and they're not useless sitting ducks like they're in EVE online. In Starpoint Gemini 2
date: you can actually destroy smaller ships in the blink of an eye flying one of those
recommended: as it's supposed to be when you're flying a freaking Battlestar with fighters and tons of guns at your disposal.\n- Devs are constantly looking from feedback from the playerbase and they're very active on forums
hoursPlayed:
taking players advices and questions and participating on the debates in a polite and helpful manner.
- You can send your troops to board enemy ships and try to steal them in a very interesting and original mechanic. Nothing like trying different strategies and escaping with a nick of health from a battle after taking your former enemy's ship with you in tow back to a station.
- Capital ships!
- DLC at a very low price that offered some new content.
- Did I mention Capital ships?!

The Bad:

- Several things are not clear on the tooltips and there are no manuals inside the game. There is no "ship encyclopedia" as you'd expect on a title like this.
- The difference between weapon types
voteText: bombers
helpfulPercent: fighters and interceptors is not clear.\n- There are not too many weapon types in the game. It seems like it lacks some variety.\n- There is no clear DPS indication. There's an "average" indicator on weapons

instead of firing on everything and everyone around randomly as it is right now.

The Ugly:

reviewText:
Product received for free

Short Version: Grand Space Sim that puts you in command of a space ship to fly, shoot, trade, save the universe, blow up stuff, do the laundry, collect files hidden in floating junk, level up, hire recruits, upgrade your ship, and do pretty much anything else your starfaring heart desires.  The game looks nice, plays well (albeit at a slowish pace), has enjoyably 'space-y' ambient music, and offers a ton of different content that may not always 'wow', but will definitely satisfy.

Starpoint Gemini 2 reminds me of a giant, sword-wielding turtle.  No, really! Just let me explain...

Waaaay-back-when, in those wonderful 8-32 bit Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtle video games, you could play as one of four characters, each with different strengths and weaknesses: Raphael, who had tiny, short-range, but superfast attacks; Donatello who was really slow but could whack-a-ninja from half a screen away with his staff; Michelangelo who specialized in... I don't know, making pizza with nunchucks? Or something?  And then there was Leonardo, who didn't attack quite as fast as Raphael, and didn't have quite the reach of Donatello, and didn't (pizza?) quite as well as Michelangelo - but hey, he was a very close second-best at *everything* and pretty dang awesome as a result.

Sooo... if space games were mutant turtles, then Starpoint Gemini would definitely be Leonardo.  Sure, some dedicated RPGs have better character development in stats and story (and DEFINITELY voice-acting), and some starfighters have more intuitive controls without the need for a gazillion tuturial screens and HUD informational windows, and some trading/exploration games have a more lifelike economy that can fully support your character as a pacifist (read: cowardly) trader... but Starpoint 2 offers ALL those types of gameplay and more, and all done extremely well. This enormous range of enjoyable gameplay content is the greatest feature of Starpoint Gemini 2.

All-in-all, SG2 is a huge Space-Based-RPG/Combat/Trading/Strategy/ShipBuilding/Sandbox-Simulator mashup that may be slightly flawed and a bit slow-moving compared to games that 'specialize', however the astonishingly vast scope of gameplay content is all well-done, nicely polished, and most importantly... fun!   With a large campaign and moddable freeplay mode spanning half a dozen genres, Starship Gemini 2 is second-to-none in being second-to-all - but hey, so was Leonardo, and he became the leader of the Ninja Turtles for a reason!

(*SIDENOTE:  Despite evidence to the contrary in this review, Raphael was actually the best turtle.  Of course, comparing Starpoint Gemini 2 to a giant mutant *sai*-wielding turtle would have been utterly nonsensical, so I went with Leonardo.)

Received a free copy for testing/reviewing purposes.  This review is part of the Steamified Community Review program. For similar reviews and fantastic giveaways please visit http://www.steamified.com/.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Finally a game that has the potential to be even better than Freelancer - and that says something.
Took me about 2-3 hours to get familiar with everything and to be able to play the game properly, even after playing years with space sims and space, so allow yourself a bit of time when first playing.
Still in beta at the time of writing, so if something not works as it supposed to, for example crashes, or missions cannot be completed, strange enemy behaviour, do not get annoyed, the devs are constant fixing bugs and writing the game, developing. It is in a playable state already; you get a fairly powerful ship at the start, you can fly around, explore, get missions like repairing space bases, destroying pirates and playing taxi between distant bases. There is a good(ish) tutorial on the start to which you can go back any time, so you are not left alone to find out what is where.
My biggest problem was having the ship not powerful enough, not fast enough and not having strong enough shileds until I found out about the quick and very handy power distribution feat - this is in the tutorial, but the information was so overwhelming that my attention slipped by the end and learned as I went along with the missions. I think (hope) there will be a smoother tutorial in the final version, perhaps like the one we get in Eve.
Everything I have seen in the game so far makes me think it was a good buy and worth every penny. I'm looking forward to see the final version and what other goodies will the devs come up.
Recommendation: BUY IT !!!!

reviewText:
A game that surpass expectations and delivers countless hours of fun and excitement to any space Sim fan.

I came across Starpoint Gemini 2 when the lack of time made me stop playing X3 Terran conflict/AP. I'm a huge fan of X series but the amount of options you have are so vast that consequently increases the complexity of the game and therefore the time you have to invest to progress. Unfortunately with work and all, I just stopped playing those majestic games.

SPG2 is not that complex and therefore its perfect if you want most features that a space Sim should offer but in a simple and easy way. You still have it all... Trading, Mining, Piracy, Boarding and countless more things to do, just way more accessible.

Recommend 100%

reviewText:
This game takes a bit to get used to. Also theres not too many guides to tell you the smaller information. Like if selling or buying the colors change. (Green good -red bad) between selling and buying.  So if your buying an item that is green its a better deal and if your selling an item  that is green its a profit.  Also they don't address the fact that after you take over a ship through boarding you need to grapple with the ship to take it back to a base to sell.  I left 1 ship out in space on accident that way.  Also there is a huge curve when it comes to getting new ships.  The first zone only carries 3 ships so your forced to go to different spaces and bases to find the one thats right for you.
9/10 gameplay (Its fun to play in space thats open ended)
6/10 support (even manual doesn't answer all the questions)
7/10 controls (especially in fights its hard to steer unless you stay still by cuttng all engines.)
6/10 Missions ( The missions are almost all the same)
8/10  Graphics (The graphics are good quality)
9/10 Customization (Would be 10 but they really don't explain why certain weapons don't go on ship)

Overall I give this game a solid 8/10.

reviewText: With all the recent updates, this game is finally playable. I think their biggest issue was releasing this so half finished originally.\nIf you enjoyed old school games like privateer, you'll find some neat similarities, mixed with freelancer style controls. Its got a lot of good structural things going for it, but still feels light on content, which is understandable given that its a small dev team working on it. If you are looking for a hardcore space sim, this isnt it, but if you are looking to fly around blowing things up and occasionally have an interesting battle, then you are in the right place.\nI continue coming back to this game to see new updates, and if the dev guys continue to produce content, I think this will flesh out quite nicely, so that the universe doesnt feel so barren with the same 3 mission types everywhere.

Ever since I played Starpoint Gemini, I have been a big fan. The original game was very easy ot use and not too overly complicated to use. The game was in 3D, but only flew in 2D, so it wasn't hard to get form point A" to point "B" with little effort.

Starpoint Gemini 2 takes the original game several steps fruther. The concept is sitll the same. You are a space pilot looking to make a name for yourself in the age of space trader. You can either play in campiagn or in freemode.

reviewText:
I don't often write reviews, but when I do, it's for a product I love. Starpoint Gemini is probably one of the most fun space games I've played. It feels reminiscent of the X series in a much-welcomed third person perspective(Though you have the option of using a mounted cam perspective instead if you prefer), with the noticeable lack of any empire-building elements to speak of; likewise controlling a fleet is very limited by comparison, and as far as I'm aware you have to be pretty far into the game to even start a fleet.

The game, much like X, has a campaign option(Which I haven't played and therefore cannot comment on) and a sandbox mode. In the sandbox mode, you pick a starting ship and get thrown out into the universe with the usual obnoxious tutorial screens, and then it's pretty much straight into the action. Your prime objective for most of if not the entirety of the game will be to make more money, which you have several options for obtaining, such as mining, hunting criminals, trading goods, or pirating goods. It's all quite fun, but the payouts are generally small in comparison to the price of ships and equipment upgrades, meaning you're definitely going to have to spend several hours chauffeuring sales reps and diplomats through hostile territory and mining asteroids by the hundreds to ever afford that ship upgrade, but this is balanced out by the fact that the starting ships are pretty powerful generally speaking, and should last you as long as you'll use them... Though that doesn't mean that the money grind is any less monotonous.

I'm not saying it isn't fun. It's just not as rewarding as it could've been. You grind money for the sake of getting a bigger ship, for the sake of grinding more money more easily, for the sake of getting a bigger ship. Perhaps the campaign provides more variety, but the sandbox is in desperate need of some more money-sinks.

Graphically, the game is a joy to look at, though the fact that I rarely dabble into anything this modern could be skewing my opinion here a little. The art style is reminiscent of a cartoon or an anime, and colours are very vibrant, making literally everything stand out dramatically. The only thing worth complaining about in terms of graphics is the little debris particles that fly past your ship during movement, as they're practically the size of my tiny gunship's cockpit, but thankfully there's already a mod to remove them.

All in all... It's definitely not a bad game. There are better games out there for the price, but I'd still recommend picking this up if you have money to blow, especially if you're a fan of space games. And if it's on sale right now, slap yourself for even giving it a second thought and then buy it. Just a forewarning however, it will definitely annihilate your social life.

reviewText:
If you liked Freelancer, you will love this. Though, so far, the story hasn't been as engaging as Freelancers but there is a freeroam mode that basically cuts that aspect out of it and just throws into this really well designed and nice looking universe, for you to do in as you please.

The combat is awesome, the UI is nicely layed out and easy to understand and the game isnt overly complex for the sake of being complex (I'm looking at you X series). The soundtrack is pretty cool too.

Its quite fun and addictive for now, but I can see it becoming quite repetitive. I'm sure later on in the game things become a bit more interesting with bigger ships and fleet battles, but the early game requires a lot of grind it seems.

I recommend buying this on sale, as it is at the time of writing this review. I can't say, yet anyway, if its worth the full asking price. Though I am having a lot of fun with it at the moment.

reviewText:
I've seen a lot of comparisons for this game to other popular titles and I think that is a disservice to this game, because then you start looking at what this game doesn't have.

Here is what the game DOES have.

Great graphics at low hardware cost.  The game looks good, it looks clean, the ships are detailed and the environment is gripping, and you don't have to sell your soul to play it.

Great music.  It's the type of music you'd expect to hear if there were an intergalactic space composer.

Lots of ship options:  There are enough choices to make your personal mark on the universe.

Space:  Everything is better in space.

Combat:  Everything is better with combat, especially in space.

Great development team:  They are VERY involved with the community and the community is VERY involved with development, in the best ways I have ever seen, ever.

It is a good game, at a low cost, that will provide many hours of enjoyment.

reviewText:
This game was exactly what I had hoped; a mix of EVE online (minus the spreadsheets) and more action orientated space games like Freespace.

I played through the storyline which served it's purpose of driving things forward but beyond that is rather forgettable. It also featured some of the worst voice acting / writing I have heard in a long time. Thankfully the sandbox of different mission types, trading and exploring more than makes up for it. One of the more enjoyable scenarios is ship capture where you have to whittle the targets shields and hull down to the limit and then board the ship with your troopers with the aim to capture it. This has big pay off's and lets you bank huge sums of money to buy new ships and gear.

The ships are the main stay of SG2, they are nicely varied and do not fall into the EVE trap where every ship has to have its trade off's, in SG2, a Dreadnought can kick serious ♥♥♥ against all sized ships as you would expect and is a blast to play with.

This game is a solid 8/10 and had me hooked all the way up until I had the best Dreadnought and Carrier available and could just mop up. Definitely looking forward to SG3 with hopefully some more budget thrown at it to get some writers / voice actors in to bring the lore to life.

reviewText:
Trader, Warrior, Pirate, Explorer, Bounty Hunter, Miner, Smuggler - a few of the things you can be in the Gemini Sector.  This game puts you in the boots of a newbie starship captain in one of the most volitile areas of human colonization, and it's your choice as to what you will do with your newfound freedom.  Will you avenge your father and find out why he was killed in the storyline?  Will you go off and discard your past in the free-roam sandbox mode?  The choice is yours.

You start out with a very basic gunship, but the game doesn't limit you to one ship like some others (Darkstar One, X-Rebirth), but instead gives you the option to upgrade and upgun in one of several ship classes.  Do you like the thought of zipping around in a fast, maneuverable stealth corvette?  You've got several to choose from.  Maybe you'd prefer to roll into a hostile area in one of the mighty dreadnaughts or carriers and outgun everything in the zone (except perhaps another dreadnaught or carrier)?  You can do that, too.  Or you'd like to be a trader, working your way from your starter ship to a freighter, and then a freightliner, ferrying cargo, buying cheap and selling high.  Again, your choice, but remember to pack guns to keep the pirates off your back, as they have the same choice in ships as you do!

You'll do all of this in a *very* good-looking setting that has NPC ships doing their own thing according to their own agendas.  My personal favorite example of this was the time I was attacked by a group of pirates.  I was in a destroyer, which is fairly middle-of-the-pack in speed-to-guns/armor, and flying with a group of trader ships.  The pirates jumped us, I engaged...and the traders *bolted!*  Left me there and ran, as they weren't going to stick around and slug it out with pirates that outgunned them (being businessmen in freighters rather than naval officers in warships, it seemed their AI told them to GTFO).  Just as I was swearing to hunt them down (if I survived this and didn't have to reload halfway across the map), security forces from the nearby station arrived with battleships and cruisers and what was a brutal last stand became a lopsided pirate turkey shoot.  Brilliant!

Starpoint Gemini does a lot of things right, and the devs have shown a lot of interest and support in the community.  There were a few bugs on first release, but continual support has polished this into a real gem most space-sim fans will enjoy greatly.  9/10

reviewText:
A very good game. Don't expect it to last longer than 2 weeks though. You can do a lot of things like:

1. Upgrading your ship.
2. Commanding a carrier type ship with 4 turret slots and 4 missile slots.
3. You can board another ship.
4. Station defense / Station assault type of missions.
5. Launch fighters/interceptors/bombers from your ships.

The thing is that it's a very short game with a ton of good gameplay that'll keep you hooked. Unfortunately, you find yourself doing repetitive things (like boarding, mining, etc.). You'll eventually find yourself with more money than you can count and you've basically done everything there is to do in the game.

Compared to other gaming simulators, this one is a junior. Great to get back into space sims, but not your goto" space sim.

For your "goto" space sim

reviewText:
Ok this is my edited review. I'll try and be semi-objective as I have interacted with the dev's, their moderator and the community for some time. But please read on and judge for yourself.

Spg2 is a tactical space combat sim. I joined in EA and didn't play it for long due to hardware limitations on my account but liked the idea of a big massive universe where the player doesn't end up being the King of the Hill" but just a small piece of a bigger universe. And Spg2 filled that need for me.

This is not the most epic game I've ever played and I didn't expect it to be. But from a small ~10-ish Croation developer team I've been surprised. Not only have these guys made their own engine which shows beatiful graphical capability but they also constantly updated the game for almost a year after release with steady patching and a nice and cheap DLC while being constantly (I can't express how crazy these dev's are when it comes to listen to player feedback and troubleshooting with the community
date: it's unheard of) active on forums and responding to any bug report they received and fixing it with each new update. This is more than half the reason I'd buy any game they'd ever release.\n\nWell about the game; There are more in-depth Space Games out there
recommended:
more epic stories to be told. But this game doesn't pretend to be any of that. It knows it's limitations as a huge space universe where the player is just a small piece of the puzzle. And it does that extremely well. Imagine being in a single-player MMO ( yeah kind of contradictory) but that's how this game treats you. You're nothing more special than the next dude around. You won't change the Universe all by yourself but you're just a small part in a bigger scheme. I love that sense of relating to your own existence in the world.

How many games dares that anymore? In an age where we all feel we're the turning point and center of the Universe this game is a fresh breath teaching us the Universe doesn't resolve around us but we're just here to try to survive and do the best we can.

There's no classic story arch to this game. You don't end up feeling like you're the king of the world. You're just a captain in the void trying to fend for him or herself. That's it. And from a philosophical perspective I love that notion. Too many games rub your need for being the "one and only". Not this game. This is reality expressed through a game. You're not gonna matter more than others but still need to claim your place in the world. That's beautiful and invigorating and  ... well poetic in some sense.

There's a story (campaign) in the game that lends itself to the lore created in Spg1. But former knowledge of that is not required. I am still on the last mission of that storyline but that's not the reason I play Spg2. I don't relate that much to the story as such but enjoy the stories I can make with my own captains more.

The game lets you choose between story and freeroam missions at a whim. You can always wander off to do randomly generated missions even when playing the campaign (campaign has a fixed character while freeroam lets you generate your own male/female character) and explore as you see fit. My preference and love for space was to be more of a "freelancer" doing randomly generated missions for different factions making friends and enemies along the way depending on my choice of the missions I'd carry out for different factions (help one faction=lose reputation with another faction and vice versa).

The game can be a grind for some
hoursPlayed: other cherish that type of neverending possibilities and in Spg2 the ever-changing possibilities for changing your reputation and the constant randomly generated missions can keep you playing this for hours on end.\n\nSome days I just log in
voteText: cloak my ship and enjoy the scenery. Other days I just log in to take my temper out on whatever faction I'm currently in bad standing with and make them suffer.\n\nFor a better description of the game check some videos on Youtube or other reviews. I'm still sold on this thing and the constant updates
helpfulPercent:
a very nice and cheap DLC plus the upcoming FREE DLC makes me wanna recommend this game to everybody. Best and coolest development team I've ever meet and a hell of a positive and friendly community.

This game is Steam History for the books. The reason I still get into EA from time to time is because of these guys right here.

This is a game made by gamers to gamers. And a hella lot of respect for their interaction

If you're in doubt visit the forum. These guys are the future of gaming and a pinnacle of how developers can make gamers trust and cherish them again (yeah plenty of jaded gamers out there seeing bigger companies ♥♥♥♥ all over their customers or make highly dubious decisions).

Edit: It should be noted that this game twists a few familiar concepts of games and how to progress the best possible way. There's not much "hand-holding" here but the forum is pretty active to anyone needing a tip or two on how to get the most of it and learn those "different" mechanics/understanding from what other games usually bring. So remember to pitch in with questions if there are any or you don't understand something. The early game in particular can be a bit rough for new players but once they get a hang of it it's really not that hard to understand.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is about to enter Beta.  As it stands, the game is not only playable, it's stable and fun!

Everyone compares the game to Freelancer, which makes a lot of sense.  The input for flying is similiar with mouse and keyboard.  But I like the fact that you captain a capital ship instead of flying a starfighter.  Even smaller ships (like the Destroyer you start out with in the Alpha) have a sense of weight and inertia in their movements.

It's a fun game, with a slower, more deliberate pacing than a starfighter game.  There's time to decide your own fate while being pounded on by your opponents.  You end up feeling like the captain of a tall ship at sea.  Which means they must have done something right.

There's no campaign yet, but sandbox offers a complete game in and of itself.  It's a career mode, so there is persistent progression, kind of like a campaign might have.  There are tons of ships to buy, and plenty of missions to run.  Or you can run around getting into trouble, and you'll progress just as fast.

So far, I haven't needed anything that isn't implemented yet.  In fact, the only things I've actually missed up till now are the jumpdrive (T-drive) and cloak.  Other than that, nothing feels like it's missing.

It's well polished at this stage, which makes sense since it's one week from Beta.  The graphics and UI look slick.  Anything that's actually implemented at this stage is almost always bug-free.  The game is very stable, too.  I don't think it's crashed once on me.

This is March of 2014, and as it stands the game provides a satisfying experience to play repeatedly.  It is on sale till the 17th, but will have a price hike immediately afterwards as it goes into Beta.  Also, buying it before Beta will give you 1 free copy of the original game.  A fun tide-me-over till this game is complete.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

even for its beta state, game is very promising. i expect it to become a new modern X3 for space sim/shooter/rts fans.game gets updated very frequently, i only think that s because due to positive outcome product of sale amount. i mean steam playerbase support should be good enough to make the devs work hard like this.

i want to point some unique points about this game.

-enhancement system for ship parts, not only you can change your offensive,defensive,special outputs but you can also further tweak the bonuses with part enhancement, offers you very high amount of combinations.
- high amount of factions, each faction's missions gets randomly generated depending on your current faction standings.thats nice. that means your actions have consquences.
-you can actively own a fleet, and make them support you in battles or transport/hauling/smuggling.
-crew salaries really a good money sink, something to think about.
-game supports modding. enuf said. ^^

now a bit of negatives :

- currently since game is beta, the main storyline is not out yet and freelance game mode(sandbox) offers  a bit repeatitive missions.
- traveling might take some time, there s no time acceleration/deacceleration
- using map, pauses your game. you cant watch your ship moves while on starchart. that makes creating waypoints make game stop and cost you time.
- current number of pilot classes only 3 and each has 4 different active abilities, these 4 abilities each has 5 sub categories changing characteristics of active skills, this s a bit few, could have been more.
-after accepting each mission, you have to find objective area/station etc manually via starchart. you gotta click each marker and see which one lets you create waypoint/jump etc.
- accepted and offered quests have same color markers on starchart. again no visual clue for finding your active missions' waypoint.
- there s a quest log but not really helpful , doesnt fully work atm. therefore if you serious about completing your missions, you gotta take and complete 1 by 1. unlike other rpgs you cannot hoard multiple missions and do it with a spree.not at the moment. Doesnt apply to people with super memory
- you cannot purchase spacestations or other type of stationary npc controlled objects. not yet.



TLDR, summary : the game runs smooth and not many bugs for its state, gameplay wise there re many things to add. lack of variety atm might be boring but combat is fun and makes up for it. im pretty sure as it develops, many new features gonna be added and this game has potential to beat X3 in future in open beta. only if devs keep the game updated just like now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You want to adventure trough SPACE!
You want to become a famous merchant or a pirat !
Maybe join a guild or become a privateer !
Frelance and explore the mysteries of the Universe !
Become a scientist or mine asterods and other space junk for goods !
Build a small army or an armada and wage war torugh he galaxy !
Do you wnat that.
IF YES, THIS IS THE GAME FOR YOU!

With soo much features and more coming by the end of Early Acces one can only imagine what this game is capable of.
In addition to that the development team is one of the most fan-dedicated out of all the other's.

There's only one thing missing form this game and that is multy player but I'm a solo player so I won't hold it against it, or you could play EVE ONLINE and pay the monthly fee. :)

Overall the game looks and feels gorgeous. The music is ambiental and realy sets you in the mood for the game.
Combat is a bit slow but it's to be expected... and that's coming form a long Ace Combat fan, still trying to find the perfect interceptor/fighter for my play style but I'll find one sooner or later... nevr give out hope.

reviewText:
The closest a game has gotten to Freelancer since, well Freelancer. If you liked that it's definitely worth trying it out but keep in mind it still has a few noticable flaws:

-Doesn't allow gliding and the dogfighting gameplay that made Freelancer the most fun
-Default keybinds feel like a mess (also doesn't support shift/alt combos at the time of writing)
-Space feels much too crowded for being something that should be mostly empty and everything is in a single large system
-You'll need a cloak to fly anywhere without constantly getting stopped by random enemies that pop out of nowhere
-Again, because this deserves to be said more than once, game doesn't allow you glide while only using thrusters to change direction

On the positive side this game includes more and bigger ships than an unmodded Freelancer did and also has more extensive wingman and trading capabilities (like in the X series).

6/10 Worth to at least give it a try but maybe wait for a sale

reviewText:
6 out of 10

Starpoint Gemini 2 is a space exploration and combat game.  In short, I expected somewhat more.   In the end I just could not finish it as it just dragged on and on.

The good:
1. Great platform.  Space, ships, weapons etc.
2. Capturing enemy vessels.

The bad:
3. I always seemed to die at the most inopportune times.  Then need to reload and re-traverse the same bits over and over.
4. Storyline is not very exciting.  No animation or something else to give it some life.

The ugly:
5. Very repetitive.  The game needed more unique locations and content.

reviewText: This game looks beautiful, even on the lowest graphics settings. The music is wonderful and sound effects are great. Voice acting is... well, pretty terrible in all honesty, but I'm really impressed that a pretty small indie developer managed to get as much voice acting in this game in the first place! That tends to be an enormous expense in any game, and it's still better than the voice acting in Just Cause 2 or Strike Suit Zero.\n\nHowever, even with two years of steady work, the game still suffers of performance issues and frequent crashes. I can accept a lot of problems but I really hate having to restart the game so many times in one evening. Last I heard, the devs are still actively working on the game - I hope they'll find these last crash and lag sources and fix them someday soon, because until then I won't be able to play this thing more than maybe half a hour a day. If the crashes are finally fixed, I'll be more than happy to recommend this game.

reviewText:
Very good space game, I'm so pleased this genre is making a comeback!

I've not played a huge amount yet, but enough to get the feel for it and I'm really enjoying it so far.

In this game you are flyng a large ship with a crew, not a one-man fighter, so it feels more like Freelancer, ST Bridge Commander, or Independence War, but it has it's own feel. The ship handling reflects this and the control scheme works really well. I tried it with a flight stick, but it's not really that kind of game, the mouse controls just feel right for the pace as you seem to spend more time targeting, selecting systems and activating powers and perks, rather than 'hands-on' flying. There is a strong RPG element in terms of building up your character and ship with equipment, skills and perks to develop. There is a lot going on and I'm sure I barely scratced the surface.

Technically it's excellent, great graphics and effects, and not a massive system hog either. The soundtrack is very nicely ambient and helps to immerse rather then distracting.

There is great community around this game, and the developers are obviously very keen to make improvements so I can see that there is a lot of potential for future enhancements, but the game that is on sale now is a totally complete and functional product

My only criticisms would be that the universe seems a bit impersonal, and the setting poorly explained, being a sequel to a game few have played, and the script a bit weak and generic. The English voice acting is very flat, and it might have been better to stick to text to be honest, but it's farily sparsely used and doesn't spoil the game.

Overall, great game, well worth the price which is very reasonable for the amount of content and the mod support and supplied tools mean that it will have plenty of new content  to come.

reviewText:
When I picked up the first Starpoint Gemini years ago I wasn't impressed. Ugly visuals, awful voice work, uninspired gameplay, I just couldn't stick with it.

Imagine my surprise when it got a sequel.
A really, really good one.

I've been playing since Early Access and, though a little messy at first even then it had put right all the wrongs of it's predecessor and was blowing away the other Early Access space-sim I had my eye on at the time (yeah I'm looking at you Kinetic Void!)
What we have here is:
Graphics on par with the X3 series. Actually abit better - there is some fantastic lighting happening here, stormy nebulae to make FSopen jealous. My god it's full of stars! The ship models are wonderfully textured  down to turret details and the little holographic projector on the Ageba frigate.  I was particularly impressed  that you can name your ships and see the name decaled across the hull, little things like that are awesome. Also the tactical overlay was a really nice touch!
Full 3D plane movement (and and handy key to reset planar orientation)
A much improved interface with hotkeys for all the important stuff and nice RPG-style perk system for your captain. The skills need a little balancing but the devs seem to be on the path.
Reliable camera control - stick it in Turret mode and make judisicous use of the Space and K keys and it feels just like EVE Online!
A well fleshed-out free-roam setting with enough side-missions, customisation, exploration and combat to keep fans of Freelancer and Edge of Chaos happy.
And a much improved campaign with some okay-but not-great voice acting and dialogue that I'm more than happy to overlook because...
...The combat is fantastic. The UI is a little clunky but when you find the right set up it's truly a joy to play. Wether weaving a speedy corvette through a torpedo run on a convoy of freighters, weapons blazing like a battlescene from DS9 or cruising a small flotilla through a gas cloud to scan a subspace anomoly, this as close you'll get to EVE Online offline. It plays somewhere between EVE and Freelancer  with more than a bit of old Star Fleet Academy.
Active devs and built-in mod support. The devs have been really active and communicative all through Early Access and look committed to tweaking and balancing Starpoint Gemini 2. The whole game feels like a true labour of love for them. Steam Workshop already has some mods available and a a Mass Effect ship mod is in the works, as well as Star Trek ships and some small UI and balance tweaks from the community.

Starpoint Gemini 2 is a space cadet's dream, in a time when genre is still only tentativly coming back from the grave.
It's focus on capital-size craft instead of the more common starfigther cockpit is most welcome and fills oft an over-looked niche in the genre. I would've like to see a subsysem targeting mechanic more in line with Nexus: The Jupiter Incident where I can tactically pick apart my target but that's really small potatoes and the damage model here works just fine with critical hits offlining ship systems.

In the end as a sequel SPG2 far surpasses, and on it's own it's a triumph, capturing everything you love about epic space operas in a wonderfully realised package.
Trade, fight, mine, command and enjoy!

Highlights:
Engaging in a battleship dual in the middle of a lightning wracked nebula, desperatley jockeying for fireing arcs as our ships burn. KHAAAAN!!!!!

Joining the defense of a besieged battlestation leading a rag-tag squadron of gunned-freighters to back up small armada of warships as beam weapons cut the night.

The first time you're pirate away-team boards and captures a faction frigate and you tow it back to the shipyard as prize. Take what you can, give nothing back.


Drifting gently through the corona of a blue giant as a gentle acoustic guitar track plays you ponder the best place to peddle small arms and battle mechs and what the odds are you'll get spotted sneaking planet side.

reviewText:
Hi Guys

Updated 15th december.

After spending sometime into this game heres my review.

Pros

1) Great graphics and good music.
2) Freedom to roam and also a campaign to play.
3) Tons of ships, items to equip your ship.you can hire troopers to board and take over ships! Hire officers and also mercenaries.
4)You have missions available at different places where you can accept or reject to earn money and experiences.
5) Mods availble for this game.
6) You have traits and specials skills as you level.

Cons

1) Tutorials wordings are too small!!!
2) I find it not very user friendly even though the tutorials are there for you. It seems that I struggle for quite some time to get used to it and also the mission chart map seems nto well constructed. To me its not user friendly.
3)Something is missing in this game I am not too sure.

I will still recommend this game because of the things you can do in the game. Its the freedom to roam. This game is a hit and miss , If you are not sure I will suggest you get it on Sale or bundle. Its much more worth it.

reviewText:
Great Space Opera game with amazing graphics... Getting lost in this universe is just great. Can't stop taking screenshot.
Some of the ship just have great design and the artwork just add an extra touch for the immersion.
Smuggling, fighting, mining, trading, bounty hunting, capturing ship, escorting convoy or attacking space base. And much more...
I have to say I am seriously hooked, and the Dev are taking good care of their baby with quick reply and patches.

This is not a a space flying simulation as the game is optimized for mouse and keyboard. But that the way I like it, giving the game a nice tactical touch. It take a bit of time to get used of all the control but once you get them, you can get into amazing space battle : Surviving the  assault of an ennemy fleet on an allied Space station is just so rewarding.
You start the game with a fast but fragile gunship then after earning tons of credit anyway you want, you might control a fleet of Dreadnought and Carrier with fighter jet... Or just be a pirate with an op Ronin Destroyer (Best share ship in my opinion) cloacking and raiding any fat cargo ship or illegal space laboratory... All of that with a bit of role playing and a nice background with faction conflict and alliance.
Some might say that the game is not perfect : Voice acting sound a bit weird but I got use to it and actually I like it now; some other talk about empty content : like in Elite Dangerous, use your imagination, add some Role playing... Being a pirate for exemple and try to be friend with the evil faction is an interesting challenge :)  And the campaign will keep you busy for some time.

This is silver that could change into gold with the rights patchs and dlc :)

reviewText:
It's a very *loose* yes as a recommendation to play this game. If you can get it on a good sale, then it can be a fairly fun experience running around a small system of planets, doing odd jobs, buying new ships, and upgrading weapons. There's some decent stories involved and the devs have made some nice DLC's available for pretty cheap/free.

Downside: this game is buggy as hell when it comes to the control scheme, especially if you want to use a controller with the game. I happen to like using a controller; I feel like it's very relaxing and I can kick back in a chair. Using an Xbox One controller with this game, (or any controller) is going to lead to a hell of a lot of mapping issues that don't get resolved easily.

Also, loading up the DLC's can be kind of weird, since you're selectively activating them. Unlike games like Skyrim, where you can just roll up and jump into a DLC once you add it to your game with whatever save file you're using, this game like to cordon off the DLC's and have you jump sandbox to sandbox. They can be fun, but it's not always ideal.

That all being said... there's a ton of ships in this game and ways to arm them out. Whatever your playstyle, you'll eventually captain a ship that meets your needs, whether that be overwhelming destructive force, a carrier that houses a fleet, or a ship that can drop out of stealth and put the hurt on. It can be pretty addictive. It can ALSO be extrememly repetitive. You mileage may vary!

Final Verdict: yes, I'd recommend this game, but it really will appeal only to a specific type of gamer.

reviewText:
There is a very important tip in this review! If you're going to get this game, you better read on.

I tried to return this game after five hours of trying to make enough money to even by the next better laser in order to break the asteroids faster.  And, I can tell you I'm very happy that I passed the hours played deadline for returning it! This really is a quite fun game if you know the right way to make money!  If you think you're going to make money trading or mining, you got another thing coming! Forget about anything except capturing enemy ships.

When you go to a space station, on the upper left you can select hiring troops or mercenaries. Hire as many troops as you can, and then go find an enemy ship. Find an enemy ship that has as many or less personnel than the troops you hired.  The number of personnel is listed to the right of the 'lock on' information.

Destroy most of the enemies hull, but leave about a quarter. Then from your 'center mouse button' menu select send troops. Over on the right side of your screen a small flag will appear showing your troops are boarding the ship and how many troops are left on both sides. At this point you can click on the green arrow to send extra troops, if you don't send extra troops you will probably lose the battle.  If and when you capture the ship, and you must learn how to capture ships, use the tractor lock on in the 'center mouse button' menu. Then head back to a space station and sell it.

In the beginning ships get you about $100 K, maybe a little less. But that beats the $10 K per trip of breaking rocks. Then use that money to buy better lasers, missiles, and systems upgrades. You do not get experience points for capturing ships though.(unless it finishes a mission) Destroying ships gives you experience points. Once you have upgraded your ship as much as you can, then go start doing missions to gain experience points.

Make sure you save at least one of every higher level ship to use as you rank up. If you are good enough at combat, you can capture ships larger and better than yours. Then once you rank up you can start using them instead.  I have succeeded capturing ships with one third less personnel on my ship than the enemy ship. I think the worst damage to the enemy ship the less troops you need.

Definitely read the instructions in the upper right ? Icon.

Pros:

It definitely is a well-made galaxy. It's pretty, large, has lots of planets, anomalies, and wormholes. The wormholes can be a little crazy when you're in a battle and one grabs you and sweeps you away!

It has lots of great ships to choose from.

Plenty of different armaments to choose from.

Some armaments work well in some situations and then do not work as well in others.

Lots of side missions to choose from.

The campaign story is really good.

Cons:

Even though it has a good campaign story, the voice acting is some of the worst I've ever heard in most of the characters.  It seems like they went around from high school to high school looking for the worst of the drama students they could find to perform the stories.

The mission text portions have obviously been poorly translated. I think it was originally in German. A lot of the stories and side missions are just given to you in text form, and because of the poor translation it can be hard to understand what they are trying to say.

Considering the size of the galaxy they provide, the main campaign was too short. I did tons of side missions, finished the story, and still had half the galaxy unexplored. Since I find no point in just roaming around the galaxy for no particular reason, the rest will remain unexplored.

All in all:

It was totally money well spent! I also got the two extra campaigns which I will now go and play.
voteText: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is the space sim I've been looking for since I stopped playing Freelancer; big open world, customisable ships, factions, upgrades and a big open world. I get to fly around a large universe, exploring, trading, collecting bounties or mining and still feel like there's more out there to see/do. Maybe these things are available in EVE, but I wouldn't know as I don't get enough gaming time these days to justify a monthly subscription.

This game is about captaining a ship; the piloting and gunning controls work best if you select a target/destnation and tell the ship to attack or move.

Here's my first impressions after 20 hours:

Pros
Big open world (might have mentioned this already)
Customisable ships
Various factions to befriend / hunt down
Freedom to choose between merc, trader, explorer, etc
No game breaking bugs (so far)
Cons
Feels like a late beta - the DLC prompt EVERY SINGLE TIME I start the game, despite my saved games already using the DLC. There's also missing voice files for some conversations and custom key configurations aren't saved between sessions.
Voice acting, when it's there (some of the voice files are missing)
Tutorial - be prepared to click through screens of dull text every time you mouse over a control the first time you play and still have to look things up afterwards. Do yourself a favour and watch some YouTube guides instead.
Still I reckon this'll be one of my most played games by the time I finish with it.

reviewText: I received a press key during the early stages and have had the pleasure of watching the game take shape into what it is today.  The tutorials could still use a bit more work, though the game is a lot of fun once you get a handle on what you're doing.  It's a bit like Freelancer and other like-games in that you can explore different sections of the galaxy, do missions, mine for resource, buy/trade commodities, and so on.  The middle mouse radial menu, coupled with the starchart, makes interacting  with objects a cakewalk.  I still find combat to be a little tough because I have trouble figuring out and observing the available weapon arcs, though you can set the ship on fire at will" and fly around while the computer does all the shooting.  All in all

reviewText:
Only 4 hours into this game and it is wonderfully stable thus far. If you feel a bit burnt by another recently released space game, give Starpoint Gemini 2 a try - I really think you'll like it. If you are a Star Wars fighter jock you'll have to get used to flying a heavier ship. The UI is both intuitive and beautiful. This feels like a sort of dystopian 29th century Star Trek.

Edit: Now 15 hours in and this game just keeps getting better all the time. I took down a hero" a.k.a. a large ship with a threat level of "Impossible." The fight took 20 minutes and alternating between targeting the enemy's heavy batteries and subsystems. This ship jumped me and was not part of a mission.  My little ship a small Pegasus class gunship wore this bad boy down and the reward was 4 million credits! I decided to step up to a Corsair class rather than an even more powerful Frigate.

This is really a game to be savored and frankly
date:
I am so happy with Starpoint Gemini 2 that I really couldn't care less for Elite: Dangerous especially with today's (18 Novemeber) announcement that Elite: Dangerous will require constant online even in single player.

You can play this game as you see fit and don't be fooled into thinking that the explorable area is small because there isn't a whole galaxy to explore. I've only seem a tiny part of this game. Somewhere in the Community Hub of this game someone had posted a complete map of the game and suffice to say it is M A S S I V E.

Limit Theory is now the only other space game that I think will force me to divide my time if it turns out to be as good as it looks. CNo Man's Sky is still a long way off and Star Citizen is so bloated that I believe it can't possibly live up to the hype nor the budget which I think equals  the budget for Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan.

Simply put
recommended: Starpoint Gemini recaptures the magic of the great space games of the past like Indepence War I and II
hoursPlayed: the Freespace series
voteText: and the legendary Tie Fighter and X-Wing and all from a small studio. If you love space games

reviewText:
Graphics are good, action is nice, the gameplay smooth and mostly bug free.  In many ways this game does things exactly right.  So why the thumbs down?

Because it does one thing wrong and that one thing is enough to drag the rest down with it: It tries to use MMO logic in a single player game.  Which is to say that the grind is the whole of the content.  Do this mission to get credits to get a bigger ship with bigger guns so that you can do a mission with a bigger enemy to get more credits to get an even bigger ship etc etc ad hoc infinitum.  Once you hit max level and get the best ship there really isn't anything left to do except mindlessly blow things up at random.  It gets old really, really quick.

Yes there is a story option but the missions in that story are hardly any different than the randomly generated ones from freeroam.  They just add voiceovers to some rather poorly written dialog.

Still, the price is cheap and they game is entirely without it's virtues.  It just doesn't have anything to really hold a person's attention for very long.

reviewText: Some intial problems with the game almost made me eat my own scowling face with rage. For serious, it took four tries just to make it launch and once it did launch it took two restarts to make it launch without messing its big boy pants. Finally, I got into the game, started playing, and immidiately strangled myself with my own mouse cable. This will happen, don't panic. Just unwrap yourself or, if you have to, find an adult to help. At first the controls feel as stable as a drunken donkey with the skurvy, at least with a mouse. I flopped around for quite a while, but eventually not only was I flying circles around the bad guys, I was...no, I was just flying circle cause that's how I dodge enemy fire while keeping my guns trained on them. The point is the flopping became on purpose, cause stragedy; now the controls seem alright to me. The map is roughly six times bigger than something really, really big (a house, a small country, yo momma, etc.). It's big, like hugemongous. Think of something really big, and then know that this is much bigger. The game has two modes: Campaign and Freeroam, although a Campaign save can abandon the story to go chase space squirrels once you realize that space rodents are much more interesting. I played the Campaign for about an hour, then made a new character in Freeroam who is a morbidly obese, one-eyed robot smuggler with a ship so fast that no one has thus far been able to catch it and I regret absolutely nothing. Freeroam is why you buy this game. Freeroam will consume you. I have accepted that this game is my new family, and you must too. Don't fight it. Let Space Daddy carry you away in his big, strong hands. Shhhhhh..... 8/10

reviewText:
Starpoint Gemini 2 makes for a pretty enjoyable space sim experience, but it is very lacking in depth.  It tries so hard to give you the complexity one desires in a space sim with features like capturing ships using marines, scanning anomalies, and coming across derelicts just waiting to be scavenged, but in the end, these activities are very superficial.  They eventually become very routine and the rewards are often limited to money or experience.  Levelling up your character doesn't grant much satisfaction, except for when a perk point is given.

Not much is required before you'll be rocking around Gemini in the biggest ship the game has to offer, decked out with the biggest guns, with all the best upgrades.  Luckily, this doesn't make you the ultimate end-all-be-all combat god of the universe.  Combat appears to be balanced in such a way that you will always be vulnerable and dealing with this turns out to require very different strategies depending on the size of your ship.

Combat is one of the things this game does very well, and a challenge always awaits you as the game throws squadrons of enemies at you routinely, even the periodic Legendary or Hero ship, which offers an even greater challenge and huge money rewards for the latter.

Otherwise, this game seems like a pretty casual space sim.  You will get plenty of enjoyment out of it, but you won't get invested in it like you'd like, which makes the sub-40 dollar price tag perfect for the experience it offers.

reviewText:
This game is a TRUE open world space RPG. I really love this game, despite is few shortcomings.

Freedom: Full freedom to do whatever you want, wherever you want, whenever you want is why this game is great. You can become a full time miner and collect minerals, you can ferry goods from station to station and trade for money, you can capture enemy ships and DRAG them back to your base to sell.

Combat: Perhaps the best part of this game is the combat system. It is really like a 3d dogfight in space ships. Do not expect a true space physics, but the combat system is one of the most fun I have played. You actually fly the ship yourself and shoot the weps yourself. Direct full energy to shields to survive, weps to destroy, or engines to run like hell!

RPG: You gain levels as you go. You can kill ships for small XP or do missions for more XP. You can level up each of your 4 special skills, get bonuses to your profession"
date: and buy new ships at higher levels
recommended: each with their own special traits.\n\nGlitches: I have had about 10 full crashes in 24 hours of playtime. I have many out of memory errors when I still have lots in task manager
hoursPlayed: although the game still runs

reviewText:
