I´ve been looking for a game that resembles one of my old favorites, Freelancer so when I found this I got very excited.
Sat down, launched the campaign and boy did I smile once I had it all set up and flew through space on my way to my first mission. Gonna try to list some of the pros and cons below

Pros
+ Nice graphics
+ Awesome soundtrack (seriously, I leave the game running when I go to bed)
+ Lots of ships
+ Select between campaign and Freeroam and choosing the first won´t stop you from doing the roaming freely.
+ Many different factions
+ Huge map
+ Really nice controls once you get the hang of them
+ Active devs, seen them post in the steam forums many times
+ Many different ways to make money in-game
+ Rare drop blueprints
+ Achievements
+ Many difficulties (only tried normal)

Cons
- The voice acting in the campaign lacks feeling
- Sometimes it´s impossible to target things by clicking on them (think it might be a bug cause if you click on something else and then try again, it works). No real problem though since it´s uncommon and you can always use quickbinds for targeting stuff.
- I´ve had a few crashes since I bought it but since the game is being actively patched (and I haven´t crashed for a few days) it might have already been fixed or I feel confident they'll fix it.
- Might get a little repetitive after a while


Having played it quite a lot the past weeks I'd say it's one of my best purchases in a long time and it deffinitly deserves a strong 4!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After playing EVE Online (Non-Steam) I've been really looking for a space-sim similar to it but an offline version. X3 (Non-Steam) was the best one I've played so far, and Rebirth I've never touched because it looked pretty disappointing.

Music: The tracks so far are good and fit the game well but there's only 4 tracks I've heard so far but hopefully more will come.

Gameplay: Depending on the class you pick, you'll have a set of skills that you can utilize in combat or other purposes, there's a leveling system as well which you progress by doing missions, mining, exploring new sectors, repairing ships/stations, scanning anomalies and blowing other ships up, with this in mind the game felt like it was a Space Sim/RPG mix to me. Combat is good, I have freedom of movement and aim. It's also cool how you have troopers on your ship and you can get them to board other ships, unfortunately I never succeded.

Graphics: Ship/Station models, anomalies look decent, the background looks excellent, planets look ok but overall the game looks great.

Single Player: So far there's only a Sandbox mode where you can do whatever you want, there's no story mode at the moment but they have said that they are working on it and we'll probably end up seeing it sooner or later.

Summary: Starpoint Gemini 2 has alot of potential and It's pretty good for an early access title, so far I've enjoyed my time with and will continue playing it. One thing I would love to see is the ability to actually fly into the planets and explore the landscapes, not just dock on the planets with a menu and what not.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off I'd like to say that I can't recommend this game or not, its still in its development without a storyline yet. It has a lot of potential but also a lot of stuff to work on.

Much of what the others have said is absolutely right. The money/combat balance system is so wonky at the moment. There have been times I fought 2 'impossible' ships and knocked them out almost immediately, and then 3 'trivial' ships have taken me down a little while later. Using manual aiming is a massive handicap because you can only fire from a few turrets at a time and trying to lead a ship is next to impossible at many ranges. I have yet to come across another gun, light or heavy, that is stronger than the ones I started with.

The skills and perks are lackluster at best, you start with all the skills and simply increase the efficiency slightly. Every five levels you get a perk, and again, that just adjusts your efficiency with one thing or another, 8% more money when trading, or 8% more damage with railguns, etc. Very uninspired stuff.

And then the money, over the course of a week I got about a million, which isn't enough for any ship. Then when I get to a particular station I kill a bounty without even realizing the ship was one. After selling at the station, I get another bounty, and another. In the course of an hour I get 17 million and can pretty much afford whatever I want, except I can't fly much at the level I'm at.

All in all it is a game on the cusp of having something really good going for it. There's a lot of potential here and I'll continue to play and explore because I do find it entertaining.

reviewText:
Edit: This was a review of the EARLY ACCESS! This does not reflect the new content added in the update, but once I play the retail version enough, I will be sure to update!

For a while I have been looking for a good open-world space game, with nothing really looking like a decent game. For me, spore is the most experience with a space-style game, which I really loved, but I wanted to move on to better things. Then I saw Starpoint Gemini 2 in development. After watching some videos and seeing how fantastic the game looked, I decided to buy it, which was an excellent decision and one that I recommend anyone reading this review to follow.

Little more needs to be said about the visuals. They are fantastic. Combat is also really well done, and content is surprising since it is still in development and only has one gamemode so far.

The most disappointing thing about this game for me was that there is no option to actually explore planets. This is purely a space exploration game, which of course is why the price is not rediculously high and is very reasonably priced especially for a game so modern that it is still in development. That limitation is really the one thing which is keeping this from being my dream game, but it is definitely fantastic for what it was designed for. Just make sure to dock whenever possible so that you can save and not lose a ton of progress!

Overall, I definitely recommend this game whether you are new to the space scene or a veteran. Especially at this price point, it is an excellent buy!

reviewText:
A very good space game, enjoyable in freeroam and the story mode seem pretty interesting.

The only thing bugging me about the game is the frequent pauses and stutters whilst flying through zones - the game will literally stop for a second, at first it didn't bother me but since starting the story mode the pausing seems to stand out more and has become a pet hate. Going to wait for a few updates and hopefully this will get cured, not sure I can finish the game whilst this is an issue.

I'm going to recommend the game because it is a really fun game, if these pauses get cured it will be really enjoyable, and I do think it will be cured because the devs have been doing a great job.

(And before anyone blames my spec for the pauses - I'm using a i7 4770K, 16GB ram, GTX 770 and the game is running from a 3TB WD black.)

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWow! I have played a lot of Freelancer over the years and always looked forward to a second comming if you will. With the recent surge in SciFi games I have tried my chances with a few and been let down (X-Rebirth I am looking at you). However this game keeps the syplicity of Freelancer with ideas from today. Honestly it really takes the best from Star Trek Online and Freelancer in that it allows you to be what you want but gain levels along the way with a pretty good skill tree. I really enjoy the freedom to do what you want combined with an RPG element. That way I actually feel like I am getting somewhere. Ordinarily I would wait to post a review however with these types of games I can usually tell if I will like them based on my love of Freelancer (hence the constant name drop). This game also has a full workshop so there is the possibility of endless content. There are already Star Trek mods and I am sure that more are to follow. All in all, if you need to scratch the Freelancer itch and you are tired of waiting for Robert's new game, please try this one. For the price it really cannot be beat.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's Freelancer+. That's a good thing.

Still in Beta, but the game so far is enjoyable.

Pros:
Freelancer-style gameplay
Good visual design-ships look different, still cool
Multiple mission types keep gameplay from getting stale

Cons:
Still in Beta. Bugs, incomplete features are part of that
Faction reputation system is linear, outlaw-to-lawful instead of faction interactions
No storyline missions (yet)
Steep learning curve at first, even for vets
No shield balancing, despite having sections of shields

Overall, probably an 82%, definitely will go up before official release

reviewText:
I've had Starpoint Gemini 2 since Early Access, but I didn't know how to play it. Only a couple of days before release from beta did I start watching YouTube videos on how to play it and since then I've been having quite a bit of fun with it. I'm hooked.

Right now, I'm ten hours into the game playing Freeroam; I haven't even begun to scratch the surface of this huge game. I kinda like how I can go in-game if I have some time over and just do a couple of quick missions, while, if I want to play for longer, I can do long trips to the end of the galaxy that will take hours and involve lots of exploration and combat. It's beautiful, it's fun and it's satisfying. I like Freeroam mode, but there's also a storyline mode.

The modding is going to be awesome. Watch out for some big total conversions for this one! Also, the community and developers are really friendly.

reviewText:
This is a great game. Graphics are top notch with a really nice pellet of colours used. Story line is easy to follow. Plenty of ways to play like mine, trade, police, smuggle or fight. Down side is learning the controls.

The tutorial is like a wiki, text and image based which I found hard to follow. I tried to play using my controller but found it impossible to shot because the controller buttons for the menu were the same buttons to fire and target, this meant I could not manually fire my guns. If I am missing something maybe a video tutorial on how to play with the controller would help so maybe a member of the community could help here.

Once I switched back to the mouse I found flying around quite enjoyable. You do not have to fly far to run into some action which I liked. Over all I like this game very much, and did I mention the great sound effects and epic music.

reviewText:
This game can be summed up as a modern day Freelancer, but with capital ships instead of fighters. It shares many similarities with the aforementioned game, as well as some enjoyable improvements, and will probably be the best single player Freelancer-style space sim available for a good while. With Star Citizen focused on multiplayer, look no further than Starpoint Gemini 2 to fill the gap between the two.

Like Freelancer, you can play with keyboard and mouse, with a rather familiar flight control style to Freelancer players. But although SG2 offers support for other gaming controllers, it's far from polished right now - it's near-enough unplayable with the popular Saitek X52 HOTAS, given the rediculous deadzone on all axes. However, if anything, the keyboard and mouse feels more natural to use in this game anyway, given you're playing the role as a ship (and later, fleet) commander.

Comparing this game to the failure that was X-Rebirth, SG2 comes out on top. Although more arcady, SG2 is significantly more enjoyable from the getgo.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You can pilot anything from a gunship to a carrier (you can NOT pilot fighters, they are launched from carrier class vessels), do freelance missions like assassinations (destroying marked ships), assistance (Fight off attackers and protect a ship). However the ships you have to destroy are not necessarily your enemy, in fact they could be allies!

The game might be in alpha (going in to beta very soon), and there are bugs/missing features (Alpha is alpha after all). But in it's current state it is highly playable and very fun for anyone interested in piloting their own spacecraft, and the developers interaction with their playerbase is very commendable. I see them answering questions in almost every quistion topic here on steam, and they are active on their own forumes as well.

I have heard the original Starpoint Gemini was not that good (I have not played it myself), and if that is so: do not fear, this game, even in alpha, is very enjoyable. Any spacesim enthusiast will get their moneys worth, and then some!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Starpoint Gemini 2 is a game I've been following for a long time, hoping for a game that would dethrone Freelancer from its rightfull place. So far things look good and this might even be the case in the future, but as of now there's still plenty of work to be done. That doesn't mean SG2 wouldn't feel good to play. Does it?

The game features a rather large open area The Gemini Star System. It's filled with stations, shipyards, bases, asteroid fields, junkyards, enemy ships, friendly ships, planets, anomalities, practically everything you would expect from a sandbox-type space game. It feels like there's a lot to do out there but at least for me that's not the case. This is because the game features very few different types of missions for the moment. There are freelance missions which you'll accept over the map view and then start them by docking with the correct facility, ship or planet. These missions usually involve hauling passangers or goods from the dock point to another. There are also scanning, repairing, patrolling and I think I even saw an assassination mission. These might keep you busy for a while but the samey repeating content of each mission type quickly lose their charm.

The game's main emphasis is on space combat which for the most parts feels good. Ships fly in space and trade fire with missiles, beam weapons, plasma and railguns. Fighters fly out from the bigger ships and engage the enemies and boarding parties can devastate the enemy ships from within. You can fire manually or tell the game to target and fire on the target for you. I find this helpful since handling the ship in combat can be a real pain.

You control your ship through two different control mechanics. The default one uses WASD to steer the ship while the mouse is used to target, shoot and activate buttons on the GUI. The second method is using the mouse to steer the ship. The ship turns along your mouse movement much the same way the default steering in Freelancer was handled. I prefer the former method in this game since using the mouse flight feels overly sensitive and I can't seem to make the ship fly straight or stay on target.

In combat you also have to keep your ship from taking damage and face the stronger shield at your enemy while also focusing on distributing fire from your weapons evenly enough so you can have a sustained stream of fire at the target. I'm not sure if this is the intended way to fight but I've found it effective. You can also enter the turret view to move the camera and aim targets around your ship freely, this helps you to shoot targets your ships is not directly facing at.

The combat is fairly entertaining, although like I mentioned above, steering the ship can be difficult and the default camera angle isn't helping much. When you need to fly on target it seems you have to place the target somewhere above your ship, close to the top edge of your screen. This is the actual direction the ship is moving towards to and it might take a while to get used to that. Also because of the odd camera angle I often had to keep the enemy above" my ship to be able to fire the majority of my weapons at it. This just feels wrong
date: at least to me.\n\nThe GUI is what really bothers me the most. It's overly colourfull
recommended: oddly clunky and the sound effects are horrendous. I have a tendency to go for a "minimalist" kind of look when it comes to user interfaces and such. In this game the UI makes me think of children toys
hoursPlayed: the large plastic kind with full of teeth marks and bright flashy colours. Actually
voteText: now that I think of it
helpfulPercent: the overall design and look of the game is overly shiny and gleamy. The ship designs could also be a tad more imaginative. Even the large battleships just look and feel like one-man fighter crafts even though they are supposed to be much larger than that.\n\nOverall the game has potential to be extremely entertaining. I like it so far even if the things I mentioned above might feel a little harsh. I've got great expectations for this game
votesHelpful: although experience has taught me not to
votesTotal: but I can't help it. I'm longing for a good space combat/sim/whatever that has the feel and openness of Freelancer."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Only clocked in around 7 hours so far but woa... i am blown away.. even in alpha stage this game just shows an great potential and already nicely working elements such as capturing ships. You earn you money the way you want! nothing is forced as of now you can even flee or just ignore enemy ships... to be honest i think and hope that i found what i am looking for in a space game... but enough of me talking here is what i love and hate in it:

Pro: Gorgeous graphics,
Random Events
lots and lots of different ships to fight/fly
large map to explore

cons: occasional frame drops (dusty asteroid field on the first spawn point... for me thats a brute videocard killer :D)
Controls might be tricky (i use gunner view all the time while flying with keyboard its fine this way for me)
alpha... i ignore the small bugs and stuff that are a usual visitor to ALL alpha stage games so ... yup
occasional small lock ups (1-2 sec) when an event/area is loading (but i kinda think this is only for me and my rather                        weak pc)

Buy: If you want a very good space Single Player RPG and if you have the patience and nerves for an alpha (meself i did not encounter any huge bug and only had game crash one times so far)

Dont Buy: if you are afraid of Alpha's (there is nothing wrong with that its totally acceptable) and if you are inpatient for them.

9/10 for me (-1 is due to some lag issues I encounter)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is like what others have said, lacking in entertaining content for the moment, story, challenge on demand, and does have you with little to do after a certain amount of time.

However, i still recomend this as a purchase for early access and most definitly recomend feature complete status on-ward.

The game runs smoothly and brilliantly, and how many early access games can you say has a games workshop up n running at this stage? there are 3 ships available right now in the workshop from star trek, one of the three is one im unfamiliar with, so perhaps an original model idea.

new content will steadily flow into this game that has had me checking every other day for new workshop mods or new patches that allows for entertainment in of itself.

I recomend early access to people who would actually want to see a game develop into something new and unique, you can help using the workshop, and even if you dont have the skills, they do not kid around when they say they are using OUR idea's. Suggest something in the forums, however simple or elaborate as you like and they WILL consider it.

There are compenies we've seen who have had amazing communities launching suggestion barrages at them just ignore every single one and watched as the game died off (i have one in mind specifically for this =p) yet here, just take a look at the forums, at how often you get responses from the dev's in regards to suggestions. I've heard of a wish list that includes a unicorn!

This is a game to keep an eye on at the very least, i feel we'll see great things from this gem in future.

I've been looking for a game like Freelancer for years because I've loved how it was open-ended and how you could do anything you wanted, apart from having huge ships. This game however does everything Freelancer did and more. You can have huge ships if you want, you can have a fleet of ships and you can get gigantic ships with the mods. There's already a titan class ship mod. The game deserves at least 9/10 from any and all aspects. Yes there are bugs and yes some missions aren't completed and yes there is no campaign mode or multiplayer, but the sandbox is more than enough. Keep in mind that this is early access and they are going to add a campaign mode.

This was what I was looking for. This game deserves to be played and loved.

reviewText:
Great game and great customer support!



SPG2 is not a Flight-Sim like the X-Games... its more likley a point and click and Flight-Sim Hybrid.
Point and Click components are implemented in the following game Mechanics:
- Targeting
- Special Skills
- Shooting (Auto Aim and Auto Fire [Optional you can aim and shoot by yourself but the controls are not really made for this])

Flight sim:
- Evasive Manuveurs
- Outmanuveurs

As you can see is the Focus on the Point and Click elements.

Personaly  i would like to play this game as an pure Flight-Sim but the controls are right now just to clumsy (Mouse Aim is a little bit hard to master and flying with joystic will lead into big disadvantages because you will have massive problems to rotaet those turrets (Nearly all Weapons are turrets).


But the Game is still in Progress and the Devs are very active in the steam forum and try to help there costumers nearly in every single thread that is posted. Suggestions are also taked really serious by the devs.
The First company i know which has a suggestion forum that isnt just a placebo.
Never has seen such a service before!
voteText: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
*Gnome Seal of Approval*
Don't let the boring tutorial text scare you off if you're new to the genre. It's not as complex of a game as they would have you think. In fact, it's quite easy to learn once you know the basics. I'm new to the genre myself and read comments saying this game is too simple and dumbed down. So if that's true then this game is a good place to start, because I had fun playing the free roam sandbox mode.

Lots of stuff to explore. Good controls. Nice visuals. Cool soundtrack.

The negative:
Earning money is slow until you're strong enough to take on heroes. You'll have a hard time earing enough to buy a new and better ship (which is important). However, once you start killing those heroes for rewards, you will quickly earn more than you need (which in turn feels a little imbalanced).

Sandbox mode was a little repetitive. Short framrate drops when the game loads a new area in front of you (which in turn have lead to a crash here and there).

If I was to play again, I'd start the story mode instead of the free roam.

Cool game!

reviewText: I gotta say ever since the Star Trek Star Fleet Command series of games I was always looking for something close.I found Starport Gemini and it quickly grew on me. It has many of the elements the former Star Trek games had, Ship command, 360 degree views, power management, repair, officers, ability to go anywhere in the galaxy, trading. The great thing aboiut Starport Gemini 2 is it improves on all that with 360 degree freedom of the camera and space maneuvering. Its no longer 2d in that regard. Even in beta it feels polished compared to the earlier game. I can't wait for the campaign to come and I do hope someone makes a mod so us girls can play as female in it. I give the Game 4 stars out of 5 as is.Big thuumbs up.

reviewText: Well for $35 I have enjoyed this game. There are aspects of this game that are in need of improvements. reviewText:
Alreet peeps, so this is my experience shot and review. So first things first id recommend this title and hope you enjoy it as much as i did.  This however will just be a general impression not a rating or in depth review.

Reasons : I'm coming from the original Starpoint Gemini and really enjoyed it for its single player freelancer style of gameplay. I picked it up in early access which i dont usualy go for but due to my experience with the original i toke a chance, this was not a mistake though as the title has come along way since i originaly purchased this.

Graphical: not cutting edge but still a really good looking game. fx to physics all of which are well made and are still being refined even after full release.

Sound assets : I have no ear for sound effects but they where up to standard, no odd sounds that ruined the experience.

Performance : Runs great. I dont have a uber rig, i run a very avarge system and this game runs great even in larger battles.

Content: A good solid campaign backed up with a freeroam mode that allows you to strip away the main story and play the universe in the way you want to. So many ships that you wont get to fly them all in one play through i reckon even with a few play throughs you will find some new ship to fly, some new mission, enemy to beat up on. Also the ability to play as a peace keeper or as a bandit.

faults : no borderless window mode and lack of a multiplayer.

Overhall: Solid singleplayer title that if you like freelancer / startrek online / x3 then your gonna be at home with this title. Defo pick this up and i pretty sure you will enjoy whats here and whats coming in the future as the team behind this is great and im sure this game can only get better.

Stay Frosty

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nBeing a SCI-Fi fan, it brings me much joy to review SPG2. This is an awesome space sim/ fighter game in which you command one of many space worthy vessels against pirates, factions and even natural elements like radiation which will wreak havok on your ship and crew. There are missions, faction missions, mining and salvage operations, and if your more about chaos and destruction then you can go around hijacking other ships to add to your own collection or sell, its all up to you. Currently the game is still in Beta and the game has its bugs and balancing issues but the Devs are always hard at work bringing constant updates and answering questions from the community, which is a major plus these days. The game at is current state is beautiful to look at with many various galaxies, planets and space stations, this game easily surpasses other sims that have already had time to mature. Future updates include strory lines, more complex missions, and ships, also the list as the devs have called it is always growing from ideas of players and the community as a whole. So if you love space, ships, fighting, customization, looting, selling and RPG elements then this is the game for you, trust me when I say you wont regret it.

reviewText:
I haven't played this game for too long but it has proven to be very fun and challenging.  I am currently playing through the campaign but I am also conducting side missions.  The side missions include (from what I have seen so far): assassination of trouble makers, repairing installations, bounty hunting, and transporting VIPs. I mine asteriods and trade at stations frequently to balance my finances.  Capturing and selling enemy starships have proven to be the most lucrative transaction.  Combat is somewhat confusing at first but the games excellent tutorial guide and fully customizable control menu is very helpful.
Pros:
-Good graphics.
-Intense space combat.
-Can easily change viewing settings - Rudder controlbridge" view
recommended:
and turret third person view.
-Ability to purchase and upgrade several starships.
-Can hire mercs and form a fleet.
-Large open world to explore.
-Many unique ways to "jump"around the map e.g. rifts and wormholes.
-Story is ok.
-Background music is pretty good and varied.
Cons:
-No NPCs to interact with at space stations.
-No first person perspective.
-No ship interior perspective.
Mixed:
-Fairly steep learning curve to become proficient with all of the games functions.
Overall a great indie title!  Give your self lots of time to play this game...it is hard to quit this game for the night!"

reviewText:
This game has lots of flaws, but I like it so much since it's the game i've been looking for a long time.

PROS:
-Absolutely beautiful, the way the binary stars cast shadows on asteroids, to the way distant nebulae appear giant and intimidating
-Most of the locations you see in space are reachable
-Great soundtrack
-You can be what you want, a pirate, trader, privateer, whatever
-Lots of ships
-Lots of modules and countless ways to setup your loadout
-For a space game, the environment is extremely varied
-Boarding and stealing a ship feels damn good
-MODDING!!!!!1111111!!11

MIXED:
-Probably just me, but the trading and interface feel to simple; after playing EVE Online for so long, the UI feels like it needs more
-The active ability RPG portion feels tacked on, I find myself almost always autofiring; at least never using my 1-4 keys
-Sometimes the autopilot glitches out and it's hilarious; I like to think of it as a feature
-Doesn't have SLI support, unless forced through a third party program like NVidia inspector or even just the control panel. However, once you do force it, it runs really nice (minus some annoying microstuttering).

CONS:
-The downscaling of the universe is really obvious and weird
-Things pop in a lot, like anomalies and stations
-Bad sound effect design, especially in weapon firing sounds
-Inconsistant graphics, some things are really highly detailed while others look like they came out of a 2006 game
-Missions get repetitive, and if you strip all the lore and factions away, all the gameplay is literally the same, minus enemies getting tougher over time

Cool game, go buy, shoot ships in the face.

reviewText:
A decent capital ship combat game, but somewhat shallow.

Pros:
+ A wide variety of ships and equipment
+ Combat is a little simplistic but fun nonetheless. Reminds of Rebel Galaxy but offers more control.
+ Capturing enemy ships feels satisfying
+ Looks good enough. I somehow love the battle hud(blue ring thingie around your ship, appears on some of the screenshots) and miss it in other similar games.

Cons:
- Probably the worst voice acting in game history. Some voices are really irritiating, especially protagonist's.
- Even though all ships are capital ships, you don't feel their scale. For example if you play X3/X:Rebirth, you do feel that your massive capital ship is a massive capital ship. Here all ships are basically the same size and you don't have anything to compare them to.
- RPG elements are pretty lame
- Story progression is sometimes very confusing. Like you won't have enough crew on your starter ship to capture any other ship (and start earning significant amount of money) or you'll simetimes find that you need 10 more levels to actually pilot a ship you've just earned. Or later in the game I kept getting way more levels than I actually needed.
- Limited ship customization options. You can arbitrarily choose any weapons for your ship which's good, but its subsystems are predefined for any given hull and you can just upgrade them slightly via enhancements.
- Even though I did rush the game in the end, I have completed it(without DLC stuff) in 32 hours on the hardest difficulty which's a little underwhelming for this kind of games.

Grab this game if:
You want a little arcadish broadside-style capital ship combat driven by a campaign scenario.

Avoid this game if:
If you're looking for a very in-depth experience similar to X3/EVE or physically plausible ship controlling similar to Elite. This game has a strong indie feeling to it, don't expect anything of AAA-like scale.

My overall rating is 7/10, I did enjoy this game and I'm really looking forward to its successor Starpoing Gemini : Warlords.

reviewText: I'll go on to say that if you enjoyed Freespace 2 or similar space themed games then you will find yourself immersed in this game. I will also add that the game requires a decent PC for the optimal smooth gameplay experience. In Starpoint Gemini 2 you get to upgrade and purchase ships as well as level up your character. There is a story ark mode available and freeroam option where you can try and emulate a raider, trader, mercenary and more. Combat in this game is extremely satisfying and blowing up combatant ships nearly never gets old. Even though this game is slated as a finished product the developers are still adding in more functions to add to the replayability and longevity of the base game. Plus all those Steam Workshop mods add to the overall experience if you want to mix things up a tad. Overall I rate this game a 7.8/10.

reviewText:
Bought this game in Early Access ~3 years ago.  Been playing it off an on.  I doubt I'll ever get over 200 hours but that doesn't mean I don't like the game.  It's amazing seeing how barebones it was back then come to life - as in, freelance missions gave you like 1000 credits and a few dozen XP. Half of the interface was useless and many things were still placeholders.  It's neat to come across a large battle and swoop in to help or to loot.

Quick list of pros/cons

+Beautiful environment
+Living world
+SPACESHIPS!
+SPACESTATIONS!
+Many ways to get money/XP

-I have zero interest in the Campaign (don't let that sway you; just a personal preference)
-In sandbox mode, it doesn't feel as though you're a big part of the solar system, which makes sense. I guess what I was looking for in this game won't be realized until Starpoint Gemini: Warlords.
-Damn PTE disrupting pirates.
-A few things are underexplained.
-Ship size difference is not noticeable enough and was a complaint since Early Access.

reviewText:
Basically Freelancer.
Similar to Sid Meier's Pirates but in space. Huge space.
Ship customization similar to Mechwarrior's mech customization.
Mine asteroids, hunt bounties, play with the market, buy better ships, better equipment, etc.

Streamlined user interface.
Combat is good. There's several weapon types for you to try out. Rockets, laser beams and plasma cannons to name a few, each with their own properties and upgrades. Get on your gunship and chase enemies by their tail or line up your battleship and bombard them mercilessly. Your choice.

Exploration is good. The game gives the player a huge world to explore. Planets, space stations and shipyards that offer different products depending on their region. Planets and space stations act as hubs, you can't set foot on them and explore. Not as huge as Elite Dangerous but huge nonetheless.

Music is good. Too bad there's not much to go around. If you have a space exploration playlist then add this game's music to that playlist and play that instead.

Economy is there. Trade clean goods or contraband. You can take advantage of rising and falling prices of materials but the economy isn't deep enough to make it an engaging enterprise. You can mine asteroids or scavenge space junk while going about your trade route, I guess.

CAN'T FORM A FLEET. You can capture enemy ships. You either sell them, keep them or scrap them. Keeping them puts them in your garage. You can switch between ships YOU CAN ONLY USE ONE SHIP AT ANY TIME. The closest to a fleet you'll get is by hiring mercenaries to fly with you for a price. Even then you can't command them. This is probably the worst negative point of the game in my opinion.

Light RPG elements.

A good space game overall but if you're into trading, playing with the economy or empire building then this game won't satisfy you.

I bought this on sale at 80% off so it's more than worth the money.

reviewText: I remember getting this game when it was still in its alpha/beta form with only a few things to do besides blowing up ships, blowing up asteroids, taking their goods, and then selling them at a market for a few dollars (which seemed weird back then because ships cost a ♥♥♥♥ TON and still do, but there are ways to get more money now.) So playing now, seeing that it is full release form, welllllll....it's still empty. I mean, there is absolutely almost nothing going on except for an occasional enemy ship flying in to a friendly territory that gets obliterated in a second. Other than that, nope, nothing. People that hate you, hate you and people that like you, like you, not much else. I thought it'd be awesome to be the revered space pirate captain who steals from all and gets in the way of people to scavenge as much money as possible, even between factions. Which is another huge problem, factions do not feel like they have bad ties between each other, it's as if they are both completely isolated with their borders set in place without anything in between. reviewText:
There are ultra realistic space sims,  there are slow paced datasheet space sims,  and on and on and on you can go down the laundry list of space games.   What Starpoint Gemini 2 seeks to accomplish is finding a healthy balance of it's predecessors without leaning too far in any particular direction.   Make no mistake,  SG2 will take you hours to accomplish anything substantial,  but it won't take you hours to start doing something fun.

Want to be a trader?  You can do that.   Want to mine for rare materials?  You can do that.  Want to be a pirate?  You'll eventually be able to do that.  Want to be the force of good bringing bad guys to justice while getting paid for your bounty kills?  You can do that to.

My 7 hours have been mostly spent divided between the three classes that you can choose from in the freeform game.  There is the Leader,  Gunner and Engineer.   Each class provides a fairly substantial difference on terms of feel however the common objective between most of these skills is all the same...   kill your enemy.   I was a bit disappointed to see that many of these skills are not overly helpful for more mundane tasks like mining,  trading,  or exploration.  Seeing as how the game puts heavy emphasis on providing you options - this particular part said to me We're only truly designing this game with combat in mind".   While the other things to do are definitely not afterthoughts
date:
they're not quite as fleshed out and as robust as I would have liked.

There is a story mode but unfortunately the voice acting is horrible.  Normally I can manage some bad voice acting but found this to be a bit too much.  This turned out to be alright in the end as the sandbox aspects of this game are fun and easy to get into.  The tutorial or lack there of was at least filled with a pop-up tips menu which got me rolling quickly enough.  I had to spend some time rummaging through the keybind menu but after that I was off and racing.

This game still feels very young with a lot of possiblities.  My 7 hours is definitely not enough time to even have a completely firm grasp of what the late game or even middle game will be like but I have a hunch it's going to just be more of the same but with higher stakes involved.  Instead of combat with 3-6 ships
recommended: it'll be more along the lines of 10-20 ships if the trailers and other various videos are telling a truthful tale.   Scaling of this nature is not altogether a bad thing if you're having fun with everything you're doing at the start of the game.  Essentially
hoursPlayed: it's not going to mix up the formula a whole lot as you get deeper into the game.  Sure you'll be able to use more skills due to having higher energy and more points to place down extra turrets and systems...  but most of those tools could be used at the start of the game as well
voteText: just within limitations.\n\nIf I could pick one thing I wish this game had
helpfulPercent: it would be co-op support.  Sharing a universe with 2-16 friends could serve for some amazing lan or house hold family fun.  Luckily the mod community seems to be getting behind this game so at the very least the variety of things to do will be getting mixed up a lot.\n\nIf you're still on the fence of this game I'd say just keep checking back.  Look at what the devs and the mod community are up to.  There is already a decent amount to do here and it's just done well.   If I had to give it a 1-10 rating I'd say we have ourselves an 8.2 with the clear opportunity to become a 9-9.5 if they continue to add features.   If you're someone who enjoys smelling the flowers and doing assorted tasks with some grinding mechancis involved due to large credit costs to purchase anything substantial
votesHelpful: then this game is the game for you!\n\nGive me a thumbs up if you found this review useful."

reviewText: One of the first Space-sim type of games I have found fun in quite a while. The controls/UI wont scare you away and are very functional, and the game feels pretty polished for a new release. While combat only missions are getting slightly repetitive I find the combat itself is very fun if you use manual aim and avoid just getting into a rythym of auto-fire on locked targets. It adds more challenge to the combat and keeps it fresh every encounter trying to dodge incoming fire while positioning yourself correctly to fire your batteries and having to stay on your toes while aiming. I have been seeing a lot of threads calling combat lackluster" or boring
date: but every one of them have been people using auto-aim and most likely just flying circles around the enemy ships haha. Of course that would become boring quickly
recommended: and the manual aiming is what makes me like this game more than a lot of other space sims that do not even have that option.\n\nOn top of the combat there is trading(though not really worth it right now
hoursPlayed: but patches will surely improve it)
voteText: mining
helpfulPercent: and boarding enemy ships to capture and haul back for good cash or to use it yourself. Mercenaries have been fixed in the latest patch as well which I have yet to try so cannot comment on that(allies that fly with you and help in combat which you can control to an extent).\n\nThe campaign is pretty basic
votesHelpful: but it has a decent story going on and gives you something else to do on the side when you get bored of freelance missions
votesTotal: mining
votesFunny: or trading to get into better ships and better upgrades for each ship.\n\nAll in all I am enjoying the game and can't wait to see what else is added down the line(devs have already confirmed they want to add more endgame with station ownership and faction warfare). And to top it all off you can already mod the game and there a few complete revamps already even though the game has just released. Highly recommended if you liked any older space-sims like Freelancer or the like."

reviewText:
A  Very solid buy

I would recommend old school fans of Escape Velocity, Freespace and the X series.
In its current state the game currently falls well short of being a master works, it lacks a level of immersion, complexity and feels like needs fair bit more spit and polish to be called finished. That being said it’s the best addition the genre in years. i may be speaking too soon as the developers seem to have fair bit of steam left for adding and fixing things up too.

The game plays like a more arcade version of the X series it reminds me a lot of X rebirth without all the complete fail. It’s simple and fast paced space action that falls between somewhere between dog fighting and EVE online ship management and thankfully nothing like the orginal starpoint gemini.

Pros
Best, fight, trade and explore game in years.
Solid graphics
Decent universe to explore
Reasonably fast and action packed
Ongoing development

Cons
Seems 90% Finished
No empire building
Shipload equipment and loadout overly simple.
Campaign worth avoiding – just don’t

reviewText: First review of a game... I am an older gamer and I am very picky about the games I get obsessive about. This Game is not finished, but the available content is more than enough to keep you busy. This is not a straight up shooter... this has more of a quest rpg style where you can be what you wanna be. The game reminds me of a game I used to play way way back in the day called starflight. You can customize your ship with colors and logos and plenty of weapons to choose from. Very Eve-escent with the loadouts. Nowhere near as complex as EVE though... and nowhere near as boring of a start like EVE... you can start shootin from the onset - and if you do a little research before you begin, you can hijack ships right from the start... Remember boys and girls, strip the captured ship before you sell it! The content that is coming is intriguing in the possibilities... I have been playing it hardcore now and I am still not bored. I paid full price for it and I am not disappointed!!!

reviewText:
The latest update has elevated this to the most satisfying trading simulation I have ever had the pleasure of playing. Not only can you see what various commodities are trading for at the stations you have visited, you also see the distance you currently are from each of those stations. This adds another level of decision making – is the extra distance you might have to travel for a ‘best’ price worth the time it will take to get there, or is a slightly lower price actually the better deal? A small thing, perhaps, but it does make you approach your cargo manifest a bit more critically when deciding on what and when to trade.

The second thing this encourages is exploration. You only see the prices for the stations and planets you have discovered. I find myself compelled to push into unknown territory on that never ending quest for the ultimate trade route. And the commodity information screen itself is wonderfully easy to use. The filters are a tremendous help, eliminating the need to scroll through every item available. Are you a miner? Click on ores. Love to hunt down pirates? Quickly discover who is offering the best price for those contraband items.

As you may have guessed, I’m a merchant at heart, not a fighter. But I’ve found the battles to be well-balanced and a simple click will tell you if that tantalizing enemy ship you have your eye on has the capability to turn you into so much space dust. Not that the knowledge will necessarily stop you, but at least you’ll know what you’re up against. And for those times when you do take on just a bit more than you can chew and yet somehow manage to pull it off by the skin of your shields, well – you know the feeling.

The graphics are gorgeous, the gameplay is addicting, and personalizing your ship is as much fun as creating a new character in most RPGs. At this point the only thing I’m hoping for is that we may eventually see a larger collection of avatar portraits. The new group was a nice addition, but as a female gamer I find the two current offerings lack some of the personality that the male portraits possess. And that something so minor is the only flaw I can find says a lot about how truly innovative and honestly fun this game is.

Now if you’ll excuse me, I have a trade empire to build.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I would definately recommend this game... but with some notes of caution.  I consider my self a supporter of 'Little Green Men', because I've always enjoyed their games ( at least the few I have).  However... I feel this one is falling a bit short, and I'm unsure if these are problems they are having issues resolving... or have just given up.  However... the problems that I've seen thus far, are more inconvenient than Game Stopping.

There's a serious issue with early game over powering of the enemy.  While I've heard a claim by the developers that this was a Development decision, I personally believe this is a Bug that they haven't been able to resolve.  Basically, when taking a mission which is marked at a specific level, the mission turns out to be impossible to complete even though your level made be higher than the recommended level.  Option:  Run and find another mission and hope this doesn't happen too often... but it will.

Another issue deals with Enhancements which can be added to ship's equipment and weapons, but the Enhancements do not actually enhance the item.  Note:  some... not all.

Licenses, also, which should provide specific bonus do not work.  Note:  some... not all.

Other than the above I have no other negative issues with this game.  It has all of the elements of a Good Space Sim, with many choices on how one wishes to play... Fighter... Merchant... Miner... Salvager... or even pirate.  I usually don't play pirate until I get bored with a game, but don't want to stop and need a new challenge.  however, the problem with being a pirate in many space sims is the limited choices you get; often being more of a headache than anything else.  But with this game I've seen the pirates (or more correctly, the Hostile Factions) have as much territory to operate in as the 'So-Called' Good Guys.  I'm actually looking forward to trying my hand as a pirate.

The merchant side of the game is IMHO as well done as it seems to be possible based on the many games I've played, and wanted to be a Merchant.  In short... I don't feel like it's Great... but it does seem Very Good; just haven't got a decent size Cargo Ship for really trying it out.  However... for the little trading I've seen and done... it looks like it has Very Good" Potential.

Mining for both Ores and Gases was done in a very fun and unique way... which I've been enjoying for the most part.  It doesn't really seem to make as much money as Combat... but then again
date: this is a Combat Game; I just like mining; with a touch of combat to give me a reason to wake up in the morning.  But you'll still need to focus on combat fairly early just to get a decent ship for mining.\n\nCombat was a bit disappointing at first because of the mechanics used to control the ship.  I found it was best to turn on Auto-Fire on all turrets... which seemed a bit Impersonal to me.  However... as I got better with all that you can do to Protect and Enhance you ship in battle... Aiming my Laser became the least of my problems
recommended: and I was rather happy I didn't have to worry about that anymore.  But that is a matter of Personal Preference.\n\nAlso... the Skill and Perk system is fun; I like the fact that you can "Sort Of" custom build yourself for the type of Player and Character you choose.  I'm not a fan of being forced to play a specific character as is done in the Campaign (I feel disconnected to my Character while following the story line)
hoursPlayed: but that
voteText: again... is just Personal Preference.  And the fact that I can build him the way I choose is far more important to me.\n\nOne of the best aspects of this game "To Me" is that Money
helpfulPercent: thus far
votesHelpful: is maintaining it's value.  Too often in Single Player Games you find that Money loses it's value far too soon.  Once you get to your 3rd or 4th ship -or- 20th or 30th level
votesTotal: you find  you start ignoring ways of making money... and just focus on leveling... because there just isn't anything left to buy that you can't afford.  I'm current level 43
votesFunny: and still find myself occasionally trying to scrap together a few Bit Coins to buy that Blaster with the Extra Kick.  I find that once a game's currency loses any real value (or more directly; Need) the game heads down hill from there.  At the time of this writing I have roughly $17mil
commentsCount: and trying to get to $29mil for the next for the next ship I want; but not the last ship I'll fly.\n\nAll in all; while I got this game on sale
column16: I would not have been disappointed if I had paid full price (assuming full price was under $40).  I definately would recommend this game; with hopes of certain issues being resolved.. but with confidence it's still a Fun and Addictive Game.\n\nEnjoy!!!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Starpoint Gemini 2 a sequel with lots of improvements, while keeping to the free form of the predecessor.
This game feels as motivating as Freelancer with its extensive Universe to explore, dozens of ships, different ship classes and moddable loadouts.

I did enjoy this game very much, it plays like a cross-over between freelancer (free to explore universe, dozens o ships) and the Star Trek Fleet Command titles (tactical fights, commanding capships).

Whether you want to relax mining and trading, or engage in combat missions and piracy, this game will be worth its money.
Did i mention you can capture enemy ships by boarding combat? You can!
If it flies, it is there for the taking!

As a captain your first and foremost crucial choice will be your class.

You can either be a Commander, featuring buffs for your fleet, empowered strike craft, retaliatory attacks and defensive boosts.

Or you can try to outgun the enemy by becoming a Gunner, who can specialize his offensive power by adding effects like disabling hits to his beam weapons, firing more shells with railguns, adding a higher refire rate to his high damaging plasma canons or boosting his heavy weaponry (schockwave cannons, missiles and torpedos).

Last but not least the Engineer, a very versatile class with a lot of debuffs.
Ever got tired of fast moving corvettes and gunboats dodging your railgun shots?
Just place a Rift-Anomaly and slow them down, then hit 'em hard!

Your second decision might be to specialize in a ship-category, as you can boost the efficiency of your ship by spending perk-points granted every 5 levels.
What will be your choice? A fast and mobile light ship(gunboat/corvette)
A merchantship, to rule the market with your cunning? (transport/freighter/freight-liner)
A medium class mobile Warship? (Frigate/Destroyer/Cruiser)
A vessel of personified dread? (Battleship/Dreadnought/Carrier)
The Choice is yours to make, though it is not final,
for you can reset your spent skill- and perk-points while being docked to a station or planet and try anew.

Currently this game is in Beta Version 0.7, so there are still some issues and lacks:
- ingame descriptions of skills and mechanics lack some love and proper english translation
- the weapons need some diversity, e.g. faster firing weapons need a higher projectile speed to use them against fast moving targets (railguns and plasma weapons)
- boarding combat is currently a numbers game, lacking the predecessors ingame videos and feedback
- the missions currently are restricted to Assassination (search and destroy), delivery, repair of beacons and rescue missions
- they need to put in some ships from the predecessors (prokhorov for example) to add even more diversity to the allready well modeled and animated ships
- ship special abilities are not included yet (like a full frontal arc auto-canon for baeldor frigates or high-energy blasts for dreadnoughts)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ok, first I want to say that overall, this is a fun game.  Even though it is in it's alpha phase, it still has a lot of fine points to keep me playing for the time being.  There is one point about this game that is going to kill it for me, but I'll get to that later.

The graphics are well done.  I have several hours into it, and have yet to experience a graphical glitch.  The ship models are well done and the stations aren't bad to look at.

The flight controls are a bit weird at first, but it really doesn't take much to get used to them.  The biggest gripe I have is that there is no first person view so you can't fly directly at something.  If you try, you actually fly over it.  Not that big of a deal and after you get used to it, it works out.  If you are flying mouse mode, there isn't enough dead space for level flight.  Your ship is always changing direction.  I ended up not utilizing the mouse mode and stuck with WASD.

As it is still in Alpha phase there are only a few different types of missions to work on.  These are called Freelances.  They are usually quick and easy.  It looks like there will be several different types of missions put in later on, so this isn't a slight, just an observation.

Also, the money doesn't keep up with your pilot level.  I'm currently level 25 and still can't afford to buy another version of the same ship I'm currently in.  I should have been able to upgrade ships a while ago.  I'm sure with the advent of other missions, the money thing will probably work itself out.

There needs to be more tutorials.  There needs to be something on Grappling and taking over ships.  Might be offered farther down the road.  Also on derelicts.  Try as I might, I can't figure them out.  I don't seem to get anything off of them.  I might not understand their mechanics, but since there is no tutorial on them, I don't know.

Now for the part that breaks this game for me personally.  I do enjoy combat and exploration.  I've never been huge into trading or diplomacy.  However, I love games where I can create things.  Crafting is huge for me.  Starpoint Gemini 2 has these huge asteroid fields that if I spent years playing, I wouldn't be able to empty them out.  However, all you can do with them is shoot them for ore and then vendor it...for a very small price I might add.  There is nothing else to do with all of this ore.  Now, your saying...wait, it is still alpha, they might add it in later.  Well, I've read up in their forums and one of the developers has already stated that they don't plan on adding in any kind of crafting utility to the game.

If I could put a station out in the fields, and have them manufacturing ship equipment, weapons & and ships themselves, this game would be one that I kept and played for years to come.  As it is, I'm going to get tired of shooting random encounters pretty quick.

As a single player game, I need something that is going on in the background while I'm out exploring and building for the economy would be great.  Without this ability, the game gets stale, at least for me.

For most people, this game will be great.  I know that a good majority of people don't care to craft anything.  For me, without it, it is a game breaker.

reviewText:
The game is fun, it's sort of a mix between X3(ship control, selling items) and Darkstar One(upgrading weapons, equipment and such). This game has some potential but right now it is still a bit lacking.

Fun factor: You will have fun fighting and dodging enemy fire. Having troops board enemy ships and take them over. Looting dead ships. Seeing how different ships are and act. The joy of dragging a captured ship to a dock.
Unfun factor: You are very much alone, yes you can hire mercs, up to two, but the only person you can talk to is the ship computer who in fact will only say anything to you do an action (move command, fire at will) or when an enemy teleports right to you. The world is pretty empty, NPC's are just sitting there really, and they tend not to do anything else unless an enemy happens to be around.

The makers have stated they plan to add expansions which will lighten things up, but those things are in the future.  They also stated they have plans to change things up, shields will matter later on for boarding and such. Time will tell.
I have put in 13 hours and so far feel a little worried. I ran most of my time in a Frigate capturing ships to sell. I even in fact captured a battleship by running back and forth between two stations to fill my troops and relaunch new boarding attacks.  It took very little time to level, and as well I fear I may never enjoy all the ships this game has to offer in the long run.

So is it worth it?

Positives: Somewhat fun, feels semi-polished, the devs are hard at work fixing bugs very fast, what seems like a bright future for a game.

Negatives: World is full of things, but they might as well be boxes floating in space. No life really. It seems like the same type of AI as Minecraft. Seems a bit short so far even with Freeroam (world is open, no story).

I feel the game's price is sort of almost right at 25 bucks.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a long-standing fan of the sci-fi genre, I can say that this is the kind of game I've been looking for. It has everything that any space-fan would enjoy! Anomalies, planets, asteroids, nebulas, and tons more! You can trade, customize your starship, upgrade, and fight against pirates as well as enemy factions. The gameplay is unlike anything I've played before, in a good way, and makes it feel like it's ship-on-ship combat. Fighting in space is dynamic, involved, and intricate so it can be challenging at times but never too difficult. The variety of weapons you can add to your starship also helps to give the game a unique feel in combat. The game has the look and expanse of Eve while remaining a single-player only game.

Finally, it is workshop/mod friendly! Personally, I like to cross-over different franchises into my games so it's really cool to see a Federation Starship flying around space and using weapons from Star Trek as a way to create a personalized and awesome experience.

Definitely would recommend to any sci-fi fan. Better than a lot of AAA titles I've bought. Keep up the good work!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Amazing game. As close to Freelancer 2 as I think we've gotten or will get with next gen sims like Elite and Star Citizen coming out. There's a huge amount of depth here and free play mode is seriously awesome. So far I have...

Missions / Trade / Exploration ( the universe is pretty huge and there are no jumpgates, you want to go somewhere be prepared to have a tea and fly it )

Boarded and pirate who attacked me while mining. Stole their ship, towed it back to station, 60k profit w/ a hold full of ore as well. Enough to purchase some weapon and power grid upgrades & repair my own hull.

Still mining, happily shooting rocks in a deep and immersive asteroid belt miles from any station ( the graphics are fantastic ) again unaffiliated scumbag smuggler drops my shield and attempts to hack my power grid. Fire a grappler, boost shields, send feedback up his signal to shut down his shields instead, steal everything on board, destroy his engines and leave him to die in the darkness.

Ships are hugely expensive. Hatched a plan... equip a gunship w/ a cloak and heavy shielding. Observe trade routes and traffic to a wormhole. Wait for lost lamb transport indy with no escorts ( they are tough as nails and heavily armored ) ... decloak, target, fire a grappler, boost shields and tear their ship apart until they surrender, kill everyone on board, towed it to station under a salvage license since it was an independent, now it's mine. All repaired and with a new coat of paint & trade license ( my main job, trading is awesome and dynamic, you need smarts and a good memory of hundreds of stations / planets )

Right now I'm flying across the universe in a heavily armored trade / transport ship carrying passengers, 2 vips and sipping a tea on autopilot. 100 thousand K to go, it's going to be a long flight. If anyone needs me I'll be in my cabin.

All is quiet... for now.

And this is alpha. Srsly.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Love this! Have not stopped playing it since I downloaded it. Shows a huge amount of promise in terms of gameplay; the visuals of the spaceflight scenery, ships, asteroid belts, stations and nebulae are brilliant and very atmospheric. Even the icons and equipment images are polished and impressive.

There are the inevitable comparisons to games like Elite and X, but even in this early incarnation I feel that Starpoint Gemini has the capacity to surpass them; I haven't seen much of the trade mechanic yet, but have enjoyed myself immensely with the freelance missions and grappling enemy ships before boarding, capturing and selling them.

Some other memorable moments so far are the sound of the engines powering up when you leave a station, or slicing up asteroids to mine ores.

I also really like the dimensions in the game - the stations are big, but the planets are massive and I like that you can land on them. I'm about 20 hours in and have covered maybe a quarter of the map (and most of that was a fleeting visit).

The gameplay gets sticky on my machine moving between sectors but  this is only the Alpha build and I imagine there is still a lot of coding spit-and-polish to come.

My wishlist for the finished game would be to be able to reduce the number of turrets as well as increase them (have been a bit overly-optimistic with power management for my Myrmydon weaponry) and for alliance ships to stop shooting at my captured enemy vessels while I'm trying to drag them back to port.

Highly recommended if you like space exploration/combat/trade games.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is fantastic, especially for an Alpha release.  Several things are still in the works, but it is a fine game as is.  Right now it is essentially a space sandbox.  I tend to play the role of pirate, or privateer, rather (I only attack the bad guys, but I'm always trying to board them and steal their ships so I can tow them back to a planet or space station and sell off their guns, then the ships themselves... seems to be pretty lucrative).  You'll love it when you get a big carrier with a bunch of fighter wings or bombers... it's awesome having a swarm of firepower surrounding you.  The game is massive and consists largely of traveling between planets and space stations (press B to boost your engines to full and enjoy the ride and the amazing scenery), doing sidequests, mining asteroids, or being a merchant or pirate or whatever suits your fancy.  There is currently no storyline or any story missions (but plenty of sidequests are available and constantly appearing), and a lot of things are currently non-functional (like the useable items... thankfully they are super valuable so I just sell them for lots of money), but with that being said, this game is amazing... I'm really looking forward to years of fun with this thing.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Think StarTrek meets Cowboy Bebop. Yes, that good.

At this stage in development only two things can be suitably inferred from this game. Its tone and core mechanics. And I am exceptionally pleased with both. Even as an early alpha it is successfully scratching a difficuly itch to reach.

I wanted a game where I could zoom around the solar system getting into fights with phasers and torpedos, having to jockey for position all the while balancing my shields, engines, and weapons. SG2 gave me exactly that. The combat is very nice. In its current state the missions are randomly generated, MMO style, filler quests, but this does not prevent the encounters from being very fulfilling, if for no other reason then the solid underlying mechanics. This game will really cause you to think strategically. Will you perform the risky gambit of dumping all power to the shields and weapons to try and pick off a weakened enemy in one pass or will I shift that power into the engines and hope for a second chance to strike at that exposed hole in their shields. As the game progresses you will be making that decision and others as you have to contend with swarms of fighters and imposing warships. It requires just enough of the player to be extremely fulfilling when a risky maneuver works without being unduely frustrating when it fails. And you will fail alot. But the game is at its best when it is challenging. That is when the flexibile thinking and fast micromanagment that characterizes its combat will bring out your inner Jean-Luc Picard. And when it does you will feel great.

The tone is harder to express then the mechanics, but is a perfect compliment to them. If you have ever watched Cowboy Bebop then this game will be like putting on a pair of comfortable shoes. Two things drive this feeling. First, the music distinctly reminds me of some of the tracks from the show. There are no jazzy interludes, but the background music reminds me of some prog songs accompanying the space scenes. The music is seamlessly woven into the background noise of your lasers, phasers, engines, and missles. Most of the time it is barely noticeable above the ruckus but it is a soothing distraction during a long sprint across the map. It simply suits the game, perfectly conveying the mystery and the solitude of space. The more obvious callout to the tone of Bebop is the types of missions available so far. Most are bounty type missions and trading runs. All taking place in fantasitic locals with cool space stations. The game has a very awesome setting. And the scale of which really makes you feel like a plucky captain trying to scrape by in a much larger universe.

All in all I was looking for a game that would let me feel like I was flying a spaces ship. This did that and more! Not only did it have the gameplay I desired but it did so in a very cool way. As such SG2 has exceeded my expectations. It is perfectly filling a niche in my gaming library which I have been searching to fill. I would highly recomend the game to anyone who has got the space captain itch. Star Citizen is a far way away. But even in Alpha SG2 rocks! And its future looks so promising. All things considered, 9/10.

The only downside is a slightly difficult camera. You will get used to it but I feel like it doesn't need to be something that we should have to get used to. An autolock feature which would keep the camera centered on a target and  making the turret mode more responsive with less 'momentum' would be sufficient. But this is just nitpicking. SG2 looks to be a great niche game. And if you are interested it deserves your money and attention.

-rm

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Starpoint Gemini 2 maybe an early access game right now but the game feels a lot more complete than a number of new releases. The game is best described as a tactical space simulator in an open universe. The game in early access has no story mission i have found yet but a lot of small missions, exploration,mining and combat. The combat is a joy once you get used to the tactical use of gun turrets and weapon usage. The game has some really interesting ship to ship combat that is easy to get the hang of.

Graphics at this stage are  excellant. Ship models are good and the effects are nice and are a lot more polished than what you would think for a game not completed yet. Sound and music are good with a nice musical track (although limited just now but will be increased when ame is finished)

Would i recommend this game. Hell yes even at this stage and i look forward to seeing the end product.

One other interesting note is the developers are always on the forums answering our questions and listining to our input and shows how dedicated they are to both the project and to their customers.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There are a lot of really good space sims out there, this is one of them.  But one thing that sets this game apart from those other games is this:  Noob friendliness.  This games UI and setup is so easy/simple that even someone who has never played any space sims before can get the hang of within an hour or so, and that's FAST.  The UI may be simple, but it's still got the same flexibility to let you do what you want.  Every time I start a new space sim, I always think 'oh god, i gotta relearn the whole system again.'  but not for this one.  Also, that map UI reminds me soo much of google chrome.

Currently, the gameplay is extremely fun even for not being complete.  One could hardly tell, except for the fact that skill, equipment, and fighter keybinds don't work--but that's okay, they're all just a mouseclick away via the easy to use UI.

I haven't played long enough though to figure out how deep this game is, whether or not the trading system is static or dynamic, or whether or not what you do affects prices.  I haven't played long enough to see whether or not the universe is 'alive' like in other games, but this is good enough for someone who wants to pick up their first space sim and not be overwhelmed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ok, first I want to say that overall, this is a fun game.  Even though it is in it's alpha phase, it still has a lot of fine points to keep me playing for the time being.  There is one point about this game that is going to kill it for me, but I'll get to that later.

The graphics are well done.  I have several hours into it, and have yet to experience a graphical glitch.  The ship models are well done and the stations aren't bad to look at.

The flight controls are a bit weird at first, but it really doesn't take much to get used to them.  The biggest gripe I have is that there is no first person view so you can't fly directly at something.  If you try, you actually fly over it.  Not that big of a deal and after you get used to it, it works out.  If you are flying mouse mode, there isn't enough dead space for level flight.  Your ship is always changing direction.  I ended up not utilizing the mouse mode and stuck with WASD.

As it is still in Alpha phase there are only a few different types of missions to work on.  These are called Freelances.  They are usually quick and easy.  It looks like there will be several different types of missions put in later on, so this isn't a slight, just an observation.

Also, the money doesn't keep up with your pilot level.  I'm currently level 25 and still can't afford to buy another version of the same ship I'm currently in.  I should have been able to upgrade ships a while ago.  I'm sure with the advent of other missions, the money thing will probably work itself out.

There needs to be more tutorials.  There needs to be something on Grappling and taking over ships.  Might be offered farther down the road.  Also on derelicts.  Try as I might, I can't figure them out.  I don't seem to get anything off of them.  I might not understand their mechanics, but since there is no tutorial on them, I don't know.

Now for the part that breaks this game for me personally.  I do enjoy combat and exploration.  I've never been huge into trading or diplomacy.  However, I love games where I can create things.  Crafting is huge for me.  Starpoint Gemini 2 has these huge asteroid fields that if I spent years playing, I wouldn't be able to empty them out.  However, all you can do with them is shoot them for ore and then vendor it...for a very small price I might add.  There is nothing else to do with all of this ore.  Now, your saying...wait, it is still alpha, they might add it in later.  Well, I've read up in their forums and one of the developers has already stated that they don't plan on adding in any kind of crafting utility to the game.

If I could put a station out in the fields, and have them manufacturing ship equipment, weapons & and ships themselves, this game would be one that I kept and played for years to come.  As it is, I'm going to get tired of shooting random encounters pretty quick.

As a single player game, I need something that is going on in the background while I'm out exploring and building for the economy would be great.  Without this ability, the game gets stale, at least for me.

For most people, this game will be great.  I know that a good majority of people don't care to craft anything.  For me, without it, it is a game breaker.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A really interesting looking game. I like the controls, highly customisable, flying star-fighter style seems equally as easy turret-based capital ship combat( depends only on the style of ship, which can be better suited to either, which is exactly what it should be). HUD and contextual control panel pack a LOT of options and info into a simple, streamlined system. Graphically it's easy on the eye, won't praise it, but there's nothing I can think of that would need pointing out.

The thing that would need tweaking is a detail, but impacts the game heavily, since it does with navigation: The waypoints do not say WHAT they point to on the map. Can't tell whether it's my active mission, accepted but not active or a completely new one. To be fixed ASAP, as going from point to point IS the game.

The only other minor thing doesn't impact gameplay, but would make it a bit more interesting:
*Refine the weapon mounting system. Grouping them together for ship sides is a good idea, but it would be good to have access to all single individual mounts anyway, also showing where they are on the ship, Star Wolves style (since they avoid fireing THROUGH the ship, which is as unexpected as it is brilliant), for enabling a more tactical loadout.
*Connecting to the former, make the whole drydock/store/exchange window bigger and clearer. As it is now is not very intuitive and requires spending at least a few minutes just studying it to finally grasp what half the options actually are, much less taking advantage of them.

In general, a good game even at this stage, just needs tweak and a good plot implemented. The latter would make a good game a great game.

This Game Is Worth every penny and perfect for people who like sci-fi, RPG, and Challanges.

reviewText:
There's already a million comparisons of this game to Eve, but I'll add another - It's a lot like Eve but with a personal story arc that concerns your character.

Unlike Eve, the space combat is twitchy and fast-paced, and surprisingly deep.  You've got to keep on the vulnerable side of the enemy you're fighting, all the while keeping your vunlerable sides pointed away from his freinds.  There are a million ways you can outfit your ship and plenty of variety in ship types - how you outfit it matters, and the weapons you choose need to suit its strengths and suit how you will be piloting it to be effective.

Not everything is perfect (I felt like the different factions were somewhat faceless, and felt like it was a little too easy to pass through hostile territory) but the small, indie studio that developed it is already planning on plenty of post-release changes.

The game has clearly had a lot of loving care put into it, and is a definite recommend.  It's amazing already, and I'm fully confident it'll get even better.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you have fond memories of Privateer or Flreelancer, then Starpoint Gemini 2 is for you. If not, but you like traveling the universe, trading and selling (and smuggling) goods, blasting space pirates trying to steal your booty, or even mining asteroids on your downtime; then SG2 is also for you!

Controls can be interesting (a bit wonky) at times, and I read there may be some joystick issues, but mouse and keyboard are my choice anyway so I've had no issues. Presentation and graphics look great, and there are some truly amazing views around the galaxy. Combat is fun and ship styles range from giant transports, to carriers with multiple fighter wings. I've got 20+ hours in at this point and while I started the campagin, I'm having more fun just roaming around, trading and upgrading my ship.

If you've been looking for a game to scratch the space sim itch, this is a good game for it.
