reviewText:
After 28 hours, I've finished SG2 on normal difficulty. I've mixed feelings about this game. Since I got it at a reduced price and it managed to enthral me long enough to finish it, I hesitantly recommend this game.

I'll give you a list of things that, in my opinion, are well done (from + to +++) or bad (from - to ---).

Stability: +++
I've encountered not a single crash. Good work.
Bugs: +
There are some minor bugs but no show stopper. Most of the bugs are only slightly annoying or are gone once you restart.
Graphics: ++
Not cutting edge, but there are some nice visual effects that improve immersion.
Audio: +
Ok, but nothing eartshaking.
Character development: -
I didn't feel that there's anything that I really want to reach" with my character

reviewText: The game in question is well structured, a winning mix of a space game and RPG, especially the RPG system is truly impressive, there are dozens of perks and bonuses to choose from. The things to do in this game are many, there is a good story, expanded recently, and there are lots of missions generated automatically, there are lots of ships to purchase all upgradeable. reviewText: Wow! Just Wow! I bought this game back when you could basically do a little mining and fly around attacking small craft. After coming back after so long, I am truly impressed in what they did with this game. I loved playing Eve, but not paying monthly subscribtions for months of mining, grinding, and training, only to get a Tengu and have it blown up in minutes by a swarm. Those days are over! I had always hoped for a single player game like this with a sandbox option. Hopefully, they might add co-op or being able to take over a space station and starting your empire, pirate kingdom, etc. They may have that, b8ut since I started playing the game I have been too busy playing to take the time to read the change docs. I even bought the DLC. I'm just so glad for the early access games. While I did buy a few early access lemons, games like SG 2 and 7 Days to Die have made the investments well worth the risks. Finally the type of space game that I've always wanted as opposed to the RTS type!  I feel the game is well balanced. I love the boarding option and the progression from miner to caputring ships to sell and hunting down bosses" (bounty hunter). I get to the story line when I want to
date: as well as running side missions and other replayable missions (escort
hoursPlayed: etc) that pop up. The map is large and there are many factions. I can't wait to see what else they are going to do next!  A definite buy for space gamers!"

reviewText:
It's a space combat game. Third person perspective, can be toyed with to give you a first person-ish view. 3D view of space, x, y and z axis. No linear paths here. Controls can be a bit hard to pick up and the tutorials were wall of text-ish for me, but with a little trial and error it's easy to master.

PRO
-Huge map, plenty to explore
-Plenty to do: missions, mining, smuggling, space combat
-Good looking graphics
-RPG elements let you upgrade weapons systems and perks, or familiarity with types of ships

CON
-Level up system isn't too clear
-Fetch quests can become boring very fast, especially when they generate halfway across the map
-No tutorial mission or intro, just walls of text thrown at you
-Will occasionally freeze and stutter at random intervals, only for a few seconds though

Despite the negatives, it's a good game. I'd buy it if you enjoy space combat games, but if you're new to the genre or have a backlog it might be better to wait for a sale.

reviewText: This game is super fun; I like Star Trek, Firefly, Cowboy Bebop, etc. and when I'm in that mood SG2 in perfect. Every time I resume my game the first thought I have is that this is a great, immersive game. It's really frustrating to see negative reviews because I love this game so much. The developers continue working on it and it keeps getting better which is really saying something since I loved it at early access. recommend for any sci-fi fan that wants a single player open world experience with a ton of ways to play. It's viable to be a miner and buy ships and outfit them just for that. I personally spent several fun hours just doing that, it was great. You can buy and upgrade ships just for smuggle or escort or freelancing. People complain about the expense of ships versus reward of missions; these people simply don't get it. There are lots of ways to build your bank roll and the time and effort it takes make the game more rewarding and immersive. The balance makes it so much better as you progress, you can't just jump from the first ship to the most powerful ship or even the most powerful weapons right away, and that is good. You actually get to enjoy and explore each level of progress , as you get a new ship, or a new upgrade and you slowly work toward that next purchase. All the while playing however you want, avoiding combat in favor of mining and trade which is super fun, figuring out how to avoid destruction or detection while making the kesel run in under 3 parsecs. Or you can be a pirate, good or bad, hijacking ships with a ship optimized just for that sort of activity. So good. So highly recommended.

reviewText:
Starpoint Gemini 2 + Secrets of Aethera DLC:

Excellent sandbox space game, campaign missions are quite easy at first and then they aren't, you need a bigger ship. Which means credits.  Trading, pop-up missions, side missions, capturing ships and mining are your friends now.

Once you get you fingers trained on flying it's a lot more fun...fly in hard and fast and then slow down to stay on the tail pipe of your target, watch out for the explosive radius of your own missiles.

Trading/Mining could use some TLC. The small cargo space and low margins on items makes for a lot of trips for those playstyles to make a lot of credits.

A dedicated mining ship would be a good idea, with maybe a compressor item or mining laser enhancement or something so that you can fit more than 1 ore in 1 cargo slot.

The trading screens in the map could really use a mode to show best to/from, rather than a per-item best buy/sell, also remote buy/sell ala Eve would be great.

But trading and mining isn't what this game is about. The real fun comes with capturing ships and running the various types of missions.

Capturing takes a while to figure out, I suggest youtube and practise.  Basically, grapple, burn the hull down 2/3rds of the way, transport your troops and keep transporting them as long as you have troops. After you get the hang of it, you take every mission around your level just to try and capture another ship.

The pop-up missions are rather generic, about 10 or so different types that I've found and they differ only in the difficulty of the enemies. Some are out-right free credits and XP (science, repair).

The Side Missions are quite variable from the few I've done, more credits and XP and more difficult than the pop-ups.

The Campaign Missions are similar to the Side Missions in reward and difficulty but advance the story-line.

Exploring the map is a lot of fun, it's huge...also more areas to find capturable ships and missions.

One downside, when you play windowed, if you focus off the game, it will pause. This is non-condusive to setting a long waypoint, maxing your engine power and doing something else on the other monitor.

Very fast save/loads.

The fights can be quite intense, the AI seems to be aggressive, but not stupid, it'll gang-tackle you quite happily. The auto-firing works great, but I'm not a fan of the way it keeps shifting targets to closest enemy as opposed to the target you've selected. I guess I have to learn manual firing.

I suggest staying with the Tauris starter boat, pick a weapon type, level that type up  and stay with it for the first 20 levels or so. The gunboat is a paper-tiger, so you learn a lot about dodging, firing, and your equipment needs. Lot's of save and reloads figuring it out. ++Shield Boosters, Repair Nanobots, Hull Plates.

66hrs, 8.5/10 and am still playing. It's not solo-Eve, but darn close.

reviewText:
My first bit of advice is this, ignore the people who reviewed this with 2 hours or less in game, or even 5 hours or less in some cases.

I've played EVE, the Wing Commander games, Star Citizen, and many other games in this genre.  Out of every game in my Steam library, this is the one that has most surprised me.  It surprised me because I hadn't heard much of it, and I got it at a very reasonable price.  It also has the polish of a game by a much larger developer, and depth galore.  Campaign is nothing super special, but there are so many side missions or freelance things, I don't see it as a big deal.  That said, I am pretty early in the campaign so I don't know how it ends up, could get better.

I rate this as a must buy if it even looks remotely enjoyable to you.  Give it a bit of time for you to figure out the intracies, and for it to impress you.  Things might seem simple on the surface, but the game is actually just the right level of complexity.  I can't reccomend this game enough.

reviewText: This game is actually pretty damn sweet. If you enjoyed games like Freelancer or the X series, you will enjoy this without a doubt. It looks amazing, plays smoothly, has a big universe to explore and conquer, has staggering ship customization and upgrades, great trading, easy interface and decent tutorial so you feel comfortable playing it within 10 minutes. It's also surprisingly bug free, for a game that's still in beta, it doesn't crash, nothing. It misses a campaign (I think it will be added in a couple of weeks just in time for release), but even just the free roam mode is great fun. I also loved the idea of having different classes that you can choose with different abilities, some make your ship stronger while others buff your (future) fleet, along with a ton of perks that you can customize as you level up. Gives it a lot of replayability as you try different styles and approaches. Even the music's great. I honestly can't find anything to complain about, and that's pretty rare for m

reviewText:
This game has a lot of good stuff in it, but also some weak spots.

Brief description of the game:
You are commanding a capital class ship in either a sandbox experience or a campaign with main missions. You will be flying around undertaking side missions and smaller assignments, upgrading your ship size and firepower.

First I will start with good things:
+ Proper 3D movement, your ship rotates in all directions
+ Huge map full of objects in space, except planets and spacestations space is full of ships of various factions and other space objects like solar power plants, gas collectors, prisons, etc. All of those obejcts come with few designs so the feeling is that most of them are unique. In addition there are clouds of radiotion of electric storms.
+ In dept ship command. In addition to guns your ship also has tractor beam (you can pull enemy ships), teleport and marines (you can board enemy ships and pull them to nearest station to sell them), launch bays for fighters, slots for various consumable items (bombs, AI turrest, boosters, repair bots etc)
+ Power management. You can direct power between 3 main areas of your ship - engines, weapons and shieldsm by default power if directed 1/3 to each, but you can channel it to one of them in order to receive +100% bonuss to speed, reload, recharge etc, at a cost of -% to others.
(PRO TIP: always channel power to engines when you fast travel for +100% boost, since you cannot shoot in this state anyway)
+ Large selection of ships and weapons as well as system upgrades to treak your ship as you like it, weapon types are really different (plasma are slow firing, slow flying, hight damage, hight power consumption; laser are 100% acurate, quick firing, low damage; projectile are quick firing, medium damage, fast flying) as for missles you can get some with huge area of effect or long distance small area of effect etc.
+ Campaign is not so bad, but lack of options, alternative solutions etc makes it a less fun.

Now to negatives:
- Bad voice acting
- Poor mission reward system - if you wanna by new ships and top weapons you better learn to board enemy ships, do it for few hours at start then start campaign fully equipped. (for example: low level assassination task will give you 4-10k credits, while if you board enemy craft, kill the crew and pull it to space station you will get 80-120k plus you will complete the mission), just doing missions for money is mindless grind and gets boring really fast.
- Not involving space combat, this will require some longer explanation.
Your ship has turrests, shields and missile weapons in 4 sectors (front, aft, port and starport). You can manually aim turrets, but odds of you hitting a tiny little black dot on black space around you are virtually none, the only thing you can hid manually are destroyed ship husks and space station with are not moving. So in order for your turrest to do anything you set them to auto-fire then they will randomly pick a target and shoot few bursts at it, then change target and go on. In the end during combat you can only select target and manually fire guided missles at it and rotate your ship so that more turrets and fresh shields are facing the enemy. After 10h of playing this is damn boring !!!
- Not interesting PTE (power to engines, which is a form of quick flying), as to why it doesnt set power distribution to engines for 100% and has to be done manually for a nice speed boost is a wild guess. And you dont get this fancy visuals of super fast travel like we know from movies, it is just that, your ship flies faster.

Conclusion:
I recommend this game as it is quite fun to play for space exploration for 10-20h of fun, therefor I advice get it on discount because it is not worth 40€.
Then I advice you to learn how to board enemy ships quickly so you can make some good credits and try out weapons and ships.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am using the gunner class freeroaming the map which is pretty big , i like to bounty hunt those big marks for the credit pay outs.
Combat has a very usefull auto fire or you can choose to manual fire, if you wish you can order fire on the systems of the target or just general hits.

Favourite ship class is  the destroyer's but i'm currently using a carrier usefull for exploring when things get heavy launch the fighters.
I honestly think this game has some real potential and have really enjoyed what they have done so far i look forward to them making the single player aspects.

The market and trading and ultra silly cost of travelling the trade lanes needs a good sorting though but i'm sure they will iron out those minor things.Hint use T-Drives to jump to get to destinations.
Found a pass that makes using the trade gates free to use anywhere very handy for trading i must have missed this on my first character it cost 250k credits but you will make it back eventually.

Flight consists of mouse controll and keyboard activated specials allthough most of the special can be activated via the middle mouse  button, graphically it reminds me of freelancer space backgrounds. And it has some nice customization you can do to personlise your ship with unique colours and markings and abillity to name your ship.

Overall i have to say i would recommend and seriously look forward to the up comming content  and i'm sure this game will give you plenty of hours of solid fun , just like freelancer did !

Also there is an active mod community and the Devs seem active, these are promising signs for life beyond the single player mode and game life in the  long run.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

reviewText:
Starpoint Gemini 2 is hours of constant enjoyment. I've been wanting a great space simulator for years and this fills that gap. Space combat ranges from you being overwhelmingly powerful and slaughtering a weaker enemy convoy, to suddenly being completely outmatched as hordes of enemy fleets warp in. You'll go from shifting your power-flow to fully charge your weapons; unleashing torrents of weapon-fire and watching enemy ships violently explode, to frantically diverting power to your shields and engines, cutting power from your weapon-batteries to overcharge your engines and jettison yourself free from the firestorm.

The space combat, environment, and ships are all wonderful and deserve high praise. The only downfall is the narrative in the story mode. My only noted negative is that the plot dialogue is very poorly written: conversations are written with very simplistic wording, adding unnecessary filler dialogue in the middle of a conversation. The characters have no expression and sitting through the dialogue moments are frustrating to even hear the characters speak. All the character interactions are not written as real conversations, monologues occur at inappropriate times. A complete re-writing of the entire game's plot narrative (by someone with writing experience) would make the game perfect.

8.5/10

reviewText:
This was a great game in beta and even better now that it's fully released. It may take a little while to get into but there's plenty plenty of exploring, missions, ships, weapons and upgrades and also Workshop support.
I haven't looked into the campaign much since the freeroam mode interested me more, but it seems to just be freeroam with story missions.

The freeroam missions are a little samey after a while but there's enough variety of mission types for you to choose to be a pacifist or a full on fighter.
Would recommend this if you like open world space sims, with factions and a good variety of ship classes and ships.

reviewText: Da. Best. And that is an exact measurement.  Starpoint Gemini 2 successfully brings the open world 3D single player RPG to space.  Some may say that sprpg is past its prime but SG2 didn't get that memo because this game doesn't feel dated at all and includes all the modern accessories like side quests, an engaging story, lots of skills and ranks and points to customize your character, hireable mercenaries, customizable ships (oh yea), and some awesome new stuff to make you feel like you are not only piloting, but commanding a fleet.  I played this game a lot during early access and I said then that this game had the potential to be awesome if executed correctly and man was it ever!  On top of all that your ship is a whole character of its own with everything from frail gunships to massive carriers that can cloak themselves and launch entire fighter wings from their carrier bays! I would recommend this game to anyone who has suffering in the drought of good space games and anyone who enjoys rpgs.  Oh and [name redacted] this isn't Eve, you get to shoot the guns and do stuff.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

pros:
great ship designs, backgrounds and tunes. no really, the work put into the lighting etc is excellent and for a graphics junkie like me its was stunning.
the variation in weapons and system additions is quite impressive for an alpha game as theres plenty to try out (if you can earn the credits)....
the controls were easy to get to grips with and the learning curve isnt all that steep, more like a shallow bowl then the eiffel tower.
i liked the ability to select missions from the system map as it saved soooo much time with reagrds to the: fly here > dock > mission select > fly there > kill whatever > done.  a novel and great idea and adds more of a flow to the game.
mining is ok if thats your thing, point shoot collect as normal, however i couldnt find any indication of whether the rocks i were shooting were full of good stuff or crap...

cons:
couldnt work out if the shield was full coverage or sectional as in the previous gemini game as angling different sides of the ship would stop hull depletion, well sometimes not everytime. got quite confused.

some enemies get stuck in space and dont move apart from shooting back, for some reason this makes them invulnerable too, so you die.

currently no save feature in the game options, limited auto save though.

combat, and this is my main gripe as its a space combat sim, theres no strafe or reverse!!  if you get to close to an object you have to bounce off it to turn around. increasing distance from targets means flying away from them all the while theyre pounding your ship. avoiding enemy fire is also very hard to do, spinning in a circle helps but only at range as the AI will fire at your current location almost without fail. however up close it just becomes a brawl between either who has the most energy or shield power...
the main thing lacking is the fact theres no strafe (moving on the same access from left to right, up and down) the ability to dodge fire is essential in any fight but sadly gemini 2 does not provide this ability. in essence the fighter fights become nothing more then lancing, flying at each other trying to hit the enemy until you are in close, see above as to why this is bad... i suppose constantly changing the power distribution from shields to weapons to speed could help and some peeps will like that but i prefer flying by the seat of my pants and dodging for that true dogfighter feeling.

furthermore, i loved the beam weapons, very powerful with exceptional range
downsides, very power hungry and can empty your charge in seconds plus theres no zoom feature so no way of knowing if your shots are hitting the target until the enemies hull depletes and as previously stated power to the weapons depletes fast!!

the only bug ive encountered so far was when the game freezes mid flight, not annoying yet as reminisent to PS1 games and their loading next area" moments.

overall for an alpha its quite enjoyable
date: very straight forward missions and great visuals.\n"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am using the gunner class freeroaming the map which is pretty big , i like to bounty hunt those big marks for the credit pay outs.
Combat has a very usefull auto fire or you can choose to manual fire, if you wish you can order fire on the systems of the target or just general hits.

Favourite ship class is  the destroyer's but i'm currently using a carrier usefull for exploring when things get heavy launch the fighters.
I honestly think this game has some real potential and have really enjoyed what they have done so far i look forward to them making the single player aspects.

The market and trading and ultra silly cost of travelling the trade lanes needs a good sorting though but i'm sure they will iron out those minor things.Hint use T-Drives to jump to get to destinations.
Found a pass that makes using the trade gates free to use anywhere very handy for trading i must have missed this on my first character it cost 250k credits but you will make it back eventually.

Flight consists of mouse controll and keyboard activated specials allthough most of the special can be activated via the middle mouse  button, graphically it reminds me of freelancer space backgrounds. And it has some nice customization you can do to personlise your ship with unique colours and markings and abillity to name your ship.

Overall i have to say i would recommend and seriously look forward to the up comming content  and i'm sure this game will give you plenty of hours of solid fun , just like freelancer did !

Also there is an active mod community and the Devs seem active, these are promising signs for life beyond the single player mode and game life in the  long run.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Edit: So here we are after full release.

In all honesty, the story is not presented in a manner I really find easily accessable, which is too bad but survivable. Besides that, everything I was told would be in this game is here, and all the fun I saw coming back in EA is also here. This is early access done right.

In case you haven't read any other reviews, the game is very similar to EVE or X3 in sandbox mode. In story mode it feels quite a bit more linear, but as I said, this is simply because the method of presentation is just not my style, and you may find it's exactly what you like.

Still, lots of fun, lots of freedom, and lots of beautiful, beautiful space in which to make your own story. Good use of your money if you like spaceship combat/trader/adventure sims.

Original reviews:


Even in beta, this is a good game. Not only is the game very playable, but the graphics are good and I personally find even the beta to be more stable and friendly to my recommended-spec rig than many full releases of other games I've played. Great forum community too and the devs are very open to feedback. There is not quite enough to do yet for freeroam to be worth $30,  but if you are reading this after the full release, then you should buy this!

EDIT:

Worth noting that the devs are so active on this that right now, only a few weeks after writing the initial review, enough stuff has been finalized or added to the current beta to probably make it worth your $30. Get on it!

reviewText:
Game managed to get my attention for over 50 hours, however in the end it got a tad monotonous and in the end found it to become rather boring for me. It's not to say this is a bad game. I guess the replayability and scope of what you could do got a tad monotonous in the end.

For those who want to fly around shooting up ships, defend stations from attack, upgrade to increasingly better ships which you can customize, it's a good game to have. Graphically it was average to above average for me.

At the end of the day, I think there were just many other games out there which drew my interest away from this.

5.5/10

reviewText:
Its a decent game. You will probably lose a few hours of your life on it.

The good:
The history.
The controls, very similar to Elite: Dangerous.
Lot of ships.
Lot of modules.
Big space, lot of places to visit...lot of enemies =))
Yet to see -> TITANS!!!

The bad:
The interface isn't intuitive. I'm still trying to find the rank xp bar...
The ship loadout interface is a bit o confusing too.
Aside from the main history, every mission is the same...Go there and kill someone...
We should be able to save it whenever we want, not only inside stations.

The worse:
For some reason the game freeze at some dialogues and at random points while flying. The only solution is alt+F4.
I've looked in the forums but not seems to solve it.

If you are looking for something which resemble EVE without the complexe learning curve and a decent gameplay, this is the one. Just be prepared for redo some missions if the game crashes.
voteText: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
It's a space sim.

If you expect soul-mouving roleplay or vast army battles or deep scale business management, you'll be disapopointed cause... it's a space sim.

It's a pretty darn good space sim at that. It's pretty, atmospheric and quite fun to play.  There are a few bugs still out there but nothing major, nothing to break the game.

The map is huge.  You have good control over your ship and character. There are more factions than you need and there's always stuff happening.  Nothing heavilly scripted, it's all pretty much standard space sim missions.  Destroy that guy, smuggle this, escort that, repair this, explore that. You know.  Space sim.

The voice acting is abysmal.  So abysmal, it's awesome.

Honestly, it feels like a game made by people who have a lot of love for the genre.  I expect to spend many, many more hours exploring space. I just throw a few Malcolm Reynolds one liners here and there and suddenly, I'm in space, doing space stuff. I'm cool like that. (I may or may not be taking meds regarding this)

Oh and the music... I would have bought the game for the music alone.

reviewText: I'm going to start this review by being negative. This is not to savage the work that Little Green Men did on this game, but rather to emphasize the positive bits later.\n\nStarpoint Gemini 2" has some pretty rough areas. The campaign
date: framed through (sometimes yawn-inducing) text boxes and uneven voice-acting
recommended: didn't connect with me very well. There's an interesting twist here and there
hoursPlayed: but I just couldn't manage to care that much about what was going on. The necessary "gloss-n-polish" doesn't exist
voteText: especially with the game dialogue writers having a strange aversion to using the word "the."\n\nThe game's difficulty curve is lumpy and strange
helpfulPercent: with the procedural mission generation apparently taking into account your level
votesHelpful: but not what ship you have. This is also aggravated by a lack of mission information. Especially with the campaign
votesTotal: you don't know that much about what you're heading into. It's possible to get to a point where you just "hit a wall
votesFunny: and get thrown into an engagment that you simply can't win without (at least) having gotten into the next class of ship. There's nothing wrong with this if you have some sort of warning, but for it to happen suddenly and with no advance notice is a kind of fake difficulty" that I dislike.\n\n(I can appreciate a game that's not interested in hand-holding
commentsCount:
but there's also a point where it all turns into sloppy experience design. "Freelancer" got this right by walling you off from taking the next campaign mission if you didn't have the prerequisites. "SG2" gets it wrong by basically telling you nothing aside from the story's flavortext. I simply don't equate legitimate game challenge with failing to communicate effectively.)

I finally got to the point where seeing what happened next in the story was insufficient incentive to work my way up to a more durable spacecraft.

But here's the thing - the above happened more than once. This is where things go positive; That I got pulled back into the experience is a testimony to just how well the basic gameplay loop was crafted.

What the developers really managed to do beautifully is to create an addicting "travel
column16: do
column17: upgrade
column18: repeat" cycle that keeps dragging you back in. The space you fly through is nicely crafted
column19: with a sense of scale that is large without having interminable length between interesting features. The combat is generally satisfying (as long as you're not in a situation where it's overwhelming)
column20: and the other game mechanics manage to be pretty deep without being clunky or hard to get your mind around. Other free-roaming space games give you all kinds of controls
column21: and then those controls don't behave consistently (or at all) as you expect. This title
column22: on the other hand
column23: is very solid in terms of behaving intelligently when you give commands.\n\nIf Little Green Men Games built a sequel that was basically the same core mechanics
column24: but with a far more refined mission (both campaign and procedural) experience
column25: they would be in the same league as "Freelancer." The foundation is there - it just needs to be built upon.\n"

reviewText:
I was out of the genre for a couple of years, and still believe freelancer holds the title of king. While this games tries really hard to copy from freelancer (the ui looks like it was copied straight from 2003) the game doesn't flow.
I have a modern GPU and a fast system, but the engine just doesn't seem responsive. In freelancer I felt like I nimble ship that responds to my every movement, Startpoint feels like I'm piloting a space oil tanker.
Single player made unbarable by the voice acting and the incoherent script.  I still remember large parts of the freelancer plot back from over 12 years ago, here: I can't tell you what I did 5 minutes ago. I don't remember the characters name, don't care about his stupid quest, I just remember it's something really pointless and stupid.
Don't buy this game. I can't think of anyone who it'll appeal to. Maybe Elite is better (didn't try), maybe no man's sky will live up, but there's absolutly no potential in this game, it's a waste of money and time.

reviewText:
I bought this game during a Steam sale not expecting too much of it, but it's had me hooked for weeks now. It's fun to play and offers you a lot of things to do and ways to play. For instance, you can focus on the story, pirating, freelancing or trade goods that you either buy legally or gain by looting other ships. You can even specialize in mining asteroids and gasclouds and sell the gains. Or do all of the above!
The game gets updated regularly and now has a very extensive tutorial library to help new players get started. You're able to customize your ship's weapon loadout and, to a certain level, it's color and decals.
The only things I've noticed so far that could be improved is the voice acting in the storyline (which is pretty hilarious at times) and weapon impact effects. The latter look really poorly done compared to the sleek and smooth ship designs, explosions and absolutely beautiful galaxy you travel through.
Oh, and the main menu music alone could have made me buy this game, just thought I'd mention that too.

reviewText:
Finally, a game that scratches my decade-long Freelancer itch.

But first, a disclaimer. While no longer an Early Access title, Starpoint Gemini 2 - as of October 2014 - is not quite the finished article. The game still has a number of items turned off in the options menu. Certain gameplay features seem to be half-finished, and the AI does not seem to be taking advantage of all the tools available in combat. In fact, many newcomers are bound to be turned off by the obtuse UI design and the text-heavy, non-interactive tutorials that spit out seemingly unending streams of text on things they have no idea about.

Get past the initial frustrations, however, and you will find an absolute gem of a timesink. SG2 nails the three key elements of a good space sim: simple controls, a massive universe full of activities, and a million paths to success on your own terms. Starting off in a tiny gunship and a poorly-voiced campaign mission, you are quickly set loose and given freedom to roam the absolutely gigantic map to mine, trade, explore and fight to your heart's content. Veteran X players may be disappointed by the comparatively static world, limited fleet building options and inability to set up your own industrial empire in the stars, but everyone else should be more than satisfied with the wealth of choices at hand. This is more than worth it at full price, and absolutely unmissable in a sale.
voteText: 9 of 15 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This game is great if you want a single player RPG and to run around in space.  The free roam is cool but gets old, and the story gives you purpose but it is limited.  This GAME WOULD BE EPIC if it had multiplayer support.  If you could build a fleet with real humans and maybe go raid someone that might be able to apply a little bit of strategy.  The biggest drawback is that it is linear, you want to beat someone get some better guns... or a bigger ship, thats it.  Buy a long range weapon and you can literally just tease the AI until they are dead waiting out of there auto combat range, attacking them and backing off when they chase so they start all over.

reviewText:
I am really enjoying this game.  To be fair, it has bugs, but overall it is fairly solid.  I used to play EVE Online for several years after it first came out and SG2 does have a *similar* feel.  The controls can be awkward at first, but after you make some fine-tuning on your own it becomes just as intuitive as any other mouse and keyboard based sim.  Note that in the last week+ since it came on steam, the community has been growing rapidly and there is a ton of good information to help new players adjust the game to fit their playstyle in this kind of sim.  If you are having difficulty, please look there and see if someone can help!

One of the biggest factors for me is that the devs are continuously fixing the small things *and* the big picture as well.

I'm excited to see where the game will go in the future...
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I'm going to try to make this as concise and clear as possible but I have a lot to say. Also note I have not played the main campagn yet although I've put around 30 hours into the sandbox mode.


Pros: SG2 has a huge universe with a cool backstory that can be read on the wiki. This game allows you to change alignments based on your actions. For the first 10 hours I was just trying to get to the point where I can strike out on my own as a pirate but ended up feeling that I wouldn't want to betray the people I had been helping the whole time. I'm not RPing as a bounty hunter, hunting down all criminals with a bounty on their head. It's pretty great.

The art direction is absolutely amazing. So much so that I got a SG2 background for my desktop. I feel like it really grasps the true beauty of space. The music is deep and emersive and it changes based on the situation in a smooth manner.

Cons: The learning curve was pretty tough in the beginning. There was a tutorial but it was kind of a huge wall of text after another.

Conclusion: This is a truly amazing game. I wish these devs had an EA budget so they could make even more content. I will definitely be purchasing Starpoint Gemini 3.

reviewText:
To be honest, I am impressed. Good graphics, fun battles, large base of ships and weapons. It was money well spent.

Game is stable, which, lately is not that common for games of this size. I haven't nodist major bugs.

If you liked Freelancer, You will like this title. On the other end of spectrum, this is not X saga. It is not as complicated or deep. It is fun shooter, with options to mine, trade, change ships and thier equipment,  but it is not an empire building game.

Campaing is ok, but I wasn't really waiting to find out what will happen next. On the other hand it is only small part of the game. Just flying around and blowing pirates, doing quests, and getting money for upgrades and new ships is fun in it self.

There are some minor AI issues:
- Your mercenaries will follow you... unless you decide to jump in any way (t-drive, wormhole, gate). They will stay there and wait. This is not really a problem, as for the most part of the game, they are not needed anyway.
- Your turrets in auto mode and your fighters will not engage enemy sometimes in campaign missions. Outside missions everything is fine though, and issues was in maybe 3 missions.

I haven't nodist anything more serious.

All in all, it is a good buy.

reviewText:
gotta say this was exactly what i hoped it would be. an awesome galaxy surfing vehicle combat game with excellent mods and dev support. endless replay value and more ships to choose from than you will ever even see in one playthrough. seriously ive played about 100 hours so far and still half my map is unexplored.

as all good games are you start out weak and end up becoming a juggernaut of near infinite power. and yet you can still get ganged up on to the point where your only choice is flee or die.

tactical decisions go a long way and you definitely want to gather the best weapons, enhancments, officers and skills. but the best part is the freedom to choose what you do. do you mine asteroid and gas with a freightliner, or become wealthy thru the destruction of your enemies in a carrier, or do you become the master trader soaring around the galaxy at incredible speeds trading resources and transporting vip's in a cruiser. its totally up to you how you play this game.

if i had complaints about this game it would be these. 1) more mods, 2) more weapon levels and choices, 3) more levels, and 4) better explained stats. so 3 out of 4 complaints are that i just want more. thats always a good thing. to play a game you can never get enough of. and if boredom ever does set in i can always start anew with a different approach, class or end goal. THIS IS A MUST HAVE!!!!!!

reviewText:
As a sequal to Starpoint Gemini it's beginning to look good... In a nutshell, they did a great job on the graphics and the 3rd dimension in the 3D environment can now actually be used. They also took away the seperate sectors and merged them into 1, with sometimes undesirable lag but no more loading screens and the feel of a huge area to play around in. Big plus there.

The gameplay has suffered greatly though, as you can no longer buy/sell individual ship systems as would in the previous game, since a somewhat different system has been employed, but worse yet, there no longer is a significant subsystem targeting system, but from what I understand that is yet to be implemented.

Bare in mind though that this is still in Beta when this was written, but it should give a general idea about what happened. With Starpoint Gemini in mind, I am a little bit more optimistic compared to my last edit. I did love that interface, but that's gone...

reviewText:
I played Elite: Dangerous, then X3AP, then X:Rebirth, went back to X3AP and finally I stumbled on Starpoint Gemini 2. How I came to this game? In elite, I was fascinated by the cool-looking fighters, the dog-fighting with HOTAS controller and hype of Horizon. I soon realised the game was time-consuming and i was unable to accomplish as much as I would expected. I loaded up X3 (I bought during a steam sale) and started playing. This game also had dog-fighting, tons of ship classes but the main draw was the scope and depth of the game. At the midpoint, I coud lead a wing of fighters, setup space stations and managed a fleet of trading freighters. It was really cool but I spent way too much time and the graphics were not as cool. I hopped over to X: Rebirth and got a headache navigating in the engine. I hopped back to X3 for a short while and finally got to SPG2.

SPG2 is a Space-Theme ARPG. In free-roam, you control a ship and navigate through a gigantic starchart map. You can pick up alot space-thremed missions, mine asteroids, trade between space stations and planets, be a pirate or police. It cover much of everything you can think of in a space sim game but to a limited depth. I won't not say it is a shallow game because you have a pretty good idea of what a space sim would be like after playing this game.

+ Tons of playable ships
+ Beautiful ship designs
+ Space combat is flashy and exciting.
+ Tons of things to do, you won't get bored of things to do

- Limited functionality in several aspect of a typical space sim game
- Reputation system, licences and bulletin news interface seems like a mere after-thought
- Shield system is surprisingly 2 dimensional
- No real space dogfighting
- It is definitely not SPG1 or starfleet command
- I had this feeling it is designed to be played on consoles since it is evidently simplified, not a good thing for PC players.

This game shines when you play at it as a ARPG in a space theme setting and not as a typical space sim. Its greatness comes from the sum of all the parts it has to offer. For its vast contents and production value, I disagree it is a poor man's Free Space.

reviewText:
This is my impression of the game after about 39 hours of play. This game is mostly fun, as a game like this can be “fun”. This is a space simulation and as such, there is a lot of “space”. Moving from one place to another is a test of patience.

It is very nice to look at and the music background/atmosphere is gorgeous; I can just listen to this game for hours. Unfortunately, the main story is not very interesting (after having done a few missions, I don’t even know what it is about). I am currently at level 17 but haven’t advanced much in the story because I don’t have any incentive to do so, or I don’t care for the story.

I am mostly having fun exploring, mining, capturing ships and selling them to make money, because the game doesn’t give you much of that and selling ships is the best and the fastest way to make money.

There doesn’t seem to any real purpose in this game; you just go around doing stuff that, ultimately, has no purpose.

This is a nice game to play if you know what you are getting into. But I should point out that this is not a fast game to play so you need to have lots of time and patience on your hands.

- I had this feeling it is designed to be played on consoles since it is evidently simplified, not a good thing for PC players.

This game shines when you play at it as a ARPG in a space theme setting and not as a typical space sim. Its greatness comes from the sum of all the parts it has to offer. For its vast contents and production value, I disagree it is a poor man's Free Space.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nQuite simply, there have been very few worthy space RPGs and combat games in recent history. I'm finicky about buying games, and no space offerings in the last few years have captured my interest enough to buy them. Now it's 2014, and two games in development have had me seriously interested: Elite: Dangerous and this one, Starpoint Gemini 2. I have to say, although this game is in Beta stage, it's quite beautiful and very functional already. It seems very stable at this point. The freelance missions are plenty to keep me engaged as the game begins to blossom for official release. Space feels huge in this game, and I really get a sense of a living, breathing Gemini system. Also, the MUSIC. It's wonderful, and I really love that there is no cliche combat music" when I inevitiably run into skirmishes enroute on my mission. Developers- please don't change this. The music really captures the vastness of the universe

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Right off the bat, this sequel is markedly superior to its predecessor without even being complete. Graphics, interface, play controls, sound, and music are all better. As it stands now, SPG2 is a somewhat plain but serviceable space sim. You can play in a 'sandbox' mode, roaming the system exploring, trading, pirate-hunting or doing freelance missions and work your way up to bigger and better ships. The game's 'RPG class' system has been implemented, allowing you to choose one of three captain 'types', each with four distinct skills, and there is an array of perks that you can choose from to customize your character.  Navigation and combat are straightforward and can be mastered fairly quickly.

There are still a number of annoying bugs and alot of memory leaks, so it tends to be up to chance whether you'll have a stable experience or a lot of crashes. Certain aspects of the game design (particularly the economy and enemy AI) still have to be tweaked and balanced. That being said, the game is still heavily in development (just entered beta stage) and many planned features have not yet been implemented. SPG2 is nowhere near complete, and yet I feel it is still good enough to provide an engaging experience. The dev team is clearly enthusiastic, determined, and appreciative of all their beta testers - they are definitely quick to respond to forum threads and e-mails and are quite good about accepting feedback and suggestions.

I definitely think that Starpoint Gemini 2 is worth picking up if you are a fan of immersive space combat/starshiip command sim games, even in its early, unpolished state. It is an enjoyable, well-designed product with a lot of potential that will surely be realized in the near-term by a dedicated and passionate team of developers.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For a beta this is a stable experience. So far I have 6 hours in and no crashes. Fullscreen and in a window on an Win 7 x64 install; AMD FX4130 Quad core 3.8hgz 8gb, Radeon HD 7700 4gb.  Holding my interest even without a storyline but I wonder if Ill be done with it as soon as the map is explored to return for a well fleshed out full version. There is certainly an enthusiastic and active community with recent relevant posts.

Whilst looking for a space or 4x or Freelancer fix this won out over Space Engineers and Mission to Mars by a gnats ♥♥♥. They are still in the oven. This seems playable and solid with a developer that is working on a 4x game as well. That just put me over the top.

Gameplay doesnt feel like a time sink so far. The hud layout covers the basics for letting you know whats going on. Navigation and camera took some getting used to. The combination of mouse follow (toggle space bar) and camera view (toggle TAB) threw me at first. The depth of menus (ship, officers, fleet) makes traveling to a remote station worthwhile if not for a trade then perhaps some rare talent or other. Im just scratching the surface and have to note the AI ship voice doesn't annoy the crap outta me and is useful as I tool around with this for the first time.

reviewText:
I'm loving Starpoint Gemini 2: probably the best space game in year. It's transitioned out of beta nicely, with minimal bugs, and improved optimization. The game has two modes, story and sandbox, and both are quite enjoyable. The control scheme feels a little like Nexus the Jupiter (but not exactly), in the sense that you're the commander of a large ship with various systems (and not just a fighter). Much better than the X series imo.

The game excells at allowing you to create the kind of space captain you want to be, and the kind of ship you want to fly. There are three classes, commander, gunner, and engineer, and each excells at different specializations. Commanders are great pilots, and augment their fleets; while, gunners excell at blowing things up; the engineer can create space anomalies like vortexes that suck enemy ships in, deal radiation damage to crews, or they can hack and shut down ship systems.

The ships are fantastic. Nearly a hundred different ships of varying classes that you can customize and taylor to your play style. You can control frigates and battleships - and command squadrons of fighters (but there are no fighters you can fly). Place different systems, weapons, and then tweak those systems and weapons with different modules. So, for example, you can tweak your teleporter to improve its capacity, or give it a defensive characteristic, and use it to block enemy teleports. (your ships have troops which can defend against and invade and take over other ships which you can later keep or sell.) Do you install a module with better accuracy, damage, or, for a little more money, both?

Finally, there are a variety of things to do. You can be a trader, a smuggler, a pirate (raid and steal ships), or a fleet commander of some sorts. There are anomalies in space that you can simply go out, explore, scan, and document, and gain experience from this. You can ferry VIP or desparately needed supplies between stations. As much variety to the missions as in any space game.

My only real complaints, and by no means are these game breaking, is the lack of documentation (there's very little information available on what different game mechanics do, exactly. Which is frustrating, since they obviously took the time to put different mechanics into the game. For example, some guns do emp" damages
recommended: and no where does it say exactly what it means by this
hoursPlayed: one is just left to assume that radiation hurts crews and emp drains batteries or shields.\n\nMy second complaint is that there's just too much clutter. Don't get me wrong
voteText: the game is beautiful
helpfulPercent: but everywhere you look there's some beautiful nebulae
votesHelpful: star
votesTotal: or simply space debry all around you. Your eyes get overwhelmed by the clutter
votesFunny: never are you allowed to enjoy the simplicity of being amongst the stars. You never get the sense that you're exploring unchartered territory
commentsCount: as there are ships and stations everywhere you go.\n\nAll in all
column16: excellent game. 8/10."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me start by saying that if you have any interest at all in the Space/RPG genre you simply have to grab this game. Anyone who liked Freelancer, Freespace 1/2, Elite, I-War or any of the X games (apart from reunion) will be right at home here.

Now for full disclosure I grabbed S♥♥♥♥ couple of months ago while it was still in Alpha stage and initially I wasn't too impressed. While issues are to be expected when you are playing an Alpha version, on my low-mid system, frame rate and stability issues kept me from playing for more than a couple of hours and I left the game alone for a while until some of these things were worked out.

Boy! What a difference a couple of months makes. I figured since it finally got it's nice new Beta" tag that I'd fire it up again and I'm really glad that I did
date: over 12 hours in the last 3 days can attest to how much fun I've been having with it.\n\nThe basic premise of the game is your a star ship captain dropped into a dynamic living game world and your free to do pretty much whatever you want in a sandbox environment. (As of this writing the more linear campaign option has not been added yet
recommended: but is coming down the pipe shortly) :\n\nFeel like transporting VIPs or cargo from one sector to another
hoursPlayed:
while enjoying the scenery? Check.
Want to make your fortune by mining asteroids and junk yards? Check.
Indescriminately want to blow up (Or at least try) any ship that comes near you? Check.

Pros:
Mind blowing number of ships to choose from (If you have the cash of course!)
Plenty of factions to work with or against.
3 unique classes with choices on which enhancements and perks to put into different skills when you level up.
Galactic news and events that actually happen in the gameworld rather than being just Lore or Fluff.
Excellent ship to ship tactical combat.
Player driven goals

UI needs to provide more feedback. (Not being able to see the target summary unless your looking right at it

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAs an ALPHA BUILD, it is a pretty good game. I recommend it based on what I have seen and the possibilities that can follow. Energy allocation is a pretty nice touch. Weapon dynamics based on direction as well. However, I believe they are still unbalanced. Right now, there's not much to do. Not a lot of quest variety and some of them are very confusing (DAMN YOU TAXI MISSIONS). However, it is a lot of fun dominating multiple ships by yourself. If you like mindless sandbox gameplay, I recommend getting this game now. If you want a storyline, you may buy it later when scenarios are added. Eitherway, this is a pretty good casual game with nice pickups when multiple fleets are against you.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI have been looking for a mission/take your time/no poxy scenario game for a while now and this delivers.  It does, however, take a bit of time to get into the game and used to the control system (I kept shooting at friendlies by clicking the wrong mouse button).  But if you persevere its defintaely worth the wait.  Although still in Beta and without a campaign mode it is worth the money.  This is the first game I've played where you actually feel like other people are aboard your ship helping you - normally its do everything yourself, from steer, to fire to damage control - whereas with SG2 you can do as much or as little as you wish.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nGotta say, as these sorts of space sims go, this is one of the better ones I've played in a while. Its got the resourceyness and good mission flow you want, with a list of well designed ships you'll always be drooling over. Mechanically some parts are a little clunky just yet (boarding and such) but, seeing as how its still very much a beta, I'm sure they'll iron out the kinks. All in all a VERY fun game!

Early Access Review

EXELLENT GAME - if you played freelancer or elite: frontier / first encounters, or even privateer the darkening ... this game is for you, its only in early beta stages but this has the potential to be the BEST space sim ever created... the feel of the ships the look of the universe, everything is going for this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm new to Steam and one of the first games I searched for was Freelancer, no luck there unfortunatly. So I was keeping an eye out for a similar, if not even better after ten years, replacment for my space combat kicks. The vids on the Store page for Starpoint Gemini 2 look amazing, it seemed to tick all the boxes.

Regardless of your Class you start with an awesome ship, it reminded me of B5s WhiteStar. It's a beast, easily crushing the initial waves of pirate scum who think they're hard enough. As you progress slightly you come up against larger foes and more drawn out battles that require a little more thought. You can upgrade your weapons or change them out, improve your crew to improve your boarding party and the idea of having a Merc fleet to command sounds great. There is a very solid foundation for an epic game here.

Combat is on the whole more tactical than Freelancers wild dog-fights, although in fairness I'm not expecting a Cruiser or Frigate Class ship to turn on a dime like a Fighter. A bit more pace wouldn't hurt though. There is currently no story mode and I didn't think I would miss it so much untill it wasn't there. The good news is that it's yet to come, so that's really something to look forward to. For the the time being however, I'm done flying about on other faceless peoples errands as it really has no impact on the greater Galactic Goings-On. The Devs have done a superb job so far but they've a real task ahead to fill out Gemini and the players role in the galaxy.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nRight now the only thing implemented is a free roam sandbox. Plenty of missions to run, things to see, and fun to be had. Flying and controling your ship takes 10-15 min to get fully used to - but once you do the game really opens up and grabs you. If your wondering if you should buy the game I would tell you to go for it - if you like space games. I have not run into any bugs yet and am really happy with how the game plays right now. Early Access can be a bit of a minefield sometimes, thankfully SG2 is pretty damn solid as it currently stands. I am happy with my purchase.

reviewText:
At first I thought this game sucked but the more I play it the more fun it is. It reminds me a lot of freespace 2 which is a great thing because that game rocked! However if your looking for a dogfight space sim then this isnt it. You get to fly huge ships which are more like gigantic gun boats. The voice acting is terible but dont let that put you off as the core gameplay is solid. I wish these guys had more money to spend on the game and add better social comms like the old wing commander 4. The game does feel lifeless sometimes as you do't really commincate with anyone, be it friendlies enemies or neutrals. So far this game has sucked up 11 hours of my life and I'm sure many hours to follow.

Hint: Leave your joystick unplugged, you won't need it. This games designed for mouse and keyboard and works well with it.

Overall 7/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So I used to play EVE online a lot, and when I say alot I mean a social life endagering amount. Dont get me wrong, its an awesome game, but I always felt underpressure from my corperation and the fact it was a pay monthy subscription to play as much as I possibly/physically could. Due to this I eventually stopped playing and have ever since been on the lookout for something that comes even remotley close to EVE visually, mechanically and diversly. Starpoint Gemini 2 is the best I have found yet, and (as at the time of writing this) is still only in BETA!! Really looking forward to where they are going to take this, and no pay monthly fee so I can pick up and put down as I wish without feeling like I'm losing money. Ok so its not as complex as EVE but EVE was (imho) massivley complex and this game does just enough without frying your brain. Diversity is there, the amount of stuff you can do already without the campain is huge, visuals are breathtaking and the playable area is massive, not EVE massive but I ve been playing now for about 20 hours with 1 character and I've only explored about 1/8 of the map. Very well done on this guys and a big thumbs up on how much feedback you take from the forums. Its so nice to see deleopvers actually listening to us gamers and implementing changes directly off the back of feedback/critisims/ideas that come straight from the community. If you used to (or still do) play EVE, love space sims (or not) or are just looking for something to fill the gap between now and Star Citizen, look no further.

All in all I give Starpoint Gemini 2 9/10 and watch this space, its only gonna get better

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't normally play space related games, nor did I play the first SP Gemini but I decided to give this one a chance based on what I saw and was pleasantly surprised.  Compared to other early access games I wasn't as disappointed as normal, in fact at this point this game could pass as an alpha.

As far as the gameplay this is more of a you against the galaxy type of deal, you fly a spaceship, you may have multiple garaged spaceships that you own but (somewhat like ace combat in a way) but it is 100% open*galaxy*.  Normal gameplay consists of going on randomized missions such as assassinate, ferry cargo/passengers, capture ships, smuggle counterfiet goods etc, you level up/rank up and have a skill tree/rank tree.

You may earn money through missions, trading, mining (asteroids and other such objects), plundering derelict ships, and the best is to find rare high level bounty ships which earn you considerable profits.  You spend your money on new ships, ship systems (weapons) and system upgrades.

Sorry for the long review but I tried to explain what I would have wanted to see before I bought it (well worth the money by the way!)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really like the licenses that you can buy but for the price of the licenses maybe the perk you get when you buy the license  should be increased or the prices of the licenses lowered.

the auto-pilot is awesome and sometimes theres nothing better than just drifting through space but at times i find it a bit uneventful, other than the stunning scenery and the the enemy factions and pirates that you run into theres not much else that makes the trip exciting. maybe turning the autopilot off when the ship has to travel through asteroid fields or maybe even grouping the asteroids closer together so that the ship has to be manouvered

the map is really easy to read and finding my bearings isnt a problem, i have played similar games and have found them vey complicated, i find this one the easiest to understand and play but its not to say that its not a very challenging game although  a better tutorial could be made. i found the current tutorial a bit too much to remember at once.

all in all it is an amazing game and i would recomend it to all my friends. i am curious to see multiplayer or even mass multiplayer capabilities. the graphics are a 10/10 and the ship controll is challenging but fun to master. it would be great to see a few more classes introduced as well.

reviewText: This game really scratches the Freelancer itch.  It's fairly easy to pick up, although I wish it had a better tutorial.  One of the early main campaign missions tells you to do something, but did not explain how to actually do it.  After stumbling my way through that it's been fairly smooth sailing. It's fairly easy to make cash, and the missions are fairly fun.  I did have a couple of crashes, but they were few and far between.  The autosave system when you land somewhere works well, and ensures that even if you do crash, you don't lose much progress.\n\nOverall, I'm really enjoying this game, and it was worth picking up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

OK, so the game is great. Looks great, sounds great, fun to play, everything about it is awesome.

EXCEPT that it's Beta, like really Beta. While it's a fun as hell game to play it crashes pretty consistently every 30 minutes or so. It has done this to me so many times that while I have 11 hours on record with steam I have only actually progressed through the game for 6.5, so just over half. The main reason for this huge loss of time has to do with the save system. It's pretty stupid: you can only save while docked, and (right now at least) you loose those missions (not failed, you loose access to those missions as if they never existed) so every time the game crahes before I can save I loose whatever time I invested into the game.

So consider this game in an update or two. Or play at your own risk. Granted right now there is no story so you're really loosing free play, which is no real big deal.

reviewText:
I'll cover the game, but first I need to talk about the developers.

This game is helmed by the best company/team I've ever encountered in a long time. They work & worked very hard on this SG2 which was even a joy to play incomplete in the earlier betas - constantly (like to the point of how do you get any work done?) reading, replying, and participating in forum discussions. They entertain ideas for how to approach planned features & possiblities of integrating new ones. This game is far from done in their eyes, and we are all excited to see how SG2 evolves over the long run.

Oh yeah, the game: The graphics are awesome. The difficulty is varied enough to appeal to everyone (I'm in the extreme club, and find it quite challenging at times). You feel the constant itch to explore as available ship components, slot enhancements, crew officers, mercenaries, and new ship models differ between areas - and buying a ship direct from the manufacturer is cheaper than buying 3rd party from a different faction.

Don't want to or can't buy a ship (because that faction hates you)? Grind rep and switch sides, or just board and capture the ship for yourself. Want to mine asteroid fields? You can do that. Want to capture ships and sell them for millions? You can do that too. Want to hunt down obsure achievements? They're here.

And this game is only going to get better.

Positive
+ Awesome community
+ Gameplay rewarding proper piloting
+ Mod support (check out sound, graphics, and UI mods)
+ Craftable rare drops (blueprints) that feel as good in use as they are frustrating to get
+ Power management
+ Huge map
+ Wormholes!
+ Great music
+ Interesting campaign storyline

Neutral
+/- Slow start - it's very hard to begin classing up in ships, especially for new players. There are guides, but there is a bit of a grind. I like the payoff feeling from earning your way. Others will just go get a mod that gives them 1 billion credits. I suggest learning.

Negative
- Voice acting (there is a mod that improves a bit).
- Illegal goods priced roughly equivalent to expensive legal goods.
- Trade market prices could be more varied for better profits.
- Few factors past pool numbers for shields and hulls.
- Unrealistic aggro (2 gunships will think" they can take on your dreadnought and rip you out of cruise speed)."

reviewText: This space simulation starts off a little slow but is a lot of fun once you get up and running. Think of it as a simplified version of the X series. At this time, theres enough content to get about 25-35 hours worth out of this title at a minimum. Its very sandbox-y with an average story thrown on top.  The storyline itself was interesting, but the voice acting was pretty awful.  All in all, I'd recommend it only if you are into space sim games.

reviewText:
Game is very good for awhile, nice amount of things to do. Great controls, upgrades, options and visuals.

But eventually, it's not the repetition of missions that grows old, it's the feeling that nothing around you changes, you can't own anything, build anything, destroy anything, push enemies back. So eventually becomes very stagnant. I totally get the dynamic stuff would be hard to implement, but then perhaps an easier way to liven things up is to throw in some random stuff like starports getting blown up (then coming back online after repairs), or certain races getting push back into the fringes or something. You can basically just settle into trading and fighting between two starports and essentially, aside from the background visuals not being different than another area... that.. is all the game becomes.  It's too bad because it has great potential and I admitedltly spent hours upon hours playing this game (65 I think). But I hit a point where the after reaching the 4 edges of the map, there was simply nothing else to do but even that is not bad, it's the feeling that nothing you do has any effect. Even trading seems to have no effect on prices or anything from what I can tell.

I totally recommend it. But with the caveat that you too may hit this point where it just stops being interesting.

reviewText: I am mostly a multiplayer gamer, love COOP, most multiplayer games, however there are some which are fun offline, of course, and this is one of them. Unique gameplay, easy controls, especially when you're mostly committed to mouse and keyboard style gameplay, Haven't played in a while, though I haven't played much of anything lately; landscraping, as opposed to computer work which I've done for 20+ years, these days, am just tired when I get home from work, though if I didn't have a wonderful woman, cooking amazing food and keeping me enthralled with her ways, I'd probably game more, and before long I'll be back gaming and doing computer work. I love to work out-of-doors, but my skills are strong on the side of the technical realm. Back to the game, It is not too complex, don't get me wrong, I love complexity, but Starpoint Gemini does require quick thinking and reaction; observing it evolve through updates / patches since I bought it in the spring of 2014, the developers seem pretty intent on making this game something to speak of and they are certainly not ditching their creation, unlike other devs I've seen veer away from working on a game, not keeping to their promises.\nI recommend this game, for sure, especiallyl at this sale price, $10.49 as of September 28, 2015. For this price you absolutely cannot pass it up. To me, it is one of those games, I'll pick back up on, finish a few missions, upgrade my ship and be content, looking forward to playing again to utilize the new hardware and getting a feel for the upgrades and their impact on gameplay.\nCheers to the devs and all who enjoy the style of gameplay.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

OK, so the game is great. Looks great, sounds great, fun to play, everything about it is awesome.

EXCEPT that it's Beta, like really Beta. While it's a fun as hell game to play it crashes pretty consistently every 30 minutes or so. It has done this to me so many times that while I have 11 hours on record with steam I have only actually progressed through the game for 6.5, so just over half. The main reason for this huge loss of time has to do with the save system. It's pretty stupid: you can only save while docked, and (right now at least) you loose those missions (not failed, you loose access to those missions as if they never existed) so every time the game crahes before I can save I loose whatever time I invested into the game.

So consider this game in an update or two. Or play at your own risk. Granted right now there is no story so you're really loosing free play, which is no real big deal.

reviewText:
If you enjoyed Freelancer, you'll love this. Many similar mechanics, with great ship customization. Maneuvering in space to get the best angles during a fight are fantastic, and managing your troops and ship's abilities and shields make every fight unique and fun.

The story mode has bad writing and worse voice acting as well as being quite linear, so I'm mostly using it just for the experience to get bigger and better ships.

The most frustrating bit of the game are the crashes. I've yet to have a single play session which didn't crash on me aty least 3 times. You'll be in the middle of a huge fight, and the game will suddenly die. The best thing the Devs did was implement auto save whenever you visit a space station or planet. But if you get in a middle of a big fight out in space and suddenly the game locks up, God help you.

-- Edit: I wrote this mini-review/opinion piece a while ago, and the game is far, far, far more stable. Over the time since it was written, the Development team have been awesome in their implementation of not only new features, but bug fixes. The aforementioned random crashes are gone. Thoroughly enjoy this game.

reviewText: I wrote this review in January of 2015 on Metacritic.  I thought I posted it to Steam, but did not.  This game deserves a review.  Here's a copy/paste of my former review.  The game has only gotten better through expansions.\n\nI am a Star Citizen backer. Want to know a dirty little secret? I love and crave 3rd person space games. En route to searching for something to fill this desire, I came across this game. A Steam sale?" I asked. "Twenty-four bucks?" I blinked. "I spend that on 2-3 drinks at a restaurant with the wife..." So
date: I plucked this one out of the Steam shelf
recommended: downloaded and started playing. Eight hours later I looked up and saw it was 4am. "Woah..." The next (read: later that) day I dove into the Starpoint Gemini 2 Community and learned I was late to a really cool party.\n\nDid you love Freelancer? Are you craving a 3rd person Space game? What are you waiting for...? Pick this gem up ASAP. There are few games that are so worth your money that you'll want to encourage others to purchase
hoursPlayed: but this is certainly one for me. In a day when space sims are seeing a great resurgence
voteText: it's refreshing to see a game that's not afraid to be 3rd person and give the player a bit of a relaxed take on space.\n\nI feel like a Malcom Reynolds
helpfulPercent: flying around in my ship
votesHelpful: always with my eye on a new shiny
votesTotal: but lovingly holding onto
votesFunny: in my case
commentsCount: "Big Red
column16:
until the time is truly right. There's dangers around every planet, but I've got a crew, a purpose, seemingly endless space to explore (certainly more than my limited time allows), and a ship. There's even a fun plot-line to follow along as you make your way in the galaxy--or don't; whatever--it's all up to you.

I can assure you that if you want a rewarding, relaxing, and immersive (but not taking itself too seriously) space game, this is it. I give it a 9 (I'd have done 9.5 if it let me) because of the somewhat outdated UI, and the graphics are not the most polished. That said, the graphics do not detract from the game too much and again, it's sort of a breath of fresh air of late with the Elite: Dangerous's and Star Citizen's of the world.

The development team has their ear to the forums and though I am new to the scene, they appear to be largely shaping the game around their community. It's mod friendly, and seemingly more so as time goes on, and there's already some great mods out there. It's much of anything you want in a fun game.

Cheers.

reviewText:
Starpoint Gemini 2 is an enjoyable Space Sim, and still looks good for its age, but I wouldn't grab it for the $35 price. It's definitely a game to buy on sale though. Some key points:

1. This is a combat focused game. Don't bother trying to be a trader; it won't work, and you can't automate the process like in X3.
2. Along 1 above, the primary way you can make money in this game is capturing ships. Unless you want to end up outclassed, learn how to use your troopers and grappling beam.
3. The progression through the classes of ships is well balanced; each feels like an improvement, without any of them feeling redundant.
4. Each class of ship does feel unique, and the methodology of flying and fighting in a corvette is distinctly different than in a dreadnought.
5. The different models of ships in each class are also rather distinct from one another, and will play well with different tactics. For instance, one ship may have great overlapping fire arcs between the side and front turrets, but have hardly any coverage on the top bottom and the back, while another will offer ballanced coverage over the whole ship, but can't offer the same forward punch.
5. Ye gods, the voice acting is TERRIBLE, and the plot is a throw away at best. This wasn't a big issue for me, as the game is mostly free-roam.

reviewText:
The game has come a LONG way since my initital review, so time to update the thing.
1. The developers are awesome.
2. This game, in early days, was a fun amusement. With their improvements as time has gone on, it has lived up to its potential. This game is now king of the hill in its genre, as far as I'm concerned.
3. At the time of this writing, developers are still improving and enhancing the game.
4. A number of game files (such as savegames) are in human-readable formats, making fixes (like if you screwed up a mod) or various changes suprrisngly doable if you want to go beyond the game's core gameplay.
5. The game is beautifully made, graphically speaking. Voice acting is still getting all the lines filled out as far as I can tell, and some characters have better voices than others, and not all are voiced, but it's good for the most part.
6. Why are you still reading this review, BUY THE GAME ALREADY!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Okay...I've been playing for a week or so now, and am overall VERY pleased with the game.  There are several bugs that obviously need to be chased down and cleaned up, but if you are a fan of the space (trading) games of the past, then this will win your heart.

There isn't much of a story line yet, but the sandbox (freeform) mode is exceptional, not to mention HUGE!  Did I mention that the map is HUGE?

For a fact, there are more opponents, stations, friends, and asteroids to keep you busy for a VERY long time.  It's because the map is HUGE!

The game is more akin to Freelancer than to Mass Effect (at least until they get the story part released), and you have so many options to build and customize your ship(s) it's going to make GOTY for space sims.

The visuals are a little less important than the action and details, and you get to blow stuff up.  A LOT of stuff.  It's probably because the map is HUGE!

Spend the money.  Buy the game.  Enjoy wiping out lots of enemies on the HUGE map.
