reviewText:
This is a really good space game.

The game offers various control methods to let you fly your ship like a pilot/dogfighter or play more of a commander role using turret view. At first it takes a while to get used to the controls and fight effectively with a style you like but once you play out a few battles out you will find a control style that suits you and probably end up switching between them depending on the situation and the ship you are using.

The graphics and interface are really nice and the game runs very well on my medium system which is an AMD APU with integrated graphics.

The sound effects are good but some cool warp like sound effect for the t-drive would be nice. The music is very good although perhaps some more variety would be nice especially for the battle music.

The story and voice acting is probably the weakest part of the game but the game offers plenty of freedom to explore space and play how you want to. So you can play like a pirate or a trader, mine or do missions etc. There's plenty to do and it's all fun.

The game has a nice rpg element which means you can upgrade your skills for when you are in battle and upgrade perks for various different effects like trading bonuses or ship capture bonuses etc. You can customise your ships weapons and buy bigger and better guns and ships as you progress through the ranks and acquire more credits.

Overall I would recommend getting this game, especially if you are into space games.
voteText: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Great space exploration game, the storyline is enjoyable but not extremely content packed and not very interesting. The best part of the game is really exploring the very large map and choosing your own path, you can be whoever you want to be in a vast variety of ships and missions in different regions on the map.

I have also had a lot of fun customizing my ship, whether that be the colors of the ship, or the weaponry on board, to the name of the ship (The SwagginWaggin)... I have also enjoyed aligning myself with the various factions, there seem to be at least 30-40 of them.

Pro's --> Great space exploration game, complex enough to make it enjoyable for more experienced gamers but also doesn't have a huge learning curve.

Con's --> Storyline is pretty weak and the quests and farming for gold can get a little repetitive if you don't enjoy the exploration aspect too much.

7/10

reviewText:
This is a great space combat game, with RPG elements.  Cruising through space, capturing ships, looting and upgrading is a lot of fun.  There are not too many games in this genre. They all seeml to be too old, too complex or they require subscriptions.  Starpoint Gemini 2 is a winner.

Short comments on the game:
- It is more arcade than simualtion.
- The story is not bad, but the presentation is very weak.
- At times the voice acting is rediculously bad
-  Dont worry about the story becuase the gameplay is engaging and addictive
- The graphics are great, minus a few hiccups here and there
- Would take about 30-40 hours to play through campaign
- Lots to do in this game. DLC is also available and the devs love to support this game
- Stop and take a screen capture! F11 will hide all the HUDs so your screen capture comes out like a Carl Sagan wet dream.
- The trading and mining is weak, but the value and money making is in capturing enemy ships and selling them and their cargo. Its 5x better than running materials from one side of the map to the other to make money.
- There are some great video tutorials on youtube that can jumpstart your ship capturing / pirating skils .  Search: Tensiaka" on youtube for valuable ship cap[turing and combat tutorials
hoursPlayed: ship options and open world win out.  I  give it   --   8.5/10"

reviewText:
This game could be so great. A real worthy successor for the likes of Freelancer and Privateer but it has so many flaws that it is very close to not being recommendable...
I still recommend it though for those in urgent need of a space sim who don’t like Elite: Dangerous and can’t wait for Star Citizen since chances are good that you still will get lost in the vicious circle of just one more mission to be one step closer to the next upgrade/weapon/ship.

Let’s start with the good things:
I really like the music…
ok… that’s not all, there is so much to see and do in this game, too. The galaxy is huge and there are many (unique) space stations and planets to visit, missions to do, artifacts/blueprints to track down and especially ships to destroy, buy or capture. Yes, you can capture enemy ships – in theory – that is one part where the design just doesn’t work out so well, more on that later. You also gain experience and level up which will give you skill points and every 5 level a point for perks. Skills feel rather cheap and bad for me. There are 4 active skills (temporary boosts) you can invest your points in, each skill for one of the available weapon systems (railgun, plasma, beam and heavy (missiles)). So you basically decide which is your favorite weapon system and put your skill points into that skill. Perks are passive but also don’t feel that well thought out. Again you can increase the effectiveness of your favorite weapon system up to 3 times and then there are a lot of semi useful perks to invest in. Additionally you get permanent bonuses by getting (steam) achievements (never seen that before in a game...)

The actual space simulation needs to get used to, too. I was expecting a feeling like in the old games and even bought a joystick to get the good old times back, but that just doesn’t work out (for me). The shooting is turret based (you have chase cam and no cockpit view anyway), meaning you can see around your ship and you just move the camera freely and aim with your mouse (depending on the turret placement on the ship). Furthermore the hit feedback is so bad that I quickly decided to switch to beam weapons that are instant hit so I know where I aim is what I hit. Railgun and plasma are projectiles flying somewhere in the direction of the enemy and unless you are not fighting a huge freighter close combat you barely see if you hit or not and especially if not why not (ok, it might just need to get used to but beam seems the better solution). Also you can just tell the system to auto fire (that's why there are acurracy stats you can influence, but I want to play the game as space shooter and not strategy game like star wolves so I don't want to use autoaim...)

What is really bad and I don’t understand how the design can fail so hard is that you can’t see your enemy information in the hud. Instead the hud is clustered with stupid, bad looking buttons I barely use (which I could easily access by keys). You only see the enemy information when the enemy is in sight and when he is close it is so fast moving that you can barely read it. So what is happening all the time is: There is a bunch of enemies closing in, you see them in the radar, you can target them (via hotkey) but you have either to start flying into their direction (which is a great idea when it turns out that they are deadly) or switch to turret and target mode and move your camera wildly to get them into focus and be able to identify their threat level. Both very inconvenient since you should be able to quickly cycle through all targets and identify them with one glance. Well perhaps I’m missing something, there even is an info hotkey but it won’t work for enemy ships, only for special objects.

The other really bad design issue is the character level system. You level up quite fast and the missions you can get (you don’t have to visit stations to get missions, you will get them while in space, which is good) show the suggested level you should have to take that mission. The problem is: the character level does tell ♥♥♥♥ about your actual strength. That only depends on your ship and weaponry. So this indicator is useless in the first place. Coincidentally it is also useless in the second place because there are types of missions that are just no brainers – regardless of which level they show. If you have maintenance or science missions you just fly to the target, repair or inspect it aaand… it’s done. On the other hand, good luck with rescue or capture missions, which are often impossible even on low level. So the balancing is very bad in general but luckily you can cheat your way out most of the time: Early game you just start your engine boosters and outrun every enemy, mid game they sometimes start blocking your boost mode but you can have a ship with cloaking device by then and just turn that on. Later this doesn't work and thats when you get in real trouble…
Talking about capturing… first you can’t capture 90% of the enemies because they have a larger crew than you have (capturing works this way: grapple the enemy with a tractor beam, send troops via teleporter to his ship, if you have more than him you possibly take over the ship). You can focus on capturing by searching for a cheap ship which allows a large army of troopers on board and you can get perks or officers (you can hire 3 officers for your ship, by the way, you can also hire merc ships that follow you and certain ships allow to take fighters on board you can launch during combat so you end up having your own fleet) that give a bonus on the capturing chances.
Second most of the time there are other ships around. So even when you manage to find a capturable ship chances are high that it will get blown apart by some other ship nearby. So it is a great feature in theory that just is no real fun most of the time but satisfying when it finally works.

Other weaknesses I like to mention:
The presentation is really bad. The main story has a ridiculous voice over most of the time, sometimes just dialog (not sure if it is a bug that voiceover is not playing because the music gets muted anyway) and sometimes just a text popup – atmosphere = 0.
The balancing of the main and some side missions is also a bad joke. You will be stuck for hours until you have enough money for a capable ship and after you finally progress you often get much easier missions afterwards.

The menus are confusing and tedious to use. E.g. you can either sell all cargo or one good at the merchant, but if you have more than 1 of a good you always have to go to the next screen to select how much of the good you want to sell (well everything!). And you will do that a lot because the screen shows if you are having good, mediocre or bad prices so you most likely don’t want to sell the goods with bad prices and rather fly to the next station. I think the ship loadout menu is simply bugged. edit: it is not bugged, turret handling is just another unintuive feature. Also when I unmount a rocket launcher I lose my missiles. The good thing is that I can store my ships with their loadout in my garage and can swap them easily depending on the situation (cargo space/troop count/gun power).
But the weapon/ship prices balancing could be much better. The next better systems are so expensive that it takes hours until you can afford something new that actually feels more powerful. The upgrade flow was much better/faster in Freelancer.
Last but not least there are that most annoying situations where a cutscene triggers in the middle of a fight, you can’t do anything but the fight continues in the background usually resulting in your death or at least a great headstart for your enemies.
So there are many occasions in the game where I ask myself: Did the developers actually play what they created?
And then I go back to the game desperately hunting for the next better ship…

reviewText:
Campaign done, here's *thoughts*.

Good:  To start off with, the music in SG2 is pretty great.  That's the first thing that hits me, and it's always good whenever I've booted the game.  A bit more variety would be nice too, after a while of free-roaming, it might get a little stale, but that goes for most games, really.

Bad:  The dialog and cutscenes are terrible.  No, really REALLY terrible.  The dialog is cliche, and *hideously* over-acted.  And those accents?  AND NO SKIP??  And the game doesn't really pause during these tedious, cliche, dragging, unskippable cutscenes.  I've seen better cutscenes in pretty much any other game.

Good:  Ships.  Mostly.  They're all quite recognizable, and have a lot of variety.  Once you know the ships, you can see a silhouette of most of them from most angles, and be able to ID the specific ship, or at least class.  Nexus ships a couple others in particular are EASY to spot.  Transports less so, but their class is obvious, so no matter.

Bad:  Firing arcs.  These are SPACE ships, they should have minimal blind spots.  They are not floating in an ocean, they need coverage above and below.

Bad:  There is a single best" weapon
hoursPlayed: the only NPC weapons that seem to DO anything are rails and plasma.  This balance state made it out of early access?\n\nBad:  Map and space design.  Freelancer got this right
voteText: and they had space with "too much" stuff in it.  The SG2 single solar system is both incredibly too small and insanely crowded.  It would be fine for say
helpfulPercent: underwater on an ocean planet
votesHelpful:
but for "outer space" it's just crowded.  And the "movement" field for dust floating past makes it feel like a fish tank with a broken filter and a bunch of pooping fish.

Space Engineers and EVE and to a lesser extent Freelancer made the game FEEL spacious.  SG2 is a lot of LARGE factions crammed into a small fish tank with a bunch of stuff floating in the water.

Bad:  I finally managed to get a ST-drive
votesTotal: yay!  ...Only to find that it doesn't actually work?  *All* the things should be working before the EA tag comes off.  At least implemented in some state."

reviewText: This is a great game with only some minor annoyances here and there. The freeroam aspect is awesome and the ability to break away from whatever you are doing to pursue an enemy, deliver some goods, or just mess around compares to games like the X series. Every ship in the game is flyable and upgradable, and the gameplay is heavily impacted by an RPG skillset and perks that you earn by leveling up. Between the great DLC (both free and paid) and the countless workshop mods, Starpoint Gemini 2 is a game you can easily sink many hours into. Definiately recommended.

reviewText:
If you enjoyed freelancer, you'll enjoy SPG2. It's not Xsomething were you can build an empire, but it's a very awesome space sim, were you fly capital ships and pewpew bad guys. Or 'roids.

Pro :
-very beautiful
-nice music
-open world (open space ?)
-lots of stuff to do
-big ships. Like carriers. I like carriers.
-very nice devs, that listen to the community, is very, very active on the steam forum/official forum, and overall nice guys
-a free DLC (a very large one). The other DLC is for a fee, but add lots of stuff, and they had a free large free patch alongside it. It's more than fair.
-a very nice and helpful community.
-may sound stupid, but I don't think I've seen 2 station that looks the same. Everything is unique, and it's awesome.
-technically, that's not the game itself (beside planets background), but the artworks are gorgeous.

Con :
-story is meh
-voice acting vary a lot, from good to terrible
-RPG part is limited, no hero customization for story mode, no choice and impact in the story whatsoever...
-no cockpit view. I don't care much, but for some it's an issue. But then, we are flying capital ship, so I guess the cockpit view would look like star trek or battlestar galactica, IE a bridge.

reviewText:
Fantastic game.

You can raid enemies, buy or sell at the trading markets, capture ships, defeat pirates or become a pirate yourselves.
This is an RPG with level up systems including perks and skills. I have logged around 50 hours and it just gets better and better.

The visuals and music are some of the most stunning art I have seen.
It's more beautiful than Elite Dangerous even.
However, this is not a space sim but a space RPG arcade-ish game with loads of fun and magical experiences.
Buy it, you won't regret :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So I have spent almost 30 hours with this game, and I have to say the boys at LGM have out done themselves. Even in Beta this game is shining, bringing back thoughts of games Like Free Lancer and EVE, while not directly copping them or stealing anything from them.

For all the negative reviews its still in BETA, I have not seen one complaint or gripe that has not been or is not being addressed, they are putting all the spit and polish on this as we speak and it shows in every aspect.

The Community for this game, even before release, is awesome, they care about what happens to it, what happens in it, and I think for the first time, atleast for me, the Devs of this game actually listen and work with the community to better it.

I've spent some scratch here at steam, I've been looking a long time for a quality game that I can enjoy, I've spent, I've looked, I've played, and when I say that even in Beta this was one of the best buys I've made here I am not kidding, its a gem pardon the pun.

If your looking for a game thats exciting, has RPG elements, space tactics, gun fights, top gun like action, look no further than SPG2!

reviewText:
I purchased this game almost immediately during early access because I had been wanting to play a good space sim for quite a long time. It is a vast improvement over the previous title in the series and successfully creates a fun space sim experience with some rpg progression for your character.

Initially after release the game was somewhat buggy, but the developers have ironed out the rough edges and even successfully adapted most of the user interface for gamepad control. Thus far I have spent most of my time in the sandbox mode, but I have recently begun the story playthrough. Both modes are fun to play with the story mode featuring a rather standard, but competently-executed space sim plot. Best of all is that steam workshop is available for the game and there have been many great mods that improve aspects of the gameplay as well as those that create custom content.

There is a good diversity of ships and weaponry in the game, with ship types ranging from small gunships and shuttle craft up to battleship size vessels available to be purchased. You can also hire officers who confer stat bonuses and other ships piloted by mercenaries to join you. There are numerous ways to make money including a robust trading economy, asteroids to mine, spatial phenomena to explore, odd jobs to be done, transport/taxi missions, and of course bounty hunter missions.

Combat is satisfying, though you certainly feel like more of a ship commander than a pilot. This is probably due to the game's third person perspective which suits the game well because most of the ships you will use are more like capital ships than fighters.

To sum it up, this is one of the best single player space sim/rpg's to come out in a very long time. In some ways I enjoy this game more than Elite: Dangerous.

reviewText:
Amazingly fun early game.
Decent middle game.
Slow endgame.

And I mean slow. Literally. The final ships are next to stationary in combat, and the lack of variety of options in combat makes this quite boring.  As you can only aim a fraction of your turrets at once you're left to turn on auto turrets with large ships which automatically takes care of firing all turrets so you have all your guns firing and just kind of sit there and occasionally use an ability if you need to kill a bit faster.

I can still happily recommend this game based on the great early and midgame that's highly reminiscent of Freelancer, but the endgame is poorly balanced and not particularly fun.

reviewText: I loved freelancer and this game has that feel to it. You can even capture ships and sale them which quickly becomes the best way to make money. reviewText: I liked the game so far, but I play a lot. I am an avid player of sci fi games, medieval, simulation battle and strategy. I play games so much I do not have any other form of life except work and games. I do stay in shape as I work out a lot. I can practically tell you exactly how to make a good game and it will be a #1 top seller, I have even made games myself constucting whole citys and governments with plots and story lines along with political agendas on governments and war. This Starpoint Gemini is very promising and is a good game. Couple of pointers to the developers, you should have ships hunt you down as if looking for you and then take off before being destoyed. Somone you can recognize that you have seen before but make some what elusive so he/she can come back again to hunt you from a jurisdiction you are not welcomed of course, but this should be once in great while not an everytime thing. Another thing is that when you get high level in the game all you see is big hard ships all the time, almost no small ones. In the begining you would see them a lot. I am level 80 and it does not seem to be going any highier(no complaints). But sometimes you exit from a station or a star gate and you are jumped by a horde of big ships just out of the blue(c'mon a little ridiculouse at times)it happens often and half the time you dont stand a chance unless you have big hired mercenarys that are expensive to maintain, which does take a big toll on the money you make. Sometimes you fall behind unless you really try to keep up the hustle and bustle of making money, then its more stress instead of pure enjoyment to try and keep good powerfull mercenarys at youre side. You should fan it out more to where at least 50% of the time there are still smaller groups of ships, or one or two important people(hunters) that show up to hunt you like I said previously, Instaed of being mobbed by a lot of big powerfull ships all the time. There still needs to be smaller ships around of all sizes. All I see now are big ships everywhere and almost no small ones traversing through space or hanging out at space stations. Its almost as if everybodys super rich now and got dreadnaughts and carriers becouse I am level 80 now. You need to tone that down to be more normal. If you did that the game would excell in greatness, otherwise that is a major downfall. But I do see it getting bigger more powerfull ships to attack you as you are highier in level that makes sense, but overall it needs to be re-worked to how i mentioned previously, thank you...... Several hours later on re-editing, I am now back to write what I said. There is more randomness, I guess i was just to fast to express at 80th level. I went back in different parts of the galaxy, it does get heavy at times and then again light on battles just depends. Also what i like is there are also missions you can take that can be much lower than youre level and also much highier. There still needs to  be ones that hunt you down and occasionally escape to come back another time but with a name to them you can recognize. May i also add i have not played the story line yet and am looking forward to it, its just in the free roam you can choose other characters instead of bieng stuck with the same story line one. Overall its all good and was very enjoyable playing. Would be nice to have another dozen songs in the game, the music is similar to eve music which I liked a lot when I played eve back in 2009.

reviewText:
This game is fun for a little while but there's so little variation it gets very tedious, which is a shame becuase the game mechanics are good.

Cons:
There are three quests you can do:
1)Go here and kill these guys.
2)Go here and scan this anomaly.
3)Go here and take stuff over there.

In order to make money you can either grind for days ferrying junk around, or buy a few upgrades for your crew and start hijacking enemy ships.  The former will take hours before you can buy your next ship, the latter will take minutes.  Rinse and repeat and winthin one afternoon you have the biggest, baddest ship with all the best hardware.

There's no variation across the map: each sector feels identical.  I guess in real life the universe is very homogenous but you probably shouldn't use WMAP as your basis for a space RPG.

The voice acting is pretty dull.  You can tell the actors aren't at all enthused by the story and nor was I.

Pros:
You can adjust the power balance of your shelds, weapons and engines, giving you a more hands on approach to aggresion, defence and running away.

Each weapon and shield module has its own power and can be drained if over taxed during a fight, forcing you to keep manouvering to keep your better charged side towards the enemy.  This makes the big lumbering ships more interesting to play.

You can take your unstoppable death machine, paint it shiny pink and name it Winnie the Pooh".

Summary:
The game world is too big and too bland.  If the devs had put the effort into writing a better story and varying the world rather than inflating it
date: this game could be great.  Otherwise it feels more like work than fun."

reviewText: As much as I want to like this game, I cannot.  Plagued with bugs that make it completely unplayable on half of my systems, I regret spending the money on this.  Windowed mode made it so I can't select menu items and had to delete the config file.  Attempting to turn on the gamepad support for my wired 360 controller made it completely impossible for me to actually select a menu item to start a game change settings, or even exit the game, so I had to alt+f4 out of the game.  The games graphics settings are ridiculous.  My systems all far outpace the requirements for this game, but only a couple of them will actually run the game smoothly.  I won't say there are better games out there that have the same feel as the first Starpoint Gemini, a game I love to play, but this game was just a disappointment and buggy mess.  Iceberg should be ashamed of releasing this game in this state.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Only been playing Early Access Beta a few hours and so far I'm really enjoying it,
Bit of a space sim fan in general…This reminds me some of Freelancer and EVE online.
Beta access is “freeroam”, I’ve found that it is fairly easy to pick up the basics but takes a while to get proficient, there is some real depth here and I’ve only scratched the surface.

First impressions, this game is looking great! Can only imagine how good it could be if it supported a multiplayer PU and had an optional cockpit/bridge view.
To early to call yet, but this game shows so much potential I think I can rate it in my top 5 space sims.
Anyhow having a blast so far and excited to see how the finished product plays!

Edit 8th of October 2014 My first impressions of SPG2 was that it might make my favourite top 5 space sims… it has the potential but it lacks a few vital essentials like a functional overview such as Freelancer. I was probably more than 20 hours into my early access when I realized just how much I missed it.
It’s no game breaker but having played Freelancer for well over 1500hrs and EVE online for much more you quickly realize just how much it holds the game back from being so much better. I’ve put some 140 hrs into the game (including beta) and I’m far from finished with it.

The good news is that some serious HUD tweaks are coming... the DEV’s have worked  tirelessly to address a few bugs that appeared at launch and they’ve been responding to some imbalance issues relating to levelling, the game having only been released a few weeks ago is already feeling much better!

Visually the game scores 9/10    Just beautiful!

Soundtrack 9/10      Really great soundtrack.

Storyline 6/10     Story was OK, I just didn’t get into it. Just dialogue, no character cut scenes at all.

Voice acting 6/10  Some were hilarious they were so bad.

Gameplay 8/10  Some solid gameplay mechanics, easy to get into but hard to master.

Replay ability 9/10  I got my money’s worth just playing the Beta early access!

General Content 9/10  Some real quality ships, gear, missions, bounties, capture ship gameplay etc…

LGM Dev’s 10/10 Never come across such a great team working so hard with so little.

I just finished the story mode… overall I enjoyed it, I’ve still got a few high bounties to go after and I haven’t explored all of the map. The game as far as the DEV’s are concerned isn’t finished they have a big wish list of features they still hope to implement and honestly I can’t wait.

Starpoint Gemini 2 easily makes it into my top 10 space sim games and if you’e looking for something to fill the void while we wait for Star Citizen, Elite Dangerous etc Just get it already.

SPG2 will keep on getting better as they go and I’m looking forward to it and new content.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Regularly updated by the developers and quickly nearing completion. How many EA titles can say that?

A great space flier with fairly simple flight mechanics - a nice change after some recent space game fails. This is not a dogfighting game. You spend most of your time flying bigger boats and trying to keep as many turrets on your target as possible. Standard mission running, war participation, trading and mining. The developers are keeping the campaign under wraps until release, so I don't have enough information to say how well it all ties together. I will say that the game is playable, as is, without the campaign. Random missions pop up on your map so it is more than possible to advance without it.

The price is great for the gameplay value and the campaign isn't even implimented yet. Very few bugs or flaws, and the ones that do make it in are quickly squished.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I find it hard to say that I recommend this game, or even that I do not.

I was a huge fan of Freelancer, and I have spent years looking for something that could fill the hole that Freelancer left behind. While Starpoint Gemini 2 comes close, it's not... quite... there yet. This game is still in development (just recently in beta), so bear that in mind.

All of the pieces are there - free roaming, trading, space battles - however, SG2 seems to fall flat a key area - ship movement. The starting vessel, a frigate, I believe, looks like a fish, moves like a fish, but steers like a cow. Most combat is spent circling around trying to get a bead on your enemy for about 1/2 a second before they move out of view once more. By that point, his buddy has been firing lasers up your butt. I'm a space combat noob with this game, but even Freelancer felt like it had more zip" to ship movement. I had to crank the mouse sensitivity just to feel like there was some kind of response to the controls.

Graphically
hoursPlayed: stations and space "stuff" is lovely to look at.\n\nThe game requires some optimization. When you are in a serious furball with many other ships

reviewText:
This is my methadone to keep me going until Star Citizen is out.

TLDR: It's very relaxing and enjoyable to roam around popping pirate ships, and scooping up their loot while exploring each hex.

Theres some nice progression with levels earning you skills and perks to your character.  Meanwhile spend that ill gotten cash to upgrade ship systems, buy fancier guns, and stock up on consumables to give your ship an edge in a fight, or i suppose help miners in their tedious rock popping. Hire troops for the wetwork, bridge officers for passive bonuses, and later on mercenary captains to back you up in a fight. Remember, it's OK to leave them to die.  Ultimately earn enough (or take over!) that fancy new ship you've been eying. There are also purchasable licenses for financial perks like earning extra credits when killing certain factions or cheaper goods from a certain corporation, even passive credits per month so you can sit around and do squat and still earn money just like the one percenter you are.

Exploration stays enjoyable by providing several modes of travel.  Pay to use an established warp gate (there's a way to make a one time license purchase to make them free though), or risk some damage and redshirt lives by using wormholes.  There's also these odd green bands of gravitational anomolies than can pull you in and whip you across several sectors very quickly, and finally the convenience of a consumable that will jump you a limited distance but can go from anywhere to any place you've already explored (and have enough drives to reach). It's also financially useful as the more stations you find, the better options you'll have to buy low and sell high with a decent variety of trade goods, some of them illicit in certain regions.

I wish the different parts of space were more varied, but at least it's all uniformly pretty with nebulas, asteroid fields, ice asteroids, and clouds of floating junk (all mineable if you're into that sort of thing) to add some variety. There are scannable anomolies, though only a few types and they all just do some sort of passive thing to surrounding space like scramble sensors or block teleporters. Scanning them down will get rid of the field, and earn some xp and credits if its a mission, otherwise they are ignorable.  Some of the more unique stations are very beautiful, like the Spire, but most of the space stuff is pretty samey.

Combat is  pretty simplistic you can even (and its recommended) set your turrets to autofire and concentrate on turning your best shields towards the light show. I wish the different guns and damage types were a little more varied. Heavy weapons have limted ammo but help speed things up, and there are some other consumables that can be deployed to help increase offense or survivability.  Spice things up by locking your grappling array on a wounded ship and teleporting over boarding parties of expendable no name grunts who throw their lives away so you can get a big payday.  If you're lucky and manage to successfully take over a ship you get to loot it far more effectively that picking through its wreckage, then tow it to the nearest dock to either add to your stable or sell off. Remember to keep the redshirts stocked every time you come back to port. Out in the stars are a bunch of named elites with bounty's on their heads and suprisingly deadly offensive capabilities to test your mettle.

Currently theres no real story, and a very limited number of missions that just help earn credits while doing the things you're already doing, but the foundation that is there is solid and fun, and surprisingly well polished for an early access title.

reviewText:
My original review (while the game was still in EA) is shown at the bottom. Please note that the sections on performance are not entirely relevant now, since the game runs much better.

REVIEW AFTER RELEASE:
---------------------------------------------------------
The game is a mix between Freelancer and X3. You can command fleets, hire wingmen, level up skills, buy massive battleships, trade, do missions. It's a lot like Darkstar One too, if we are comparing - but a lot better.

The focus here is on large ship battles - and with many ships, rather than smaller dogfigthing. Your starting ship is fairly large ( gunship), and some of the stuff I have seen to buy looks cool. You can climb the ranks and get battleships, dreadnoughts and the like, and command officers and mercs to help you out in battle, either on your own ship or as a wingman. You can even board enemy ships and take control of them, or tractor ships back to stations to sell them.

It looks lovely and has a massive open map to explore, complete with anomalies, slipstreams, wormholes, gates, planets, stations asteroid fields, nebula etc. - all you would come to expect from such a game and more.

The campaign is basic, but enjoyable. The voice-acting is absolutely atrocious though - the accents are all over the place and it is detrimental in an necessary way. You also have the option to free-roam, doing missions as they come along, trading or becoming a pirate. It has a complete reputation and trading system, allowing you to become anything you want.

A lack of multiplayer hits hard, since this game would be infinitely better with it and a real shame it is not included. It also seems to have a fairly repetitive and grindy feel to it - hence the mark of 6/10. If it had multiplayer I think my score would jump to 8/10 instantly though.

Jimbo Rating: 6/10

REVIEW WHILE IN EA:
---------------------------------------------------------
It's a mix between Freelancer and X3. You can command fleets, hire wingmen, level up skills, buy massive battleships, trade, do missions. It's a lot like Darkstar One too, if we are comparing - but a lot better.

The focus here is on large ship battles - and with many ships, rather than smaller dogfigthing. Your starting ship is fairly large, and some of the stuff I have seen to buy looks cool. You can even board enemy ships and take control of them, or tractor ships back to stations to sell them.

It looks lovely, but does seem to suffer from some performance issues. Putting the lengthy loading screens aside, I frequently experienced 0FPS drops when entering new sectors (occurrs quite often), which is a royal pain in the ♥♥♥ - especially if it happens to be a wing of enemy fighters.

It's still beta, but if they can fix the performance issues (severe slow downs, long load times, crashing) then this game will be a winner.

Jimbo Rating: 6/10

Note: why have I not recommended" this game - even though it's good? Simple: it's nigh-on un-playable (or very frustrating) at the moment
date: what with the aforementioned performance issues."

reviewText:
A quick review for this really cool space game.
I spent 35 hours on this game, In that time I finished the base game + one DLC, reached maximum Level and bought on the best ship. So even if I am not an expert, I think I can write a fair review.

+ Great Value.  You easily can beat the game 2 / 3 times without feeling bored. And the Dev team enhanced the First Starpoint to the new engine, it should give you around 50 hours more of gameplay.
+ Cool graphic; not realistic like Elite Dangerous for example, but a very nice representation of space.
+ Nice gameplay /  Mix of Rpg and tactic space game ; if you play in high difficulty it can be very challenging.
+ A lot of things to do.
+ A lot of ships and weapons to suit all tastes.
+ A extremely nice and responsive Dev Team. Basically if you post anything ( interesting ) on the steam forum, there is good chances that a Dev will be the first to answer.
+ A perfect example of how a Early Access should be done and handled.
+ Mod support.

- Scenario not great.
- A little bit short. I know it is against my + on greate value, but the thing is  I think 35 hours to reach max level is a little bit to quick; of course if you want the best weapons you will have to spend a lot of times, but it lacks the motivation of leveling up.
- At the end you are incredibly overpowered. Some may consider that a + , as a kind of reward but not for me.

So highly recommend this game made by a very nice and little team of passionate Dev.

Will by their next project without hesitation.

reviewText:
I want to like this game however the lower quality voice acting and the eventual repetitiveness of all of the mission are what broke it for me. There are still some missions that completely bug out for me and I am unable to complete them until I fail it and try again. The main story missions can be long and you can only save at the space stations so when it does fail half way through you have to start all over again and push through the voice acting once more.
Other than mousing over the faction and reading it's description there is nothing that makes any of the factions feel personal in any way.
There is the basis for a great game here and some might enjoy this title. I however cannot recommend it.

Update:
For a 9 man indie team then this is a very well done game. I must admit I did no research before reviewing. I'm very impressed that the developers care so deeply about their project to comment on my small post and describe their plans and ambitions for the future. I have decided to change my recommendation because in light of this I want this game to succeed. Space games are the future!

reviewText:
First off I want to say I am really enjoying the game.  Unlike some space games, most things are strait forward, and I don’t feel the need for a spreadsheet full of stats just to progress in the game.  SPG2 does this rather well without feeling like its dumbing anything down.  It really feels like a modern take on Freelancer, which I thought was a fun game as well.

The progression through the different levels is strait forward, but at the same time your profession choice seems to be inconsequential.  I wish you were given the profession choice after your first level up, so you could see what play style you actually preferred before making the permeate commitment.
The camera movement is a bit wonky with no real free look option.  Instead you have a sluggish turret cam that you can manually aim your guns with. Ironically I rarely use to aim since my guns work much better on auto-fire, so I just use it to look around.

The fire arcs for the guns are a neat gameplay mechanic but their representation in 3d space and on the 2d stats are hard to visualize. Often I think I should be hitting an enemy when I turn my camera to find out they are actually below me and outside my firing range since I don’t have a gun down there.
There is a wide variety of ships and weapons in the game, but you are left up to your own exploring to find out what they are and where they are sold. This seems a bit odd to me since the market place has a great mechanic to show you what, and where the best prices for trade commodities are, but none for ships and weapons?

The universe is large and has a good feel to it without feeling like your traveling through light-years of nothingness.  Every once and a while during PTE (Power -To-Engines) an enemy ship will drop out and take a shot at you or you will see an anomaly to scan and many other random events.  This adds a lot of fun and excitement to traveling that many games turn in to pain wrenching boredom just for the sake of realism.

You have plenty of choice as to how you would like to play, pirate, enforcer, trader, miner or just the storyline.  The missions are varied and while there is the occasional grind it is rare and in no way feels necessary for progression.  Also with a large universe there is plenty of places to explore and room for several playthroughs without getting old.

To sum it up I think it’s a great game that has a lot of replay potential.   So if you like the space game genre and would like a fun, non-hardcore game to jump in to, Starpont Gemini 2 is awesome choice.

reviewText: If you were a fan of the old Freelancer games then this game is for you. There is nothign cooler then sneaking up on your bounty target cloaked then firing a barage of missiles at its critical systems and then hacking the ship while your blasters tear it apart. The combat is engaging as well as the other aspects of the game. It is like a mix of Freelancer and the X series with a very user friendly interface. Fight pirates, trade, explore and everything else you love about a good 4X game. I recommend this to all fans of the genre.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This games has tons of potential. It has decent graphics, good game controls, easy to learn and best of all, it's pretty addicting. There are three character classes, different type of ship classes, different kinds of ships within the classes, four different weapon types and tons of missions to do in sandbox mode.  I've been playing as the gunner,  especializing on weapons systems,with the ability to adds different bonuses to the weapon system of choice. My weapon of choice being rail-guns.
It's up to you how you want to play. You have the option of playing as a pirate, enforcer, bounty hunter, miner, trader or a freelancer (combination of all). How effective you are doing each type of job depends on the ship, the combination of skills you select as you increase in experience and buying a license. License determine how much money you will receive depending on what the license is for. For example, a mining license will get you more money when selling ore, a police license will reward you with moneyfor everykill, and so on so forth. The point of it all is to make money, so you can get better ships and better gear, you know, the same old formula that keeps us coming back for more.  Overall I really like this game and if you are a fan of freelancer and games likes these I dont think you will be disappointed. The best part? It's only  going to get better.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Wow. What a fantastic game!

While it is in beta, I found there was lots to do in this game. Lots of exploration and complete freedom to do as you wish. In a space sim, for me at least, that's a very necessary feature. I plan on logging many more hours on this game in the future.

This game is absolutely beautiful. The universe feels immense; it feels like I could fly in any direction for miles. Just set a course, put full power to engines, and see what I come across. The game rewards exploration.

Some of the graphics optimization features are locked as it is in beta, but I found that lowering the graphics settings available and the game's resolution fixed any issues I was having. I anticipate that anyone with a more modern rig would have no issues running this on high settings.

Overall, it's worth the price they're asking for it. Good job devs! Looking forward to what comes in the future!

reviewText: Very fun. Kind of like a space sim crossed with an RPG but in a good way. Only just beginning but I can tell this is going to be a great game for my tastes. If you like Freelancer at all, this game is a must buy. The graphics are beautiful and it's a genuinely fun game. The systems are a little intimidating at first, but once you get the hang of it you'll be lighting up space like some sort of...thing...that does that...that provides light. In space. Through 'splosions. It's not necessarily the fastest-paced game but it's certainly not slow-paced at all. Sometimes you do small mundane things like mining asteroids for ores or scanning anomalies in deep space to farm xp. I can see how that might seem tedious to some. I personally enjoy that kind of stuff to break up the intense space battles. I've only gone after low-level guys in my little ship so far, but I can see how you could command huge fleets or have some massive ♥♥♥-kicking frigate at your own command and go headfirst into the toil of battle. Let me give you a TL;DR:\n\nFun game, slower paced farming stuff to do, really fun and exciting space battles, beautiful scenery, decent music. Definitely worth 40 bucks, though I got mine 20% off.

reviewText:
tl;dr: If you ever wanted a game that plays like Star Trek Online, but is actually good, buy this game.


You have all the basics of an open world space game - trading, piracy, bounty hunting, mining, scavening etc, but here you don't fly small fighters, but mostly capital ships. The smallest craft are gunships that already dwarf a fighter, and from there you have the entire scale up to massive freighters, dreadnoughts and carriers.

You can outfit your ship with a variety of light weapons (e.g. rail guns, plasma cannons, beam lasers) and heavy weapons (e.g. torpedoes, missiles, ion cannons), plus you can install upgrades to both the weapons and the various components of the ship.

Ships handle basically the same as in Star Trek Online, however you can choose between setting your turrets to fire-at-will or manual crosshair aiming. You have the four shield quadrants, weapons have distinct firing arcs, and thus some ships are better suited for frontal assault, others can deliver heavy broadside attacks. The game also features power distribution - at any time you can freely adjust your power between engines, shields and weapons, and I must say the UI for that is very slick, with a handy snap-on center point for a balanced distribution.

Speaking of ships, there is not just a variety in stats and turret placement, but a great variety in visual styles. From Battlestar Galactica-style bulky ships (my favourite is the Bishop class battleship) to organic-looking cruisers, there should be something for everyone's taste.

Space itself is not realistic. The game takes place within a star system with a binary star, and both the sizes of objects and all distances are massively scaled down. That's the one thing I am missing, that feeling of vast emptiness in space. Though the  Gemini System is large, seamless and sprawling, you come across a space station, mining platform, planet, asteroid field, nebula etc. every few steps. It's a busy place, maybe a bit too busy.

The skill system is rather simple, but does its job. There are 3 classes, each with 4 unique special abilities, and every level you get 1 skill point to upgrade one aspect of one ability. All abilities have multiple effects, and therefore can be developed into different directions. Every 5 levels you get a perk point which can be used on passive bonuses like increased turn speed, better trading prices, higher mining yield or more damage with a weapon category.

The graphics are very nice. The ships are gorgeously detailed, you can zoom in and see things like individual windows, weapon turrets are fully animated and you can even adjust your ship's color and metal glossiness (from dull to polished), you can even choose from a variety of decal and even give it name which is printed onto the hull.
But it's not just the ships. For example, SG2 features some of the most beautifully looking asteroid fields; the asteroids even cast shadows on the surrounding dust!

The sounds are well done, too, the UI sounds very Star-Trek-y and the engines, weapons very Star-Wars-y (i.e. the best of both worlds). But the highlight is the music. I've had the game during Early Access but only towards the actual release was most of the music added, and all I can say is that I was mightily surprised by how epic it is.

Finally, a few positive words about the community. The atmosphere is generally helpful and friendly, and the devs are very active on the Steam forums and are really listening and interacting with the players. The game is also Steamworks modding enabled, and you can already find stuff like the obligatory Star Trek ship packs.

reviewText: A very well put-together mix of a bit of Sid Meier's Pirates and Sci-Fi, with a bit of trading put in if you want to do this. Moreover, the visuals are great, even if a few features aren't working as of this being posted. Free Roam could use a bit of extra stuff to do, and the I only played a tiny bit of the campaign and got put off by the silly voice-acting. But overall, it's a solid Sci-Fi game, and definately worth buying. Especially with it's workshop support! Hope to see lots of mods soon! (Especially Star Wars ones :) )

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Starpoint Gemini 2(Just Released into Beta) is exactly what you want from this genre.

Compared to other space games in its genre, this game has more of an arcade style of gameplay.  If you are expecting the depth and simulation of something such as the X-Universe then you will probably want to avoid this game.   However if you want to just fly around in a beautiful world, and combat enemies with responsive and fuild controls then this game is for you.

The ship designs are very beautiful and unique. The enviornments are very good and beautiful to look at as you go through the game.

There are many different factions within the game that will end up fighting each other.  As well as many you can gain or lose rep with that will effect your standing with them.

The controls are easy to understand and reponsive.

Combat can be fought in several ways, you can hire a crew to improve stats of your ship such as accuracy, dodge, shields, etc.  However you can also tell the gunner to shoot for you, so either you can fly and have the A.I. shoot for you or you can Shoot and fly yourself.  This provides a nice change of pace for when you are wanting the A.I. to focus on defense or attack while you just maneuver the ship.

i have read the reviews and played the main scenario to its conclusion. and played a while in the open life goes on scenario. the reviews which criticize the game for its problems targeting and firing completely ignored the options. there are single keytokes which allow auto targetting closest enemy,closest object, fire primary weapons, etc. however they are not in my opinion logical. i recommend setting up your own hot keys through the options first. the voice overs are clearly russian, and the translations don't make for easily understood english. and the limited tracks make it useless to try to play with volumn on at all. the ships are easy to control and fun to use in a fight situation.

Overall it deserves higher than the ratings it gets. It is a fun game to play for a while, but loses its appeal eventually. probably a good week of enjoyable play, then move on to other games.

reviewText:
First off I want to say I am really enjoying the game.  Unlike some space games, most things are strait forward, and I don’t feel the need for a spreadsheet full of stats just to progress in the game.  SPG2 does this rather well without feeling like its dumbing anything down.  It really feels like a modern take on Freelancer, which I thought was a fun game as well.

The progression through the different levels is strait forward, but at the same time your profession choice seems to be inconsequential.  I wish you were given the profession choice after your first level up, so you could see what play style you actually preferred before making the permeate commitment.
The camera movement is a bit wonky with no real free look option.  Instead you have a sluggish turret cam that you can manually aim your guns with. Ironically I rarely use to aim since my guns work much better on auto-fire, so I just use it to look around.

The fire arcs for the guns are a neat gameplay mechanic but their representation in 3d space and on the 2d stats are hard to visualize. Often I think I should be hitting an enemy when I turn my camera to find out they are actually below me and outside my firing range since I don’t have a gun down there.
There is a wide variety of ships and weapons in the game, but you are left up to your own exploring to find out what they are and where they are sold. This seems a bit odd to me since the market place has a great mechanic to show you what, and where the best prices for trade commodities are, but none for ships and weapons?

The universe is large and has a good feel to it without feeling like your traveling through light-years of nothingness.  Every once and a while during PTE (Power -To-Engines) an enemy ship will drop out and take a shot at you or you will see an anomaly to scan and many other random events.  This adds a lot of fun and excitement to traveling that many games turn in to pain wrenching boredom just for the sake of realism.

You have plenty of choice as to how you would like to play, pirate, enforcer, trader, miner or just the storyline.  The missions are varied and while there is the occasional grind it is rare and in no way feels necessary for progression.  Also with a large universe there is plenty of places to explore and room for several playthroughs without getting old.

To sum it up I think it’s a great game that has a lot of replay potential.   So if you like the space game genre and would like a fun, non-hardcore game to jump in to, Starpont Gemini 2 is awesome choice.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alright. First of all, I am not going to comment on the technical issues currently existing in the game. It's very resource hungry, and there's an unpatched memory leak forcing you to close the game roughly every hour. The devs will have to address this before the final version is released.

Also: What this game IS NOT, is Eve Offline". Anyone who says such things is severely overhyping the title. It is
recommended:
a Freelancer clone.

Now for the meat of the review.
=THE GOOD=
1. Fluid interesting combat
hoursPlayed: but don't expect dogfights. It plays more like traditional naval battles with turrets and missiles.\n2. Responsive dev team. They take community input to heart and make changes as needed.\n3. Very large map. So large
voteText: that travelling from one corner to the other would take you probably 20-30 minutes.\n4. Seamless travel. There's still warpgates and jumpdrives available to the player
helpfulPercent:
but no "zones" or loading screens.
5. Many different factions enables you to work with and shoot whoever you want.
6. Many different ships. Enough variety to keep it fresh and interesting.
7. A bounty system that enables you to live out your inner Boba Fett. Be the space cop you always dreamed of being!

=THE BAD=
1. Ship designs are... different. Maybe I'm used to the look of EVE
votesHelpful: or WingCommander
votesTotal: or Homeworld
votesFunny: but I expect space ships to have a certain bulkiness and weight to them. Most of the ships in this game either look like some derivative of a shark/fish
commentsCount: or an insect. It's very strange cruising along and seeing a flying praying mantis scoot by. The rest look dated. It's like the devs took the Freelancer inspiration a little too far
column16: and saddening that the mod community is starting to produce models far better than the "official" ones shipping with release. You can have more than 5
column17: 000 polys on a model these days
column18: guys...\n\n2. Combat. I know I said it was a "good" aspect
column19: but I just want to make something clear here. 90% of battles I've been in
column20: no matter what ship I'm using
column21: no matter what my loadout is
column22: I can win by pushing three buttons on my keyboard: Railgun skill -> Damage amp -> Fire at will. Done. And this is playing on Hard Mode. There is something inherently wrong with being able to destroy a dreadnought with a frigate.\n\n3. Combat (again). Missiles and other 'heavy weapons' are very pointless. It's odd you can only fire them once the little orange bar on your reticle fills up
column23: nearly defeating the point of having them. On one ship
column25: I opted for no missiles or heavy weapons of any kind and noticed absolutely no difference in my ability to destroy anything and everything. They're effectively redundant
column26:
and with the current system in place I cannot see this ever changing.

4. Ship customization is basically not a thing.
People have been praising customization in their reviews
column27: but I feel they are being dishonest. You can customize your ships in-so-far as being able to change their paint job or logo
column28: or how shiny it is. That's it. As far as gear and parts are concerned
column29: you're only tuning stuff already on your ship
column30: and you do so by scrolling down a list and simply getting the most expensive thing on there. You're not really buying new engines
column32: or a different powerplant. You're not weighing the options and going "Hmm! If I get this
column33: then I can't have that!" It's not at all a mod system like what's in EVE. If your ship doesn't have a cloak
column34: you'll never have a cloak. If your ship has crappy shields
column35: you'll always have crappy shields. Etc. I hope this changes before release
column36:
but I somehow doubt it.

5. There's no reason to go beyond a cruiser. I can kill or capture anything with a Saratoga. I basically stopped playing when I towed a dreadnought into port and cashed it in. Apparently 90 guys can overpower a ship staffed by thousands.

6. It's far too easy to hit 'end game'. The first few hours of playing was just me saving up to buy a frigate. From my frigate
column37: I captured a destroyer. From my destroyer
column38: I captured enough ships to get a cruiser. From my cruiser
column39: I was unstoppable. I did this very rapidly
column40: despite pouring tens of hours into simple exploration.\n\n7. Bugs. Yeah yeah
column41: it's beta. I know. But it is rather silly flying up to a bounty
column43: and then just following them around until someone kills them
column44: yet -I- get rewarded with the bounty. I wish that worked in real life where if I watch the cops bust someone
column45: cash magically appears in my pocket.\n\n8. No main quest. It's supposed to have one eventually
column46: but despite being beta none of it is playable. You're stuck doing random low-paying generated missions
column47: or inventing your own fun. The the latter can be quite enjoyable
column48:
but you will run out of stuff to do in a hurry.

=Final Thoughts=
Despite its issues
column49: Starpoint Gemini 2 is quite the fun little sandbox and probably the closest thing we're ever going to get to a successor to Freelancer. Freelancer was far more polished as an overall product
column51: and until SG2 introduces a TRUE parts and customization system (which I consider to be a much greater problem than combat
column53: it will not hold a candle to Eve Online.\n\nThis is a beta that plays like an alpha
column54: but if you're hungry for a spaceship game with solid promise

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you like space games, sandboxes and rpgs, Starpoint Gemini 2 is the game you are looking for. I don't like buying early access games anymore but, well, I was looking for a game which would answer my sace exploration moods and I bought this.
Now the only thing I regret is not buying it sooner.
I can't wait for the complete game, this has the potential to become of of the best space game available.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not much to say, just one word: Super !!

This game is a real timekiller. Start with it and you can't stop again.

As old Elite veteran it's not such hard to understand this game even if you'll find a lot of new stuff inside.
Still there are some things I don't understand up to now, and sometimes I'm thinking 'less would be more' .
Yes, I know, there are tutorials outside, but.., I'm more the one to find out things myself :)

For newcomers, it will be a little hard before you'll understand the how to. But don't give up. The charm of this game will come while playing around!!

The bottom line is:
who love this kind of game will find a very well done, up-to-date, good looking and really exiting game. Check this one out!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWell. The game itself looks quite attractive though it might at first sight be frightening with all the panels and buttons involved in the gameplay process.  But u need only 1 hour or a bit more to get used to it and comparing to good old X series the controls are VERY simple. The gameplay itself is quite fun but has some issues still. For example while doing taxi" missions and stuff like that which is like 1000-10000 credit reward i managed to encounter a pirate that attacked me near the station. Thanks for the help of allied station system pilots i shot him down(though he was trying to run from me) and got rewarded with 8000000(!!!) credits. Which makes the other missions which i have to do in order to get exp absolutely silly regarding the reward they provide. And also there is still no main campaign task available (at least i couldn't find it in any menu). So the game is just a free roamer. But i hope it will get better. Music in game is decent. Overall i would rather recommend the game than not."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game does something that no other space themed game will let you do, captian your own ship and do whatever the hell you want in a massive open world. This game could already be realeased with the content in it so far and it is only in beta. It has limitless potential for mods. The only big issue with it is that you can't get mods off of the steam workshop yet because it will crash if you do. A great game already with great potential and well worth the 25 dollar early access price.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is just amazing from the graphics to the gameplay! Even though there is no storyline at the moment, purchasing the game in Early Access gives you the chance to get a feel for the game controls and also to try out some mods (Or even create some of your own mods). The one thing that I absolutley love about this game is the depth of the lore. You can sit down and read for some time on different factions and their background and know their allies and enemies. Since there isn't many Space Simulator games like this and I absolutley love Spaceship-type games, I felt as if I had to buy it. I was disappointed when a game called Black Prophecy was taken down and that game had a lot of potential, but looking through steam and spotting this game, I almost immideatly fell in love with it. As I've briefly said, the graphics are amazing to this game as you look around, from the giant nebulas to just looking at space. I strongly reccomend buying this game now if you haven't played it before and are looking to buy it when the storyline comes out because you do have to settle in to using the controls and finding out what you can actually do in this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Really impressed! It plays like a mix of Freelancer, X3 and Eve. It's super intuitive to pick up and play and the menus are all neatly laid out and self explanatory without sacrificing your ability to do what you need to do. Combat varies depending on the ship but for the most part it's slower than the frantic arcade dogfights seen in Chris Roberts games; with more emphasis on positioning and presenting sides of your ship to enemy.

Trading and economy functions as you'd expect, with goods costing more or less dependant on their origins and the political affiliations. There's a fair amount of contraband so it's best not to use the Loot All" button if you're trying to live a virtuous life.

In terms of Early Access content; the game feels very polished already with much of the world content seemingly in place and all game systems working as you'd expect. The current starting scenario is possibly a little bit easy
date: starting you off as it does with a mid level ship and plenty of tools already at your disposal. The missions are all randomly generatied (apparently depending on your actions
recommended: though I've yet to make a big enough impact on my galaxy to see this) and most of them follow a fairly standard template. It'd be nice for some more intensive missions with multiple stages but the ones that are there give you enough to do
hoursPlayed: and when they involve going through hostile areas they can become quite harrowing. The full game will have a story mode
voteText: which isn't present in this E.A release
helpfulPercent: so who knows what that will entail."
